( Ord. No. 2016-07 , § 2, 6-14-2016) 
8.20.030 - Regulation of private hydrants. 
A.  All owners of private property who have private fire hydrants located upon their property which are not serviced, maintained, flushed or tested by the city shall on an annual basis service, flush, test, repair and maintain the private fire hydrant so as to ensure that the hydrant is in proper working order in the event of emergency use. 
B.  All data gathered pursuant to subsection A of this section, including the location of the hydrant drawn on a scale map, shall be submitted each year by September 30th to the fire department, addressed directly to the chief of that department for filing in the permanent records. All costs associated with compliance with this section shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
C.  The owner may contract directly with the utility department of the city to perform the obligations of this section or the owner may employ the services of a private firm in submitting the testing and data required by this section. In the event the owner contracts directly with the city, the city shall submit the required report under subsection B of this section. 
D.  Any owner of private property who wishes to install a private hydrant on such property shall be subject to the provisions of this section. Additionally, all new private hydrants that are to be installed in the corporate limits of the city shall first be approved by the city utility director, fire chief, and city engineer. Such approval shall be conditioned upon review of the location, model type and flow specifications of the proposed hydrant. The proposed hydrant shall be a waterous hydrant or an approved equal such that it matches city specifications. 
E.  The fire chief or designee shall be responsible for the enforcement of this section. 
(Prior code § 5.11) 
( Ord. No. 2016-07 , § 1, 6-14-2016) 
8.20.040 - Outdoor fires and control thereof. 
A.  Definitions within this section. The following terms, phrases, and words and their derivations have the meanings given therein: 
1.  "Open fire" means any fire involving any type of combustible material, whether for cooking, pleasure or any other purpose, located anywhere within the City of River Falls, on public or private property. 
2.  "Outdoor cooking apparatus" means a charcoal grill, camping stove or similar apparatus designed exclusively for cooking food. 
3.  "Recreational fire" means any noncommercial burning of materials other than rubbish for pleasure, religious, ceremonial, cooking, or similar purposes in which the fuel burned is not contained in an incinerator, a barbecue grill, or a barbecue pit, and the total fuel area is not exceeding three feet in diameter and two feet in height. 
4.  "Waste and refuse" means all rubbish, garbage and residual matter of any kind, including grass trimmings, and leaves. 
5.  "Pyrotechnics" means fireworks or any incendiary/explosive device used for public display purposes whether indoors or outdoors. 
B.  Except as permitted in this section, no person shall burn or cause to be burned in any open fire any waste and refuse or hazardous materials upon any street, court, alley or private property within the city. 
C.  The use of portable drums, barrels or any containers used to burn leaves, yard wastes, rubbish, garbage, other household wastes or hazardous materials upon any premises within the city is prohibited. 
D.  No person shall burn, or cause or permit the burning of waste and refuse in any container which was designed for the sole purpose of burning any type of fuel, such as natural gas, fuel oil, propane, gasoline, kerosene, diesel fuel or wood used for heating purposes. 
E.  Fires set by the River Falls fire department for practice and instruction of fire fighters are allowed, along with burning of police records. 
F.  Outdoor cooking apparatus and open fires used for cooking are allowed. These are, however, limited to charcoal and gas grills, freestanding fireplaces (clay or metal) or fire pits. Use of outdoor cooking apparatuses on multi-residential dwelling decks is prohibited. 
G.  Recreational fires are allowed only under the following circumstances: 
1.  Only clean and clear (unpainted and unfinished) wood, split firewood, tree limbs or charcoal may be burned. No rubbish, yard waste, garbage, household wastes or hazardous materials may be burned. 
2.  No recreational fire shall be in an area larger than three feet in diameter (three feet by three feet). 
3.  Each fire must be attended by at least one-person eighteen (18) years old or older when lighting the fire and at all times until the fire is completely extinguished. 
4.  A fire extinguisher or water hose shall be available nearby at all times. 
5.  Each fire shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet from any structure and/or combustible material. 
6.  No accelerants such as gasoline, kerosene or any other accelerant may be used, with the exception of charcoal lighter fluid. 
7.  When burning, all burning material must be completely contained within the freestanding fireplace (metal or clay) or fire pit and shall not extend beyond the confines of such container and flame height shall not exceed four feet from base of fire. 
8.  No fire shall cause smoke that has the tendency of creating a public nuisance or a traffic hazard due to decreased or diminished visibility. 
9.  The open fire and embers must be completely extinguished before the open fire is vacated. 
10.  If a fire pit is used, the construction and use of the fire pit shall, in addition to the above requirements, comply with the following requirements: 
a.  The diameter of the pit shall not exceed three feet. 
b.  The depth of the pit shall be one to two feet deep and covered when not in use. 
c.  The rim of the pit shall be lined with rock, concrete, brick or steal that is twelve (12) inches wide all around the perimeter. 
11.  Recreational fires shall only be used outdoors at ground level. 
H.  The fire chief is granted the authority to issue burning permits for no more than a forty-eight (48) hour period at a fee to be set by the common council, from time to time. Such a permit shall allow the burning of waste construction materials, including but not limited to wood and paper products and trees and vegetation resulting from land clearing. The fire chief shall not issue a permit to burn any material that could result in a health hazard. Each permit shall indicate when material can be burned, where it will be burned, where it can be burned, under what wind and other climatic conditions and shall include such other or further restrictions that the fire chief may require to protect the health and safety of the general public. 
I.  The fire chief is granted the authority as a delegation of power by the common council under Section 323.11, Wis. Stats., to declare a fire emergency in the city, during which open fires are prohibited, for such period of time during which emergency conditions exist or are likely to exist. 
J.  Violations of this section are punishable under Chapter 1.20 of the city code and citations for such violations may be issued by the fire chief or his or her designee as well as by the police department. 
(Ord. 2003-17 § 1) 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, §§ 1, 2, 1-24-2012; Ord. No. 2016-07 , § 1, 6-14-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-02, § 1, adopted January 24, 2012, renamed Section 8.20.040 from burning waste and refuse to outdoor fires and control thereof 
8.20.050 - Use of pyrotechnics. 
    The use of pyrotechnics shall be prohibited in the city except follows: 
A.  Fireworks in conjunction with a community event for which the required permits has been procured, limited to sites in Hoffman Park or such other locations as may be approved by the fire chief. 
B.  The mayor, or his/her designated representative, has the authority to issue pyrotechnic permits. A city permit is required for use/discharge of any pyrotechnics within the city. 
(Ord. 2003-17 § 2) 
8.20.060 - Key boxes. 
A.  Definitions. The following definitions shall govern this section: 
    "Authority having jurisdiction (AHJ)" means an individual responsible for enforcing the requirements of a code or standard, or for approving equipment, materials, an installation, or procedure. The chief or the chief's designee. 
    "Chief" means the fire chief of the Department. 
    "Department" means the River Falls Fire Department. 
    "Key box" means a container of a type approved by the department, installed in an accessible location by the property owner, for the purpose of containing keys or other devices for the department use only, to gain quick access to all areas of the premises without having to damage property. 
    "Public building" means any structure, including exterior parts of such building, such as a porch, exterior platform, or steps providing means of ingress or egress, used in whole or in part as a place of resort, assemblage, lodging, trade, traffic, occupancy, or use by the public or by three or more tenants. 
B.  Requirements for Access by the Department. As required in subsection 2.16.070D.2., when access to or within a structure or an area is unduly difficult because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for lifesaving or fire fighting purposes, the chief may require a key box to be installed in an accessible location. The key box shall be a type approved by the fire chief with one master key and shall contain keys to gain necessary access as required by the chief. The type, number of, and location of key boxes shall be approved by the AHJ. 
C.  Contents of Key Box. The box shall contain one master key or other devices to allow access as required by the AHJ. 
D.  Notification in Event of Change in Means of Access. If keys or devices for access are changed, a new master key or device shall be provided to the department within three business days. 
E.  Key Boxes Required. The AHJ shall require key boxes in the following instances: 
1.  In all public buildings that are locked for security reasons and that have common corridors serving individual units; 
2.  In any sprinkled public building; 
3.  The size or construction of the building, or the physical barriers or terrain around the building may dictate more than one key box at the discretion of the AHJ. 
F.  Inspections. During a regular fire inspection, the key or other device stored in a key box may be accessed to ensure access to all areas of the structure. 
G.  Penalty. Failure or refusal to obey may result in assessment of penalty in accordance with Section 1.20 of the city code. 
(Ord. No. 2008-37, § 1, 2-10-2009) 
8.20.080 - Frequency of fire prevention inspections. 
    In accord with Wis. Adm. Code Section SPS 314.01(13)(b)7., fire prevention inspections of all public buildings and places of employment in the city shall be conducted at least once per calendar year or more often as is ordered by the fire chief, provided, however, that the interval between each such inspection shall not exceed fifteen (15) months. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 7-10-2012; Ord. No. 2016-07 , § 1, 6-14-2016) 
Chapter 8.21 - FALSE ALARM SERVICES 
Sections: 

8.21.005 - Purpose. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted pursuant to Section 62.11(5), Wis. Stats., to deal with the public safety hazard caused by the necessity of both the fire and police departments having to respond to all private fire and security alarms, including false alarms, triggered by malfunctioning or poorly maintained private alarm systems, both to protect the personal safety of individuals who are found at the location of activated alarms as well as to prevent damage, as well as to promote the interests of the public in general and to protect the public from injuries and deaths resulting from possible fires or criminal acts. The fire and police departments respond to alarms as a form of current service provision to the owners of properties at which alarms are maintained. To this extent, the purpose of this chapter is to designate alarm responses as a service for which a fee is established when the fire and police departments are confronted with false alarms. 
(Ord. 2007-23 § 1 (part)) 
8.21.010 - False alarms. 
A.  The user of any private alarm system which, upon activation, elicits a response from the city fire or police departments, shall be subject to the following answering fee schedule for each false alarm within a successive twelve (12) month period. A false alarm shall be defined as any alarm which is discharged falsely, accidentally, through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, lack of maintenance, or by negligence of the owner or lessee of the alarm system or of his or her employees or agents. 
B.  Fee Schedule. A fee is imposed for every fire or police department response to a false alarm. The schedule for applicable fees is established by resolution of the common council, incorporated herein by reference, and shall be subject to modification from time to time upon motion of the common council. 
C.  Exemption From Fee. False alarms shall not include: 
1.  Alarms that occur during electrical storms, tornadoes, blizzards, or other natural disaster or acts of God; 
2.  Disruption of the telephone circuits beyond the control of the alarm company and/or the alarm user; 
3.  Electrical power or disruption or failure not caused by the user. 
D.  Imposition of Fee Structure-Waiver. This fee shall be imposed whether the fire or police departments received the alarm by direct connection or through an intermediary, such as an answering service or modified central station. If the fire chief or police chief is notified in writing prior to the day of installation of a new alarm system, the fee imposed by this section shall be waived for a ninety (90) day period beginning with the date of the installation. 
E.  The alarm user shall, in the case of fire alarms, provide the fire department and shall, in the case of security alarms, provide the police department with the names and telephone numbers of at least two people who can be reached at any time, day or night, who are authorized to respond to an emergency signal transmitted by the automatic alarm system or device, and who are trained in the operation and functioning of the alarm system, and who can open the premise wherein the alarm system is installed. It shall be a violation of this section if any of these persons cannot be contacted, or if they refuse to cooperate with and respond at the request of fire or police department officials, they and/or the alarm user may be subject to a forfeiture under the penalty section of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
F.  No alarm system designed to transmit emergency messages directly to the fire or police department/9-1-1 or through an intermediary service shall be tested or demonstrated without first notifying the fire department and the fire dispatcher or police department prior to the start of such test or demonstration. 
(Ord. 2007-23 § 1 (part)) 
8.21.020 - Liability. 
A.  The city shall be under no duty or obligation to a subscriber or to any other person concerning any provisions of this chapter, including but not limited to any defects in an alarm system or any delays in transmission, or response to any alarm. 
B.  Any person feeling aggrieved by a fee assessment of the fire or police department may appeal such decision to the city council within fifteen (15) days of the written notification made by the fire chief or police chief or their respective designees. The date of the written notice shall be the date of mailing or the date of personal service of the notice. The appeal shall be filed with the city clerk upon a form provided by the city clerk's office. The appeal shall be in writing and specify the reason for the appeal. The city council may reverse or affirm wholly or in part, or may modify the decision of the fire or police department. The vote of the majority of the members of the city council present shall be necessary to reverse or modify the decision of the fire or police department. 
(Ord. 2007-23 § 1 (part)) 
8.21.030 - Payment of fee-Placement of unpaid fees on property tax role. 
    Fees assessed under Section 8.21.010(B) shall be paid within thirty (30) days of the date on which the invoice for such service is mailed to the owner of the property from which the false alarm causing the need for the service was generated. Any fee remaining unpaid as of October 31st, in any calendar year, shall be placed on the tax roll for the property in question pursuant to Section 66.0627, Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. 2007-23 § 1 (part)) 
Chapter 8.24 - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS INCIDENT RESPONSE REIMBURSEMENT 
Sections: 

8.24.010 - Prohibited discharges. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall discharge or cause to be discharged, leaked, leached or spilled on any public or private street, alley, public or private property, or unto the ground, surface waters, subsurface waters or aquifers or within the city, except those areas specifically licensed for waste disposal or landfill activities and to receive such materials, any explosive, flammable or combustible solid, liquid or gas, any radioactive material at or above Nuclear Regulatory Restriction levels, etiologic agents or any solid, liquid or gas creating a hazard, potential hazard or public nuisance or any solid, liquid or gas having a deleterious effect on the environment. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.020 - Containment, cleanup and restoration. 
    Any person, firm or corporation in violation of Section 8.24.010, shall so notify the fire department and begin immediate actions to contain, clean up and remove to an approved repository the offending material(s) and restore the site to its original condition, with the offending person, firm or corporation being responsible for all expenses incurred. Should any person, firm or corporation fail to engage the necessary personnel and equipment to comply or to complete the requirements of this section, the office of the emergency government coordinator may order the required actions to be taken by public or private sources, and allow the recovery of any and all costs incurred by the city as action imposed by Section 8.24.030. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.030 - Emergency services response. 
    Emergency services response includes, but is not limited to: fire service, emergency medical service, law enforcement and public works. A person, firm or corporation who possesses or controls a hazardous substance which is discharged or who causes the discharge of a hazardous substance shall be responsible for reimbursement to the responding agencies for actual and necessary expenses incurred in carrying out their duties under this chapter. Actual and necessary expenses may include, but not be limited to: replacement of equipment damaged by the hazardous material, cleaning, decontamination and maintenance of the equipment specific to the incident, costs incurred in the procurement and use of specialized equipment specific to the incident, specific laboratory expenses incurred in the recognition and identification of hazardous substances in the evaluation of response, decontamination, clean up and medical surveillance, and incurred costs in future medical surveillance or response personnel as required by the responding agency's medical advisor. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.040 - Site access. 
    Access to any site, public or private, where a prohibited discharge is indicated or suspected will be provided to fire department officers and staff and to city police department personnel for the purpose of evaluating the threat to the public and monitoring containment, cleanup and restoration activities. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.050 - Public protection. 
    Should any prohibited discharge occur which threatens the life, safety or health of the public at, near or around the site of a prohibited discharge, and the situation is so critical that immediate steps must be taken to protect life and limb, the fire chief, his or her assistant, or the senior police official on the scene of the emergency may order an evacuation of the area or take other appropriate steps for a period of time until the common council for the city can take appropriate action. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.060 - Enforcement. 
    The fire chief and emergency government director shall have authority to issue citations or complaints under this chapter. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.070 - Civil liability. 
    Any person, firm or corporation in violation of this chapter shall be liable to the city for any expenses incurred by the city for loss or damage sustained by the city by reason of such violations. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
8.24.080 - Coordination with county. 
    Prior to the city pursuing an enforcement action, it should coordinate enforcement options with the affected county pursuant to Wis. Stats. Section 166.22. 
(Ord. 1997-8 (part)) 
Chapter 8.28 - NOISE CONTROL 
Sections: 

8.28.010 - Excessive noise prohibited. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excessive noise which either unreasonably annoys, disturbs or affects the comfort, repose, health or peace of others. 
(Prior code § 9.09(1)) 
8.28.020 - Unlawful acts. 
    The following acts are declared to be loud, disturbing and excessive noises in violation of this chapter, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
A.  Horns and Signalling Devices. The sounding of any horn or signalling device on any automobile, motorcycle or other vehicle, except as a danger warning. 
B.  Radios and Phonographs. The using, operating or permitting to be played any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet or comfort of the persons residing in the neighborhood at any time with louder volume than is reasonably necessary for convenient hearing of the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle, chamber or area in which such machine or device is being operated. 
C.  Loud Speakers and Amplifiers for Advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. 
D.  Yelling and Shouting. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office or in any dwelling, hotel, motel or other place of residence or any persons in the vicinity. 
E.  Animals and Birds. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
F.  Whistles or Sirens. The blowing of a whistle or any siren except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work, as a warning of fire or danger or the testing of such warning systems or by public emergency vehicles. 
G.  Operation of Motor Vehicles. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. Operation of a motor vehicle so as to cause the tires to squeal or the motor to race excessively. 
H.  Defect in Vehicle or Load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise which disturbs the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
I.  Air Pollution. Sound Trucks for Advertising Purposes. The use of sound trucks or any other vehicle equipped with sound amplifying devices for the purposes of advertising any program, project or meeting of any public agency, private business, religious organization, civic group, political party or charitable organization. 
J.  Loading, Unloading or Opening Boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers. 
K.  Construction or Repairing of Buildings. The erection (including excavating), demolition, alteration or repair of any building between ten p.m. and six a.m. where such work disturbs the peace, quiet and comfort of the persons residing in the neighborhood, except in cases of emergency when such repair work is needed to protect the health and safety of the persons in the vicinity. 
L.  Schools, Churches and Hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street or private property adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or hospital while the same are in use which unreasonably interferes with the use thereof. 
M.  Hawkers and Peddlers. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
N.  Pile Drivers, Hammers, Chain Saws and Power Mowers. The operation between ten p.m. and six a.m. of any pile driver, power shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, power or electric hoist, chain saw, power mower or other equipment or appliance the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise. 
O.  Blowers, Fans and Engines. The operation of any noise creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(Prior code § 9.09(2)) 
8.28.030 - Exceptions. 
A.  The city council may, upon proper application, grant exceptions to the above for special events, celebrations, parades and similar activities. 
B.  Maintenance of public property by city employees. 
(Prior code § 9.09(3)) 
8.28.040 - Enforcement. 
    Violations of this chapter shall be enforced by the police department using the municipal citation method as provided in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 9.09(4)) 
Chapter 8.32 - NUISANCES GENERALLY 
Sections: 

8.32.010 - Public nuisances prohibited. 
    No person shall erect, contrive, cause, continue, maintain or permit to exist any public nuisance within the city. 
(Prior code § 10.01) 
8.32.020 - Public nuisance defined. 
    A "public nuisance" is a thing, act, occupation, condition or use of property which continues for such length of time as to: 
A.  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public; 
B.  In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property; 
C.  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; 
D.  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of water or other public way or the use of public property. 
(Prior code § 10.02) 
8.32.030 - Public nuisances affecting health. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are specifically declared to be public health nuisances; but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other health nuisances coming within the definition of Section 8.32.020: 
A.  Adulterated Food. All decayed, adulterated or unwholesome food or drink sold or offered for sale to the public. 
B.  Unburied Carcasses. Carcasses of animals, birds or fowl not intended for human consumption or food which are not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within twenty-four (24) hours after death. 
C.  Breeding Places for Insects or Vermin. Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish, rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, scrap metal or any material in which flies, mosquitoes, disease-carrying insects, rats or other vermin can breed. 
D.  Stagnant Water. All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, f1ies or other insects can multiply. 
E.  Privy Vaults and Garbage Cans. Privy vaults and garbage cans which are not fly-tight. 
F.  Water Pollution. The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or other body of water by sewage, creamery or industrial wastes or other substances. 
G.  Noxious Odors. Any use of property, substances or things within the city emitting or causing any foul, offensive, noisome, noxious or disagreeable odors, gases, effluvia or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the city. 
H.  Street Pollution. Any use of property which causes any noxious or unwholesome liquid or substance to flow into or upon any street, gutter, alley, sidewalk or public place within the city. 
I.  Air Pollution. The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes, gases, fly ash, industrial dust or other atmospheric pollutants within the city or within one mile therefrom in such quantities as to endanger the health of persons of ordinary sensibilities or threaten or cause substantial damage to property in the city. 
(Prior code § 10.03(1)-(5), (7)-(10)) 
8.32.040 - Public nuisances offending morals and decency. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of Section 8.32.020: 
A.  Disorderly Houses. All disorderly houses, bawdy houses, houses of ill-fame, gambling houses and buildings or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling. 
B.  Gambling Devices. All gambling devices and slot machines. 
C.  Unlicensed Sale of Liquor and Beer. All places where alcohol beverages are sold, possessed, stored, brewed, bottled, manufactured or rectified without a permit or license as provided for by the ordinances of the city. 
D.  Continuous Violation of City Ordinances. Any place or premises within the city where city ordinances or state laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals or welfare are openly, continuously, repeatedly and intentionally violated. 
E.  Illegal Drinking. Any place or premises resorted to for the purpose of drinking intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages in violation of state laws. 
F.  Public Urination/Defecation/Vomiting Prohibited. No person shall defecate, vomit, or urinate in any public place, on any public property, or on any private property not designed, intended, and approved for such use. Example: A public restroom or portable satellite facility. Violations of this section shall be subject to the forfeiture established by the city and the court may require, upon conviction, that the offender pay as restitution the actual costs of cleaning up a public or private place as a result of a prohibited act. 
(Ord. 1998-9; prior code § 10.04) 
( Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1, 5-13-14 ) 
8.32.050 - Public nuisances affecting peace and safety. 
    The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety; but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting public peace or safety coming within the definition of Section 8.32.020: 
A.  Dangerous Signs and Billboards. All signs, billboards, awnings and other similar structures over or near streets, sidewalks, public grounds or places frequented by the public, so situated or constructed as to endanger the public safety. 
B.  Illegal Buildings. All buildings erected, repaired or altered in violation of city ordinances relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures within the city. 
C.  Unauthorized Traffic Signs. All unauthorized signs, signals, markings or devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing which purport to be or may be mistaken as official traffic control devices or railroad signs or signals or which, because of their color, location, brilliance or manner of operation, interfere with the effectiveness of any such device, sign or signal. 
D.  Obstruction of Intersections. All trees, hedges, billboards or other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an intersection or pedestrian crosswalk. 
E.  Low-Hanging Tree Limbs. All limbs of trees which project over and less than ten (10) feet above any public sidewalk, street or other public place. 
F.  Dangerous Trees. All trees which are a menace to public safety or are the cause of substantial annoyance to the general public. 
G.  Fireworks. All use or display of fireworks except as provided by state laws and city ordinances. 
H.  Dilapidated Buildings. All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human use. 
I.  Low-Hanging Wires and Cables. All wires and cables over streets, alleys or public grounds which are strung less than fifteen (15) feet above the surface thereof. 
J.  Noisy Animals or Fowl. The keeping or harboring of any animal or fowl which, by frequent or habitual howling, yelping, barking, crowing or making of other noises, greatly annoys or disturbs a neighborhood or any considerable number of persons within the city. 
K.  Obstructions of Streets-Excavations. All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by the ordinances of the city but including those which, although made in accordance with such ordinances, are kept or maintained for an unreasonable or illegal length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished or which do not conform to the permit. 
L.  Unlawful Assemblies. Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street, alley or sidewalk or of a public street, alley or sidewalk which causes large crowds of people to gather, obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks. 
(Prior code § 10.05) 
8.32.060 - Abatement of public nuisances. 
A.  Enforcement. The city officials shall enforce those provisions of this chapter that come within the jurisdiction of their offices; and they shall make periodic inspections and inspections upon complaint to insure that such provisions are not violated. No action shall be taken under this section to abate a public nuisance unless the officer has inspected or caused to be inspected the premises where the nuisance is alleged to exist and has satisfied himself that a nuisance does in fact exist. 
B.  Summary Abatement. If the inspecting officer determines that a public nuisance exists within the city and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, the mayor may direct the proper officer to cause the same to be abated and charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant or person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance, as the case may be. 
C.  Abatement After Notice. If the inspecting officer determines that a public nuisance exists on private premises but that such nuisance does not threaten great and immediate danger to the public health, safety, peace, morals or decency, he or she shall serve notice on the person causing or maintaining the nuisance to remove the same within ten (10) days. If such nuisance is not removed within ten (10) days, the proper officer shall cause the nuisance to be removed as provided in subsection B of this section. 
D.  Other Methods not Excluded. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the city or its officials in accordance with the laws of the state. 
E.  Court Order. Except when necessary under subsection B of this section, an officer hereunder shall not use force to obtain access to private property to abate a public nuisance but shall request permission to enter upon private property if such premises are occupied and, if such permission is denied, shall apply to any court having jurisdiction for an order assisting the abatement of the public nuisance. 
(Prior code § 10.10) 
8.32.070 - Cost of abatement. 
    In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection, contrivance, creation, continuance or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the city shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant person causing, permitting or maintaining the nuisance; and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge. 
(Prior code § 10.11) 
Chapter 8.36 - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, adopted February 22, 2011, repealed the former Chapter 8.36, §§ 8.36.010-8.36.160, and § 2 of Ord. No. 2011-02 enacted a new Chapter 8.36 as set out herein. The former Chapter 8.36 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from prior code §§ 11.05(1)-11.05(14), 11.10; Ord. No. 2001-11; Ord. No. 2002-05; Ord. No. 2002-11 and Ord. No. 2009-3, adopted February 24, 2009. 

8.36.010 - Regulated. 
    No person shall dispose of solid waste in the city except as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this section, the following terms shall have the meaning stated: 
    "Alleyside" means at the edge of the abutting alley of the rear yard of the residence. 
    "Appliances or white goods" includes refrigerators, freezers, dryers, washers, stoves, large furniture, other appliances, box springs, mattresses and uncut carpeting. 
    "Certified landfill" means any landfill that is properly licensed and approved by the city for use. 
    "Certified recycling facility" means any recycling facility approved by the city for use. 
    "Compact fluorescent bulbs" or "CFLs" means a type of fluorescent lamp that is designed to replace an incandescent lamp and can fit into most existing light fixtures formerly used for incandescent. CFLs are more energy efficient than incandescent bulbs. 
    "Curbside" means at the curb of the abutting front yard street of the residence. 
    "Demolition debris" means waste resulting from the demolition of buildings and other manmade structures which may include: untreated wood, masonry, glass and plastic building parts. Demolition debris does not include asbestos waste, clean fill nor treated wood products. 
    "Duplex" see "unit." 
    "Fluorescent light bulbs" means a glass tube coated inside with fluorescent substance giving off light when mercury vapor in the tube is acted upon by electrons from the cathode. 
    "Multiple-family dwelling" means a property containing four or more residential units. 
    "Non-residential facilities and properties" means commercial, retail, industrial, institutional and government facilities and properties. This term does not include multiple-family dwellings. 
    "Plastic containers" means an individual, separate, rigid plastic bottle, can, jar or carton, except for a blister pack, that is originally used to contain a product that is the subject of retail sale. 
    "Post-consumer waste" means solid waste other than: 
1.  Solid waste generated in the production of goods; 
2.  Hazardous waste, as defined in Section 291.01, Wis. Stats; 
3.  Waste from construction and demolition of structures, scrap automobiles; or 
4.  High-volume industrial waste, as defined in Section 289.01, Wis. Stats. 
    "Refuse tag" means a tag purchased and attached to a bag of refuse to compensate the refuse hauler for disposal. Said tags are utilized when the standard refuse container is full. 
    "Residences" means private dwellings, apartments (three dwelling units or less) and rooming houses. 
    "Recyclables" means products that can be collected and remanufactured into new products after they've been used. 
    "Rooming house" means a building arranged or used for lodging for compensation, without meals, and not occupied as a single-family unit. 
    "Solid waste" has meaning given in Section 289.01 Wis. Stats. 
    "Triplex" see "unit." 
    "Unit" means a single-family residential home. A duplex shall be treated as two units, a triplex as three units and a rooming house with five rooms or less as one unit. Each five rooms of the rooming house or increment thereof shall be treated as one unit. (Example: Six rooms = two units; eleven (11) rooms = three units). 
    "White goods" see "appliances" 
    "Yard waste" has meaning given in Section 287.01 Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.030 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to maintain and protect the public health and sanitation by the removal of solid waste from residences in the city and to prevent any unregulated and unrestricted hauling of solid waste by means other than through the solid waste collection system established by this section so as to eliminate the disposal of solid waste along the streets, roads and other properties in and near the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.040 - Collection by the city. 
A.  Residential Collection. All solid waste accumulated in residential units in the city, together with such other solid waste which is the responsibility of the city or which is accumulated by the city or for the city shall be collected, conveyed and disposed of by the city or its authorized contractor. No person shall collect or dispose of any solid waste accumulated on residential unit premises of the city, except the city or its designated contractor. 
    For duplexes and triplexes, the default action by the city will be to include them in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services. However, these facilities may opt out of service as explained below. In addition, a duplex may have one set of containers to service both units. 
    For condominium units, the default action by the city will be to include them in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services. However, the city may allow a condominium unit to opt out in cases where the property is not suitable to individual service, such as cases where the units are stacked and no individual outside entrances for the units exist. 
    For a multiple-family dwelling (four units or more), the default action by the city will be to assume they will provide their own solid waste and recycling services. However, if a multi-family dwelling desires to be a part of the city contract, this may be allowed at the city's discretion. 
    Notwithstanding the above, owners of residences that are part of or contiguous to a commercial property under the same ownership and owners of duplexes, triplexes or rooming houses or other multiple-family dwellings may make private arrangements with any licensed hauler the owner may choose for the removal of the solid waste accumulated for those units. An owner choosing this option shall file a written notice with the city clerk stating the property address, the number of units and the licensed hauler that has been contracted with. The city's contractor shall not pick up solid waste at the exempt address nor shall the city's contractor charge the city or resident for any pickup at that residence. If this private option is chosen, solid waste shall be picked up at the exempt residence on at least a weekly basis and recycling shall be picked up on at least a bi-weekly basis. If solid waste is not being picked up at an exempt residence for any reason at least one each week, the city, in its sole discretion, can terminate the exemption by written notification to the owner at which time the residence goes back on city solid waste collection. 
B.  Accumulation by Nonresidential Facilities. Solid waste and recyclables accumulated by nonresidential facilities shall be properly disposed of by the owner, renter or other occupant of the premises. Appliances or white goods as defined above shall not be considered solid waste and the owner of each property wishing to dispose of such goods must make independent arrangements with any hauler for the pickup of these items and pay the hauler directly for their disposal. 
C.  Separation and Processing of Recyclables. 
1.  Recyclables. Occupants of single-family, duplexes, triplexes, rooming houses, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties in the city shall separate materials from their post-consumer waste as outlined in Section 287.07, Wis. Stats. In addition to state requirements fluorescent light bulbs and compact florescent bulbs shall also be diverted from the post-consumer waste. 
2.  Care of Separated Materials. To the greatest extent practicable, the recyclable materials separated in accordance with subsection (C)(1) of this section shall be clean and kept free of contaminates such as food or product residue, oil and grease, or other non-recyclable materials, including, but not limited to: household hazardous waste, medical waste and agriculture chemical containers. Recyclable materials shall be stored in a manner which protects them from wind, rain and other inclement weather conditions. 
3.  Management of Lead Acid Batteries, White Goods, Waste Oil and Yard Waste. Occupants of single-family, duplexes, triplexes and rooming houses, multiple-family dwellings and non-residential facilities and properties shall manage fluorescent light bulbs, lead acid batteries, white goods, waste oil and yard waste as follows: 
a.  Fluorescent light bulbs shall be taken to the Pierce County recycling center or residents can contact a licensed vendor to properly dispose of fluorescent bulbs; 
b.  Compact fluorescent bulbs (CFLs) shall be recycled at River Falls Municipal Utility or at a recycling facility; 
c.  Lead acid batteries shall be taken to an area retail business that sells vehicle batteries; 
d.  White goods shall be collected and recycled by the city's hauler for a fee, taken to the Pierce County recycling center or other certified recycling facility; 
e.  Waste oil shall be brought to a designated waste oil collection site. Contact the city for a list of designated sites; 
f.  Yard waste shall be managed on-site or brought to a municipal compost facility. Yard waste shall not be placed in a landfill or incinerator. 
4.  Preparation and Collection of Recyclable Materials. Except as otherwise directed by the city of River Falls, occupants of single-family, duplex, triplex and rooming house residences shall do the following for the preparation and collection of the separated materials specified in subsection (C)(1) of this section. 
a.  If applicable, items shall be rinsed clean; 
b.  Remove any covers and pumps; 
c.  Items shall be placed in the approved recycling cart and placed curbside or alleyside on the day designated for collection or they shall be placed in the designated receptacle of an established drop-off site during the days and hours of operation; 
d.  Waste tires shall be collected by the city's hauler for a fee, brought to a licensed tire collection facility, or brought to the Pierce County recycling center. 
5.  Multiple-Family Dwellings and Nonresidential Facilities and Properties. Owners or designated agents of these properties in the city that are not participating in city contracted collection, shall do all the following unless post-consumer waste generated in those properties is treated at a processing facility that recovers for recycling the material specified in Section 287.07(3), Wis. Stats., from that solid waste in as pure a form as is technically feasible: 
a.  Provide adequate containers for the recycling program established in compliance with this section; 
b.  Notify all users, tenants and occupants in writing at the time of renting or leasing, and at least semiannually thereafter, about the programs in this section; 
c.  Provide for the collection of recyclables materials separated from the solid waste by the tenants and the delivery of the receptacle materials to a recycling facility; 
d.  Notify tenants of reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste, which materials are collected, how to prepare recyclable materials in order to meet the processing requirement, collection methods or sites, locations and hours of operation, and a contact person or company, including a name, address and phone number. 
6.  Procedures and Penalties. Procedures for prosecuting and penalties for violating this section will be the responsible party designated. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.050 - Residential solid waste and recycling containers. 
A.  Solid Waste Containers. The owner or resident of each residence on city garbage service shall be provided a container for refuse by the city or its contracted hauler. Each residential unit shall be allowed one container per week for the base charge of solid waste. A residential unit may, if desired, place additional containers for pickup if the containers have the required refuse tag attached. Additional containers will not be collected if tags are not attached and residential occupants will be so notified by the city's hauler by virtue of placing a noncollection notice on the additional containers. 
B.  Recycling Container. The owner or residence on city garbage service shall be provided a container for recyclables from the city or its contracted hauler. 
C.  Residential solid waste and recycling containers shall be stored out of view as much as possible, but shall be readily accessible on the curbside or alleyside on the day of collection. 
D.  Nonresidential facilities' and properties' refuse and recycling shall be stored in containers with covers when located outside a building. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.060 - Collection practices. 
A.  Solid waste shall be collected at least once each week according to a schedule to be determined and notice given by the collector at least two weeks in advance. 
B.  Collection locations shall not be changed by the hauler without consent from the city. 
C.  No person shall place any solid waste or recyclables at the collection point more than eighteen (18) hours prior to the regular scheduled pickup. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.070 - Reserved. 
8.36.080 - Burning solid waste. 
    No person shall burn any solid waste within the city, except as provided by city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.090 - Marking of vehicles. 
    The holder of a license or contract for solid waste and recycling shall have the vehicles used for that purpose conspicuously marked with the hauler's name and refuse collection permit number on the cab doors. Such vehicles shall comply with all state regulations and shall be subject to inspection by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.100 - Spillage or leakage of solid waste. 
    All solid waste, recycling and yard waste hauled on public streets in the city shall be securely tied and covered so as to prevent leakage, spilling or blowing. No person shall allow any solid waste, recycling or yard waste to leak, spill, blow or drop from any vehicle on any public street within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.110 - Fees. 
A.  The fee schedule for residential collection shall be approved by the common council and shall be on file with the city clerk. 
B.  Fees shall be collected by the city or its contracted hauler as established in the city contract for solid waste and recycling services. 
C.  For billing purposes, a duplex shall typically be considered as two billing units, a triplex as three billing units and rooming houses shall be charged at the established per unit rate. However, if the property opts for less containers than units, as allowed in Section 8.36.040(A), they shall be billed appropriately for the number of containers serviced at the property. 
D.  Collection of delinquent accounts for solid waste and recycling services shall be in accordance with Section 13.32.010 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011; Ord. No. 2016-01 , § 1, 1-26-2016) 
8.36.120 - Financing. 
    The cost of operation of the residential solid waste and waste collection system shall be paid from fees established in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.130 - Unlawful disposal. 
    No person shall dispose of solid waste other than as stated above. No person or business shall place their solid waste on another person's property or in a private or public dumpster, unless written permission has been obtained from the owner. No person shall place any solid waste or yard waste in any street, alley or other public place or upon any private property, whether owned by such person or not, within the city limits unless it is in proper containers for collection, nor shall any person throw and deposit any solid waste or yard waste in any stream or other body of water. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. No person shall cast, place or deposit anywhere within the city any solid waste in such manner that it might be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, sewer, parkway or other public place or into any occupied premises within the city. Nothing contained herein shall prohibit individual, properly maintained compost piles. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
8.36.140 - Notice. 
    Adequate notice of the revisions and additions to this section shall be transmitted to the citizens via written or electronic communications or notices with utility billings or notices in the city newsletter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011; Ord. No. 2016-01 , § 1, 1-26-2016) 
8.36.150 - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of this chapter or any regulation, rule or order made hereunder, shall be subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 1.16 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-22-2011) 
Chapter 8.40 - WEEDS AND NOXIOUS GROWTH*[] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* Prior code history: Prior code § 10.03(6) 

8.40.010 - Purpose. 
A.  Property in the city shall be maintained in a manner which does not present a health or safety hazard to owners of adjacent parcels of real estate, and in a manner which does not detract from the appearance of the neighborhood and the value of real estate in the vicinity. 
B.  All areas on a lot not used for buildings, driveways, walkways, parking areas or other permitted improvements, shall be established with suitable vegetation to prevent erosion due to wind and water. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
8.40.020 - Definitions. 
    "Destroy" means the complete killing of weeds or the killing of weed plants above the surface of the ground by the use of chemicals, cutting, tillage, cropping system, pasturing live stock or any or all of these in effective combination, at such time and in such manner as will effectually prevent such plants from maturing to the bloom or flower stage. 
    "Garden" means cultivated and defined areas containing perennials, annuals, trees, shrubs, flowers, ornamental grasses, agricultural crops, vegetables or native plantings used for aesthetic and/or wildlife promotion. 
    "Land management plan" means a written plan related to management of the lawn which contains a legal description of the lawn upon which the grass or other plantings will exceed six inches in length, a statement of intent and purpose for the lawn, a general description of the vegetation types, plants and plant succession involved, and the specified management and maintenance techniques to be employed. The management plan must include provisions for cutting at a length not greater that six inches in the boulevard area, that portion between the sidewalk and the street, or a strip not less than four feet wide adjacent to the street, where there is no sidewalk, and the vision clearance triangle area on any corner lot. 
    "Noxious Weeds" means noxious, rank vegetation such as cockleburs, poison ivy, poison sumac, poison oak, wild parsnip, spotted knapweed, leafy spurge ragweed, burdock, Canadian thistle, marijuana, english charlock, wild mustard, field bindweed, goatsbeard, field dodder, indian mustard, oxeye daisy, sow thistle, harmful barberry, bull thistle and wild lettuce. 
    Noxious weeds do not include native grasses and plants indigenous to western Wisconsin that are: 
1.  Planted and maintained as part of a garden or for landscaping purposes; or 
2.  Planted and maintained for erosion control, weed control or designated wildlife areas. 
    "Plantings" means trees, shrubs, bushes and other common landscape plantings. 
    "Wetland" means a swampy or marshy area and include the areas immediately surrounding ponds, river beds and streams. 
    "Wooded area" means an area densely covered with trees and shrubs. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
8.40.030 - Prohibitions. 
A.  Untended, rank and unmanaged growth of vegetation on any property within the city which is visible from any public way, street, sidewalk or alley is declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated in accordance with the procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
8.40.040 - Responsibilities. 
A.  On property having lawns of the conventional bluegrass type, such conventional lawn areas shall be maintained at a height not to exceed six inches. 
B.  Every person shall destroy all noxious weeds on all lands which he shall own, occupy or control. The person having immediate charge of any public lands shall destroy noxious weeds on such lands. 
C.  Plantings and gardens shall be maintained so as not to present hazards to adjoining properties or to persons or vehicles traveling on public ways and shall be subject to the provisions of Section 17.08.030 of this code. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
8.40.050 - Abatement by the city. 
A.  If the provisions of this chapter are not complied with, the weed inspector or designee shall serve written notice once per calendar year upon the owner, lessee or occupant, or any person having care or control of any such lot or land to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  If the person upon whom the notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to cut and remove or to cause to be cut and removed such weeds, grass, brush or other vegetation within five days of date of such notice, or if no person can be found in the city who either is or claims to be the owner of such lot or land or who represents or claims to represent such owner, the weed inspector or designee shall cause such weeds, grass, brush, and other vegetation on such lot or land to be cut and removed. 
C.  The actual cost of such cutting and removal, and other costs associated with abatement shall be billed to the property owner by the city clerk, and payable to the city within thirty (30) days. Actual costs shall be from the current city fee schedule, payable to the city clerk. If the property owner has not been in violation of Section 8.40 during the previous three years, 50 percent of the current charge will be waived under the condition that payment is received within 30 calendar days. 
D.  Failure to pay the city for the services billed will result in the costs being assessed against the property as a special charge per Section 13.32.010. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-04, § 1, 3-9-10) 
8.40.060 - Managed natural landscaping. 
A.  It shall be lawful to grow native and naturalized plants to any heights, including ferns, wildflowers, grasses, forbs, shrubs and trees, in accordance with an approved land management plan when said plants were obtained not in violation of local, state, or federal laws. No employee of the city may undertake to damage, remove, burn or cut vegetation on a managed natural landscape incorporating native plants, except those specifically prohibited herein, and except on order of a court of record following a hearing at which it is established that noxious weeds exist in a managed natural landscape and that a condition creating a clear and present hazard to public health or safety has arisen. An action for a court order under this subsection shall provide that the destruction, cutting or removal of vegetation shall be selective unless general cutting, destruction or removal is necessary to eliminate the offending condition. 
B.  It is not the intent of this legislation to allow vegetated areas to be unmanaged or overgrown when such growth provides either a direct health hazard or provides a demonstrated breeding ground for fauna known to create a safety or health hazard. The city recognizes that a limited number of species may be indicators of neglect, a condition which may adversely affect human health or safety. The city has specifically defined certain noxious weeds recognized to be indicators of neglect. 
C.  Any owner or operator of land in the city may apply for approval of a land management plan for a natural lawn, one where the grasses exceed six inches in height, with the department of community development subject to provisions of this chapter. 
D.  Revocation of Land Management Plan. The land management plan may be revoked for failure to comply with the approved plan. Notice on intent to revoke the land management plan shall be appealed to the board of appeals. All applications for appeal shall be submitted within fifteen (15) days of notice of intent to revoke a land management plan. 
E.  Application Requirements. Each application for a land management plan shall be on a form provided by the department of community development and shall be accompanied by a fee from the current city fee schedule, payable to the city clerk. The department of community development shall send a copy of the application to all owners of property situated in whole or in part within two hundred (200) feet of the property for which a land management plan has been requested. If within fifteen (15) days of receipt of a copy of the application, at least fifty-one (51) percent of such property owners file written objections to the application with the department of community development. The department of community development shall refer the application to the board of appeals for hearing and decision, according to the provisions of Section 17.140.030 of this code. 
F.  Application for Appeals. The owner or operator of land in the city may appeal a decision of the department of community development for a land management plan. All appeals shall be to the board of appeals of the city which shall hear such appeals. All applications for appeals shall be submitted within fifteen (15) days of notice or denial of the land management plan. 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
8.40.070 - Exclusions. 
A.  This chapter shall not apply to: 
1.  Wooded areas; or 
2.  Wetlands 
(Ord. 2004-12 (part)) 
Chapter 8.48 - SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES BANNED[4] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2010-13, § 1, adopted August 10, 2010, repealed the former Chapter 8.48, §§ 8.48.010-8.48.080, and enacted a new Chapter 8.48 as set out herein. The former Chapter 8.48 pertained to and derived from Ord. No. 2003-12. 

8.48.010 - Smoking in public places banned. 
    The provisions of Section 101.123, Wis. Stats., as amended by 2009 Wisconsin Act 12 relating to the prohibition of smoking in variously described enclosed places are hereby adopted and made part of this code by reference. Penalties for each violation shall be as prescribed in Chapter 1.20, General Penalty, of this code. As is prescribed in Section 101.123, a warning notice shall be issued to the "person in charge" for the first violation. 
(Ord. No. 2010-13, § 2, 8-10-2010) 
Chapter 8.50 - OCCUPANCY LIMITS FOR BARS AND RESTAURANTS 
Sections: 

8.50.001 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter shall be to regulate the occupancy of bars and restaurants licensed by the city and made open or available to the public at large or to members, whether free of charge, subject to a cover charge or whether on a membership basis. It is in the interest of the public health, safety and welfare to prevent overcrowding in such facilities so as to avoid injury or deaths which may be a direct or indirect result of overcrowding. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
8.50.010 - Adoption of state regulations by reference. 
    Wis. Adm. Code Ch. SPS 376 is adopted by reference and shall constitute a portion of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
8.50.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall control interpretation and application of this chapter. 
    "Day" means a twenty-four (24) hour period of time commencing with twelve a.m. and ending with eleven fifty-nine p.m. 
    "Facility" means any licensed premises open to the public, whether in the form of a restaurant or a bar, tavern, pub or other premises licensed for the "on sale" consumption of fermented malt beverages, wine or intoxicating liquor. 
    "License" means a license to engage in the operation of a facility. 
    "Occupants" means the number of members of the public found in a facility at any given time. 
    "Owner" means the owner of the licensed premises or the occupant thereof, whether under a formal or informal lease or rental arrangement who is further denominated as the holder of a license for operation of the facility in question. 
    "Public" means any and all persons other than the owner, his or her agents and employees. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
8.50.030 - Overcrowding prohibited. 
    No facility shall allow occupants, in a number exceeding the maximum established for said facility in accord with Section 8.50.010 to congregate in, to be found upon or otherwise to sit, stand or otherwise occupy, loiter upon or to be located in or situated within the facility at any one time. The owner of each such facility shall be required at all times to maintain strict compliance with this restriction. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
8.50.040 - Posting of occupancy limits. 
    Immediately adjacent to each door or other means of public access to a facility, the owner shall post a sign, eighteen (18) by twelve (12) inches in size, which shall contain the following information: Occupancy Limit XXX Persons in letters not less than three inches in height. Occupancy shall also be posted on liquor license issued by the city. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
8.50.050 - Public portion of facility to be open to inspection. 
A.  At all times when the facility is open to public occupancy, the owner shall afford unrestricted access to all portions of the facility which are open to the public to all city police officers, fire officers, ambulance and emergency response personnel and building inspectors. The owner, by applying for and receiving a license to operate the facility shall be deemed to consent to such entry by city officers and employees for the purposes of maintaining the safety and welfare of the public. This chapter presumes that city officers and employees charged with or empowered to enforce its terms may accept the general invitation to the public to enter the premises for these purposes. 
B.  Upon entry to the premises for the purpose of enforcing this chapter, city officers and employees may take all reasonable measures to count the number of the public, present upon the premises at that time, including but not limited to asking all members of the public to depart the facility for purposes of engaging in such a count. 
C.  If upon counting the public present on the premises it is determined that the number is in excess of that established under Section 8.50.030, at the option of the owner or the agent of the owner apparently in charge of the facility on the owner's behalf, either a number of persons equivalent to the excess number shall be required to leave the facility or the facility may be closed for the remainder of the day in question. 
(Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
8.50.060 - Penalties for violation. 
    Violations of this chapter shall subject the owner to one or more of the following potential penalties: 
A.  For each violation of this chapter, a forfeiture may be assessed in accordance with the general penalty in Chapter 1.20 of the municipal code and the schedule of deposits as established by the municipal judge. 
B.  For the second and each subsequent violation of this chapter within a twelve (12) month period, an injunction against the continued use of the facility may be sought from the circuit court. 
C.  The city may, in addition to or in lieu of one or both of the penalties prescribed under subsections A and B of this section, pursue license revocation proceedings against the owner. 
(Ord. 2008-25 § 1: Ord. 2008-18 § 1 (part)) 
Title 9 - PUBLIC PEACE, MORALS AND WELFARE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 9.04 - STATE CRIMINAL STATUTES ADOPTED 
Sections: 

9.04.010 - Offenses against state laws subject to forfeiture.

Stats. shall serve to so modify and amend this section. 
(Ord. 2001-11 § 16; Ord. 2001-8; prior code §§ 9.29.288-9.961.575) 
9.04.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person who violates any provision of this title shall be subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. In addition to any penalty imposed for violation of Section 9.943.01(1), any person who causes physical damage to or destroys any public property shall be liable for the costs of replacing or repairing such property. The parent of any unemancipated minor child who violates Section 9.943(1) may also be held liable for the cost of repairing such damaged or destroyed property in accordance with Section 895.035, Wis. Stats. 
(Editorially amended during 2002 codification: prior code § 9.25) 
Chapter 9.08 - PROPERTY OFFENSES 
Sections: 

9.08.010 - Obstructing streets and sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall stand, sit, loaf or loiter or engage in any sport or exercise on any public street, sidewalk, bridge or public ground within the city in such manner as to prevent or obstruct the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic thereon or to prevent or hinder free ingress to or egress from any place of business or amusement or any church, public hall or meeting place. 
(Prior code § 9.07) 
9.08.020 - Open cisterns, wells, basements or other dangerous excavations prohibited. 
    No person shall have or permit on any premises owned or occupied by him or her any open cisterns, cesspools, wells, unused basements, excavations or other dangerous openings. All such places shall be filled, securely covered or fastened in such manner as to prevent injury to any person; and any cover shall be of such design, size and weight that the same cannot be removed by small children. 
(Prior code § 9.08) 
9.08.030 - Littering prohibited. 
    No person shall throw any glass, refuse, waste, filth or other litter upon the streets, alleys, highways, public parks or other property of the city or upon any private property or upon the surface of any body of water within the city. 
(Prior code § 9.11) 
9.08.040 - Fishing and swimming from bridges prohibited. 
A.  No person shall fish, jump, dive or swim from any bridge located in the city which has been posted as to these restrictions. 
B.  No person shall swim, wade or otherwise enter the water in Lake George without a watercraft at points within one hundred (100) feet of the Falls St. bridge and dam. 
C.  The city shall cause signs to be erected and posted at such locations as the city council directs to carry out the provisions of subsections A and B of this section. 
(Prior code § 9.19) 
9.08.050 - Presence of persons on roofs prohibited. 
    No person shall be on the roof of any commercial, retail or manufacturing business or any public building without the express consent of the owner of the building or his or her designate. 
(Prior code § 9.20) 
9.08.060 - Unauthorized presence. 
A.  No student who is under suspension, expulsion, or other disciplinary procedures excluding him or her for attending any school located within the city or any other school district, or any person not a student presently enrolled or not an employee of such schools or not a parent or guardian of a student, or not an otherwise authorized person, shall be present within any school building or upon any school grounds without having first secured authorization to be there from the principal or other person in charge of the school building or school grounds, except while in direct route to secure such authorization. 
B.  Any unauthorized person who shall come upon school property and fail to secure authorization, or refuses to leave upon request by the school principal or any person acting under the direction of the school principal or any police officer, has committed a violation of this section. 
C.  "Unauthorized presence" shall include any vehicle that is found on school property which has not received permission to be there. If the occupants or owners are not on school property for some legitimate business or activity or are parked in an area that regulates parking to certain authorized vehicles, they are in violation. Such vehicle may be issued a city parking citation and may be towed away at the direction of the school principal or person in charge of such school building. Law enforcement officers may also have any vehicle towed away which, because of its location, creates a hazard to life or property. 
D.  "Authorized person" shall include: 
1.  Any person who is present at any school building or school grounds for the purpose previously authorized by the school or their designee; 
2.  Any person transporting a student and who utilizes the driveway specified for loading and unloading personnel; 
3.  Any person utilizing a designated area for attending an athletic or other organized or authorized school event; 
4.  Any student in good standing at that particular school; 
5.  Any person acting in the normal course of business activities. 
(Prior code § 9.22) 
9.08.070 - Failure to return library material. 
A.  Definitions. 
    "Library" has the same definition as Section 943.61(l)(b) of the Wis. Stats. 
    "Library materials" has the same definition as Section 943.61(l)(c), Wis. Stats. 
B.  No person who checks out on loan library materials or who allows another to use their library authorization to check out library materials shall fail to return any or all the materials according to the established procedure of the library. 
1.  No person shall use, provide, or give false or fictitious identification or information to obtain library loan authorization or to obtain or check out any library materials. 
C.  All library authorizations issued to children age seventeen (17) or younger shall require parental or legal guardian authorization. Any parent or guardian of a child who has given authorization for that child to check out on loan library materials shall assume co-liability for any violation of this section by the child. 
D.  Any person violating this section and failing to return any or all of the library materials is liable to the city and subject to the following: 
1.  Replacement costs of the unreturned materials; 
2.  Suspension of their library privileges; and 
3.  Suspension of the privilege of receiving any city license or permit. 
E.  The library board is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations for library checkout/loan procedures, conduct and behavior and operations of the library. These rules shall be conspicuously posted for public notice at the library. The rules and regulations established by the library board as posted shall be incorporated by reference into this section as fully as if set forth herein. No person shall violate the posted rules or regulations of the library. 
F.  Any person violating this section, in addition to the penalties contained in subsection D of this section, shall be subject to the penalties contained in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 9.24) 
Chapter 9.12 - TRESPASSING 
Sections: 

9.12.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to enable private owners of real property, situated within the city and to which the public has some implicit right of access, to exclude persons from that property where the person has committed a crime on the premises or violated the properly posted rules of conduct for the property. 
(Prior code § 9.21(1)) 
9.12.020 - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms when used in this chapter shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    "Common areas" means all areas of the property which are maintained for the common use of its tenants or the general public incidental to the conduct of the normal and legitimate activities upon the premises, including but not limited to parking lots and ramps, private roadways, reception areas, rotunda, waiting areas, hallways, restroom facilities, elevators, escalators, and staircases. 
    "Covered premises" means any improved real property, or portion thereof, to which the public has an implicit right of access including, but not limited to places of worship, shopping malls, retail sales facilities, hotels, motels, nursing homes, restaurants, multiple-family residential buildings, hospitals, medical and dental offices, clubs, lodges, office buildings, banks and financial institutions, transit stations, athletic and recreational facilities, personal service establishments, theaters, and day care facilities. 
    "Property manager" means any owner of a covered premises or an agent thereof who is authorized to exercise control over the property, including common areas. The term "property manager" includes any tenant who is an owner of the property or agent of the owner and authorized to exercise control over the property, including common areas. 
    "Tenant" means any authorized occupant of a covered premises, or the agent thereof. 
    "Trespass notice" means a written notice which contains minimally the following information: 
1.  A verbatim copy of Section 9.12.040 infra; 
2.  The name, date of birth, and address of the person to whom the notice is issued and the name of the person's custodial parent or guardian where that person is a juvenile; 
3.  A description of the specific conduct which serves as a basis for the notice's issuance; 
4.  A description of the specific property to which the trespass notice applies; 
5.  The period during which the trespass notice is in effect, including the date of its expiration; 
6.  The name, title and telephone number of a person with authority to modify, amend or rescind the trespass notice prior to its normal expiration; 
7.  The method by which the trespass notice was served upon the person to whom it was issued; 
8.  The written notice attached to this ordinance and incorporated herein by reference shall be deemed to have complied with this section. 
(Prior code § 9.21(2)) 
9.12.030 - When trespass notice may be issued. 
    A property manager, tenant or police officer may issue a trespass notice as provided under this chapter under the following circumstances:
