A.  Where there is probable cause to believe that the person has committed an act prohibited by state statute or city ordinance while on the covered premises, whether on common areas or a tenant's space; or 
B.  Where there is probable cause to believe that the person has violated the rules of conduct for the property which have been conspicuously posted at all public entrances to the property or have been personally provided to the person in writing by the property manager or tenant. 
(Prior code § 9.21(3)) 
9.12.040 - Prohibited conduct. 
A.  No person shall trespass in or upon any private property and, without claim of right, refuse to depart therefrom on demand of the property manager, tenant or police officer. 
B.  No person who has been served with a trespass notice in conformity with this chapter shall enter the premises described therein during its effective period without the written permission of the issuing property manager or tenant or the authorized agent thereof named in the notice. Violation of the terms of the notice is a violation of this chapter. 
C.  No person shall enter any area of private property in violation of conspicuously posted signs prohibiting or restricting access thereto, including but not limited to the following signs: "No Trespassing," "Authorized Personnel Only," "Private," "Employees Only," "Emergency Exit Only." 
(Prior code § 9.21(4)) 
9.12.050 - Additional provisions. 
A.  Where a trespass notice is issued by a tenant, who is not the property manager, the notice is effective only as to that portion of the premises over which the tenant is entitled to exercise control. 
B.  No trespass notice shall be effective for more than one year from the date of its original issuance. 
C.  All trespass notices issued pursuant to this section must be properly served upon the person named therein as follows: 
1.  Personal service documented by either a receipt (trespass notice) signed by the person to whom it was issued, a written statement by the issuer or documentation by a police officer in the official police report or by certified mail to the individual named in the notice; or if the person named in the notice is under age eighteen (18), to the parent, guardian or underage person. 
2.  Where the person named in the trespass notice is arrested by a police officer for an act prohibited by state statute or city ordinance, the arresting officer may personally serve the notice on behalf of the property manager or tenant and so document that fact in the officer's official police report detailing the incident. 
(Prior code § 9.21(5)) 
9.12.060 - Other forms of trespass prohibited. 
    In addition to the regulations encompassed by Sections 9.12.030 and 9.12.040 of this chapter, the following shall constitute trespass: 
A.  No person shall enter into, sleep or take temporary habitation, or remain in any privately owned building without first receiving the express or implied permission of a tenant lawfully renting the premises or the property owner or designee if private property and the property is not currently leased or rented. 
B.  Exceptions. The following acts shall constitute exceptions to the prohibitions of this chapter. 
1.  This section shall not prohibit any person from participating in lawful conduct in labor disputes pursuant to § 103.53, Wis. Stats. 
2.  This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, emergency personnel or other personnel acting in an official capacity or as part of their employment, who enter upon property for purposes attending to performance of their official duties or in the course of emergencies. 
(Ord. 2005-06 § 1) 
Chapter 9.16 - CURFEW 

9.16.010 - Hours of curfew. 
A.  No child under the age of sixteen (16) shall loiter, idle, be upon or remain on any street or other public place, whether on foot or in any means of conveyance being driven or parked, in the city between the hours of eleven p.m. and five a.m., any day except Friday when curfew hours are extended until twelve midnight. Nor shall such a child loiter in, be in or remain in a place of amusement or entertainment during the prohibited hours. 
B.  No person operating a place of amusement or entertainment within the city or any agent, servant or employee of such person shall permit a child under the age of sixteen (16) years to enter or loiter in such place of amusement or entertainment in violation of the curfew hours of this chapter, unless such child is accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other adult person having legal custody of such child. 
C.  It shall be a defense to a violation of subsection A or B of this section that the child is engaged in prohibited conduct while: 
1.  Accompanied by his or her parent, guardian or other person having his or her legal custody; 
2.  Participating in, going to or returning from: 
a.  Gainful employment, 
b.  A school sanctioned activity, 
c.  A religious event, 
d.  An errand or some other function at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian without any detour or stop, 
e.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily harm or substantial damage, 
f.  an activity involving the exercise by the child of his or her rights protected under the 1st Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article I, §§ 3 and 4 of the Wisconsin Constitution, or both, and the right of assembly, 
g.  An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training or other care under the supervision of one or more adults, 
h.  Interstate travel to or from locations outside of the city of River Falls, or 
i.  An exception granted by resolution of the common council for a specific event or activity. 
3.  On property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by his or her parent, guardian or legal custodian; 
4.  On property owned, leased or otherwise controlled by persons other than the child's parent, guardian or legal custodian, with the permission of his or her parent, guardian or legal custodian, but not including public places or places of amusement or entertainment. 
C.  With respect to activities involving the exercise by a child of his or her rights protected under the 1st Amendment to the United States Constitution or Article I, §§ 3 and 4 of the Wisconsin Constitution at the time he or she is confronted with an alleged violation of this chapter, as is commanded undersubsection (B)(2)(e) of this section, such a child shall not be taken into custody or charged with a violation of this chapter. Additionally, however, under circumstances in which a reasonable law enforcement officer charged with enforcing this chapter should develop a perception that a child confronted with an alleged violation of this chapter had been engaged in an exercise of those protected rights prior to, being confronted or intended thereafter to engage in an exercise of those protected rights, before such child may be taken into custody or charged with a violation of this chapter, the law enforcement officer shall perform an investigation to determine whether or not that child had been engaged in prior to being confronted or was enroute at that time to engage in an exercise of 1st Amendment rights under the United States Constitution or an exercise of rights under Article I, §§ 3 and 4 of the Wisconsin Constitution. 
(Ord. 2005-07 § 1 (part)) 
9.16.015 - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall be applied: 
    "Emergency" means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster or automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    "Legal custodian" shall have the meaning set forth at §48.02(11), Wis. Stats. 
    "Loiter" means to congregate idly with others, linger, wander, stand, delay, walk or stroll about aimlessly, or to remain idle in essentially one location in a manner and under circumstances manifesting an unnecessary or aimless purpose. 
    "Place of amusement or entertainment" shall include but not be limited to arcades, pool parlors, video game parlors, bowling alleys, fairs or youth centers. 
    "Public place" shall include but not be limited to any park, school, school ground, vacant lot, parking lot, sidewalk, pedestrian bridge or other property generally open to the public, owned, operated or maintained by the city, a county, a school district or other governmental entity, both with respect to buildings and open spaces. 
    "Street" shall include any public way, thoroughfare or bridges upon the same, whether operated and maintained by the city or another governmental entity. 
(Ord. 2005-07 § 1 (part)) 
9.16.020 - Parental violation. 
    No parent, guardian or other legal custodian of a child under the age of sixteen (16) years shall permit such child to engage in acts prohibited under Section 9.16.010 of this chapter, subject only to the defenses set forth thereunder. 
(Ord. 2005-07 § 1 (part)) 
9.16.030 - General penalty. 
A.  Any parent, guardian, legal custodian or person who operates a place of amusement or entertainment and who violates Section 9.16.010(B) or Section 9.16.020 shall be subject to the penalty prescribed at Ch. 1.20 of this code. 
B.  Any child who violates this chapter shall, after being detained and released, be dealt with under Chapters. 48 and 938, Wis. Stats., as the circumstances dictate. 
(Ord. 2005-07 § 1 (part)) 
Chapter 9.20 - WEAPONS 
Sections: 

9.20.010 - Discharge of firearms. 
    No person shall discharge any firearm within the city, except law enforcement officers or other agents or employees of the city as authorized by the chief of police. The council may authorize additional exceptions by resolution for organized gun clubs to engage in target practice; and for special events, e.g. parades, funerals and American Legion activities on public property, provided no projectiles are associated with the discharge. 
(Ord. 2000-16: prior code § 9.02) 
9.20.020 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-01 , § 1, adopted January 23, 2018, repealed § 9.20.020, which pertained to airguns and slingshots and derived from prior code § 9.03 and Ord. No. 2009-6, adopted June 23, 2009. 
9.20.030 - Carrying concealed knives prohibited. 
    No person shall carry or wear concealed about his or her person any bowie knife, dirk knife, dagger or other device commonly known as a surth knife, spring blade knife or push button knife. 
(Prior code § 9.04) 
Chapter 9.23 - TRUANCY 
Sections: 

9.23.010 - Statutory authority. 
    This chapter regulating truancy in the city of River Falls is adopted pursuant to the authority of W.S.A. Section 118.163. 
(Ord. 2002-20 (part)) 
9.23.020 - Definitions. 
    The following terms shall have the following meanings when used in this chapter: 
    "Habitual truant" means a pupil who is absent from school without an acceptable excuse under W.S.A. Sections 118.15 and 118.16(4) for part or all of five days or more on which school is held during a school semester. 
    "Truant" means a pupil who is absent from school without an acceptable excuse under W.S.A. Sections 118.15 and 118.16(4) for part or all of any day on which school is held during a school semester. 
(Ord. 2002-20 (part)) 
9.23.030 - Prohibitions-Dispositions-Truants. 
    No person shall be a truant. Any truant seventeen (17) years of age or younger shall be subject to the following dispositions. The court may impose either or both dispositions. 
A.  An order for the person to attend school. 
B.  A forfeiture of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) plus costs for a first violation or a forfeiture of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) plus costs for any second or subsequent violation committed within twelve (12) months of a previous violation, subject to Section 938.37, Wis. Stats. and subject to a maximum cumulative forfeiture amount of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for all violations committed during a school semester. All or part of the forfeiture plus costs may be assessed against the person, the parents or guardian of the person, or both. 
(Ord. 2002-20 (part)) 
9.23.040 - Prohibition-Dispositions-Habitual truants. 
    No person shall be a habitual truant. Any habitual truant seventeen (17) years of age or younger shall be subject to the following dispositions. The court may impose any or all dispositions. 
A.  Suspension of the person's operating privileges for a period of not less than thirty (30) days nor more than one year. The court shall immediately take possession of any suspended license and shall forward it to the department of transportation, together with a notice stating the reason for and the duration of the suspension. 
B.  An order for the person to participate in counseling or a supervised work program or other community service work, as described in Section 938.54(5)(g), Wis. Stats. The court may also order the person's parent, guardian or legal custodian to participate in counseling at the parent's, guardian's or legal custodian's own expense or to attend school with the person, or both. 
C.  An order for the person to remain at home except during hours in which the person is attending religious worship or a school program, including travel time required to get to and from the school program or place of worship. The order may permit a person to leave his or her home if the person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
D.  An order for the person to attend an educational program under Section 938.34(7)(d), Wis. Stats. 
E.  A forfeiture of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus costs, subject to Section 938.67. All or part of the forfeiture plus costs may be assessed against the person, the parents or guardian of the person, or both. 
F.  An order for the person to attend school. 
G.  An order to revoke a work permit. Section 118.163(2)(e), Wis. Stats. 
H.  An order to be placed in a teen court program. Section 118.162(2)(f), Wis. Stats. 
I.  An order placing the person under formal or informal supervision for up to one year. Section 118.163(2)(j), Wis. Stats. 
J.  Any other reasonable conditions consistent with Section 118.163(2), Wis. Stats., including a curfew, restrictions as to going to or remaining on specified premises and restrictions on associating with other children or adults. 
(Ord. 2002-20 (part)) 
9.23.050 - Contributing to truancy. 
A.  Except as provided in subsection B of this section, no person seventeen (17) years of age or older shall, by act or omission, knowingly encourage or contribute to the truancy of a person subject to school attendance laws. 
B.  Subsection A of this section does not apply to a person who has under his or her control a child who has been sanctioned under Wis. Stat. Section 49.26(1)(h). 
C.  An act or omission contributes to a truancy of a child whether or not the child is adjudged to be in need of protection or services, if the natural and probable consequences of that act or omission would be to cause the child to be truant. 
(Ord. 2002-20 (part)) 
Chapter 9.24 - MISCELLANEOUS OFFENSES 
Sections: 

9.24.010 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-01 , § 2, adopted January 23, 2018, repealed § 9.24.010, which pertained to traps and derived from prior code § 9.05. 
9.24.020 - Sale and discharge of fireworks restricted. 
A.  Subject to subsection B of this section, Sec. 167.10, Wis. Stats., regulating the sale and use of fireworks exclusive of any penalty imposed thereby, is adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter as though set forth in full. 
B.  In accord with Sec. 167.10(5)(b), Wis. Stats., which authorizes cities to adopt regulations of fireworks which are more restrictive than is the statute, the city declares that it is illegal for any person, acting as a wholesaler, to possess and sell at wholesale, any fireworks within the city limits. For the purposes of this subsection, "wholesaler" means any person who is engaged in the sale of goods or commodities in quantity for resale. As defined, the term "wholesaler" includes any person who sells fireworks to persons outside of this state. 
(Ord. 2004-08 § 1: prior code § 9.06) 
9.24.030 - Abandoned or unattended refrigerators prohibited. 
    No person shall leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or other structure under his or her control in a place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded ice box, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, unless such door or lid, snap lock or other locking device has been removed from such ice box, refrigerator or container or unless such container is displayed for sale on the premises of the owner or his or her agent and is securely locked or fastened. 
(Prior code § 9.12) 
9.24.040 - Possession and consumption of liquor and beer restricted. 
A.  Possession Outside Taverns or Picnic Areas Prohibited. No person shall consume, possess or carry about an open container of intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage outside a licensed tavern or off the premises of an established picnic area where such possession and consumption is not prohibited. 
B.  Intoxicants in Vehicles. No person shall consume, possess or have under his or her control any open container of intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverage while in a vehicle, whether parked or moving, on any public thoroughfare or public parking lot. 
C.  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to any person on private property with the permission of the owner or occupant of the property. The city council by resolution may authorize an exception to the section. Such exception shall be specific as to occasion, location and length of time. 
(Prior code § 9.17) 
9.24.050 - Fighting events prohibited. 
    No person shall sponsor, sanction, condone, or permit to be held or carried out on any real estate under his or her ownership or control any mixed martial arts fighting event or any amateur wrestling or amateur boxing events except for those amateur wrestling events sanctioned by USA Wrestling or amateur boxing events sanctioned by USA Boxing. This limitation on the holding of fighting events shall apply whether or not admission is charged to the public for attendance at the same. This section shall not apply to curricular or extra-curricular athletic events held or sponsored by secondary schools or universities. 
(Ord. 2007-25 § 1) 
(Ord. No. 2010-19, § 1, 12-14-2010) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - TRAFFIC CONTROL REGULATIONS ADOPTED 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - State traffic laws adopted. 
A.  The city hereby adopts all relevant provisions of Chs. 340 through 349 of the Wis. Stats. that pertain to traffic, motor vehicle and such provisions, where not a criminal offense, are so adopted and made a part of this section by reference. 
B.  Any amendments, creations or supplementation of Chs. 340 through 350 of the Wisconsin Statutes shall serve to so modify and amend this section. 
(Ord. 2001-11 § 28; Ord. 1998-11; prior code § 7.01) 
10.04.020 - Motor vehicles on public and private property. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  "Motor vehicle" means any vehicle which is self-propelled. 
2.  "Public property" includes all lands owned by the city or by any other public agency within the city limits including schools, parks, playgrounds and golf courses. 
3.  "Private property" includes all land within the city limits not publicly owned. 
B.  Prohibited Operation. 
1.  Public Property. No person shall use, operate or park any motor vehicle or device towable by a motor vehicle on public property in the city except: 
a.  Upon streets, highways, alleys, parking lots or trails designated as such for the purpose of vehicular travel or parking; or 
b.  Upon any land designated by the city for vehicular use for special events or programs as recommended by the park and recreation board. 
2.  Private Property. No person shall operate any motor vehicle on private property within the city without the express or implied consent of the owner or occupant of such property. 
C.  Vehicles to be Towed Away. The city may tow away by its employees or any other person any motor vehicle or device towable by a motor vehicle found upon public property in violation of this section. Any such vehicle or device shall be impounded and the procedures herein set forth shall be employed. 
D.  Procedure for Impoundment. 
1.  Notification to Owner. Upon the impounding of any motor vehicle or device towable by a motor vehicle hereunder, the chief of police shall immediately make reasonable effort to ascertain the name and address of the person owning such vehicle or device and advise the owner by letter that such vehicle or device has been impounded. Such letter shall: 
a.  Give the general description of the vehicle or device and the license number thereon, if any; 
b.  Give the approximate time of the removal and reason therefor and the place where such vehicle or device is stored; 
c.  State the towing charge and the daily storage charge and advise the owner that such charges must be paid prior to the release of the vehicle or device; 
d.  Advise the owner that such vehicle or device shall not be released to him or her without reasonably satisfactory evidence that he or she is in fact the owner of such vehicle or device. 
2.  Deposit of Funds. Any employee receiving any money for the release of an impounded vehicle or device shall deliver such money to the city treasurer within twenty-four (24) hours of receipt thereof together with a statement identifying the released vehicle and the amount of money collected. 
(Prior code § 7.09) 
10.04.030 - Use of flashing red lights by school buses. 
A.  School bus operators shall use flashing red lights in residential or business districts when pupils or other authorized passengers are to be loaded or unloaded. 
B.  School bus operators shall be allowed to load and unload pupils or other authorized passengers in residential or business districts only at locations at which there are no traffic signals and only where a sidewalk or curb are laid on both sides of the road. 
(Prior code § 7.13) 
10.04.040 - Engine braking prohibited. 
    No operator of any vehicle or truck shall employ the use of an engine braking system which utilizes engine exhaust to slow the vehicle, commonly referred to as compression braking, engine braking or "jake" braking, except in the case of an emergency. Emergency service vehicles are exempt from this provision. Violations shall be enforced by means of the city citation procedure under Chapter 1.16 of this code and the deposit for such violation which is approved of separately by the common council. 
(Ord. 2005-23 § 1) 
10.04.050 - Prohibiting riding in the cargo bed of pick-up trucks. 
A.  No driver of a motor truck with a cargo area shall permit a passenger to ride in the cargo area of a motor truck while the vehicle is in motion unless in a seated position within the cargo area. Specifically prohibited are persons who are standing, seated on the bed rail, or seated on the open or closed tailgate of such a truck. 
B.  This section shall not apply to low speed travel while participating in a parade sanctioned by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 2, 5-10-2011) 
Chapter 10.08 - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

10.08.010 - Official traffic control map. 
A.  The official traffic control map shall be as represented on the document titled "Official Traffic Control Map - May 15, 2003." The original version will be kept in the engineering department. Hard copies of the official traffic control map will be made available in the police department and municipal court. 
    To the extent that this section is at variance from or conflicts with prior ordinances pertaining to the subject matter of this section, this section shall control and previous ordinances in conflict herewith shall be deemed to be amended or, when appropriate, repealed by this section. 
B.  Erection of Signs and Changes. The street superintendent shall cause to be erected such traffic control signs and marking changes as are necessary to give adequate notice of the restrictions, prohibitions and limitations as shown on the official traffic control map. 
C.  Violation Prohibited. A violation of any properly noticed restriction, prohibition or limitation shown on the official traffic control map shall be a violation of the provisions of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 2003-16 § 1; prior code § 7.07(2)) 
10.08.020 - Official signs and markers. 
A.  Chief of Police Responsible. The chief of police shall procure, erect and maintain appropriate standard parking and traffic signs, signals and markings conforming to the rules of the State Department of Transportation, giving notice of the provisions of this title as required by state law. Signs shall be erected in such locations and in such manner as the chief determines shall best effect the purposes of this title to give adequate warning to users of the streets and highways and parking areas. 
B.  Prohibited Signs and Markers in Highways. No person other than the chief of police or his or her designee shall place within the limits of any street or highway maintained by the city any sign, signal, marker, mark or monument unless permission is first obtained from either the, chief of police or Wisconsin State Department of Transportation. Any sign, signal, marker, mark or monument placed or maintained in violation of this subsection shall be subject to removal as provided in subsection C of this section. 
C.  Removal of Unofficial Signs, Markers, Signals and Traffic Control Devices. The chief of police shall have the authority granted by Section 349.09, Wis. Stats., to remove any sign, signal, marking or other device which is placed, maintained or displayed in violation of this title or state law. Cost for removal of a prohibited or illegal sign, signal, marking or device shall be reported for review and certification to the city council. It shall be charged against the premises from which removed. Any charge not paid on or before the next succeeding November 15th shall be placed, upon the tax roll for collection as other special municipal taxes. 
D.  The chief or police or his her designee has the authority to erect and establish temporary traffic control restrictions, prohibitions or limitations in accordance with this section for the purpose of highway maintenance/construction, snow removal, efficient facilitation of pedestrian and vehicular traffic, or in the interest of public safety. These restrictions, prohibitions or limitations are in effect and enforceable for a period up to sixty (60) days without official council action. 
(Ord. 2002-13 § 1; prior code § 7.08) 
10.08.030 - Appointment of volunteer adult school crossing guards. 
A.  The police department shall be empowered to appoint from time to time volunteer adult school crossing guards for the protection of persons who are crossing a highway in the vicinity of a school. The tenure of the volunteer adult school crossing guards and other terms and conditions of employment shall be set by the police department at the time of such appointment. 
B.  All volunteer adult school crossing guards who are appointed pursuant to this section shall wear insignia or uniform which designate them as school crossing guards and shall be equipped with signals or signs to direct traffic to a stop at school crossings. 
(Prior code § 7.11) 
10.08.040 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The penalty for violation of any provision of this title shall be a forfeiture and penalty assessment, if required by Section 165.87, Wis. Stats., a jail assessment, if required by Section 302.46(1), Wis. Stats., plus any applicable fees prescribed in Ch. 814, Wis. Stats. 
A.  State Forfeiture Statutes. Any forfeiture for violation of Chs. 340 through 350 of the Wisconsin Statutes adopted by reference in Section 10.04.010 shall conform to the forfeiture permitted to be imposed for violation of such statutes, including any variations or increases for subsequent offenses. 
B.  Local Regulations. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, the penalty for violation of Sections 10.04.020, 10.08.010, 10.08.020, 10.12.010 through 10.12.030, 10.16.010 through 10.16.030 and Chapter 10.24 shall be as provided in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. 
C.  Citations shall be subject to a schedule of deposits which shall be revised by the municipal court judge from time to time and, as revised, approved of by the common council by motion or resolution. 
D.  Lien and Disposal for Towed Vehicles. 
1.  Whenever a motor vehicle is ordered to be towed by a police officer of the city in the enforcement of the provisions of the federal, state or this municipal code or in the exercise of the police power in furtherance of the public safety, health or welfare, the city shall have a lien on the vehicle for all reasonable towing charges incurred by the police department in ordering the tow. 
2.  The vehicle that has been ordered towed, unless otherwise needed for evidentiary purposes, shall be released to the owner or their designee, upon the payment to the police department of the towing fee. 
3.  Any vehicles that are not claimed by the owner shall be disposed of in accordance with Chapter 8.08 of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 2000-11 §§ 17 (part), 18; prior code § 7.15) 
10.08.050 - Enforcement. 
A.  Enforcement Procedure. This title shall be enforced according to Sections 23.33, 66.0114, 345.11 to 345.61, 350.17 and Ch. 800, Wis. Stats. 
B.  Deposit. 
1.  Any person arrested for a violation of this title may make a deposit of money as directed by the arresting officer at the police station or at the office of the clerk of court or by mailing the deposit to such places. The arresting officer or the person receiving the deposit shall notify the arrested person, orally or in writing, that: 
a.  If the person makes a deposit for a violation of a traffic regulation, the person need not appear in court at the time fixed in the citation and the person will be deemed to have tendered plea of no contest and submitted to a forfeiture and penalty assessment if required by Section 165.87, Wis. Stats., a jail assessment if required by Section 302.46(1), Wis. Stats., plus any applicable fees prescribed in Ch. 814, Wis. Stats., not to exceed the amount of the deposit that the court may accept as provided in Section 345.37, Wis. Stats.; 
b.  If the person fails to make a deposit for a violation of traffic regulation or appear in court at the time fixed in the citation, the court may enter a default judgment finding the person guilty of the offense or issue a warrant for his or her arrest. 
2.  The amount of the deposit shall be determined in accordance with the deposit schedule established by the Wisconsin Judicial Conference and shall include the penalty assessment established under Section 165.87, Wis. Stats., a jail assessment if required by Section 302.46(1), Wis. Stats., and court costs. If a deposit schedule has not been established, the arresting officer shall require the alleged offender to deposit the forfeiture established by the chief of police, which shall include the penalty assessment established under Section 165.87, Wis. Stats. Deposits for nonmoving violations shall not include the penalty assessment. 
3.  The arresting officer or the person receiving the deposit shall issue the arrested person a receipt therefor as required by Section 345.26(3)(b), Wis. Stats. 
C.  Petition to Reopen Judgment. Whenever a person has been convicted in this state on the basis of a forfeiture of deposit or a plea of guilty or no contest and the person was not informed as required under Section 345.27(1) and (2), Wis. Stats., the person may, within sixty (60) days after being notified of the revocation or suspension of the operating privilege, petition the court to reopen the judgment and grant him an opportunity to defend on merits. If the court finds that the petitioner was not informed as required under Section 345.27(1) and (2), the court shall order the judgment reopened. The court order reopening the judgment automatically reinstates the revoked or suspended operating privilege. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 2001-11 § 17 (part); prior code § 7.16) 
Chapter 10.12 - PARKING GENERALLY 
Sections: 

10.12.010 - Reserved parking. 
A.  Reserved Parking. The parking premises adjacent to the north side of the City Hall is designated as a reserved parking area for the city officers and employees. No person shall park a vehicle within the designated parking stalls except as authorized by the city. 
B.  Marking. The street department shall have such stalls appropriately marked and maintained. 
(Prior code § 7.05) 
10.12.020 - Overnight parking. 
A.  Odd-even Parking. 
1.  There shall be odd-even parking on all city streets from November 1st to March 31st of each year between the hours of one a.m. and six a.m., unless other "no parking" regulations are in effect. Streets that are subject to a ban on parking during specific times and/or days shall remain subject to this odd-even regulation when the more specific parking prohibition is not in effect. 
2.  "Odd-even parking" means vehicles will be parked on the odd side of a street designated by property addresses on odd days of the month and on the even side of the street on even days of the month. 
B.  Snow Emergency Requirements. 
1.  A snow emergency shall be in effect when declared, upon public notice, by the superintendent of public works and will remain in effect until cancelled. 
2.  When a snow emergency is in effect, a vehicle may be towed when it is in violation of the parking regulations prohibiting parking any time between the hours of one a.m. and six a.m. 
3.  Signs and Warning Markers. The superintendent of public works shall erect such signs and warning markers necessary to give notice of the restrictions, prohibitions and limitations of this subsection and as are shown on the official parking control map. 
(Ord. 2001-4; Ord. 1997-11(part); prior code § 7.06) 
10.12.030 - Official parking control maps. 
A.  The official parking control map shall be as represented on the document titled "Official Parking Control Map - May 30, 2003." The original version will be kept in the engineering department. Hard copies of the official parking control map will be made available in the police department and municipal court. 
    To the extent that this section is at variance from or conflicts with prior ordinances pertaining to the subject matter of this section, this section shall control and previous ordinances in conflict herewith shall be deemed to be amended or, when appropriate, repealed by this section. 
B.  Erection of Signs and Changes. The street superintendent shall cause to be erected such parking signs and marking changes as are necessary to give adequate notice of the restrictions, prohibitions and limitations as shown on the official parking control map. 
C.  Violation Prohibited. A violation of any properly noticed restriction, prohibition or limitation shown on the official parking control map shall be a violation of the provisions of this municipal code. 
D.  Towing of Parked Vehicles. Any vehicle parked in violation of statutory provisions or contrary to the restrictions, prohibitions and limitations of this section and the Municipal Code, generally, may be towed. Additionally, vehicles may be towed as deemed to be necessary for snow removal, highway maintenance/construction or in the interest of public safety including, but not limited to, situations in which the parked vehicle is blocking traffic or otherwise creating an emergency. The police department shall facilitate towing under this section. 
2.  Beyond the circumstances described under subsection (E)(1) of this section, as justifying the towing of vehicles, a parked vehicle may be ordered 
to be towed by the police department if its owner has received at least three parking or moving vehicle violations in the city which, as of the date in question, remain unpaid and uncontested. Upon the issuance of the third violation, a notice shall be mailed to the owner's last known address, advising the owner that if he or she fails to pay the outstanding forfeitures within ten (10) days, in the event that another violation occurs, his or her vehicle shall be subject to being towed under this subsection, if found parked at any location in the city. In the event that a vehicle is towed under this paragraph, the following procedure shall be applied: 
a.  Immediate notice of the fact of a towing shall be mailed to the vehicle owner's last known address, together with a copy of the citation for violation of this section. The notice shall inform the owner of the following rights: (1) The right to an immediate hearing, to be held within two business days of his or her receipt of the notice to determine the validity of the tow. The hearing shall be held by the municipal court clerk. The sole issue at the hearing shall be whether or not the owner has three outstanding violations. (2) Upon payment of security in the form of a bond, the amount of which shall be established under authority granted hereby to the chief of police and which shall be equivalent to the total amount of the unpaid forfeitures outstanding against the motor vehicle in question and towing charges listed in the citation, the right to re-obtain possession of the vehicle. (3) Pursuant to the citation, the right to defend the citation in the manner prescribed by Wisconsin law and the municipal ordinances. 
E.  The chief of police or his or her designee has the authority to erect and establish temporary parking restrictions, prohibitions or limitations in accordance with Section 10.08.020 of this code for the purpose of highway maintenance/construction, snow removal, efficient facilitation of pedestrian and vehicular traffic, or in the interest of public safety. 
    These restrictions, prohibitions or limitations are in effect and enforceable for a period up to sixty (60) days without official council action. 
(Ord. 2005-09 § 1; Ord. 2003-15 §§ 1, 4; Ord. 2003-01 § 1; Ord. 1997-11 (part): prior code § 7.07(1)) 
10.12.040 - Temporary handicapped parking permits. 
A.  Permit to be Issued. The chief of police or his or her authorized officer shall issue to an applicant a temporary handicapped parking permit to any individual who is temporarily physically disabled by any physical condition which renders the person unable to walk or unable to walk without great difficulty. 
B.  Application. Any person applying for a temporary handicapped parking permit shall submit to the chief of police or his or her authorized officer an application consisting of: 
1.  Applicant's name; 
2.  Applicant's address; 
3.  A statement of a licensed physician stating: 
a.  A description of the disability, including a statement that the applicant is unable to walk or is unable to walk without great difficulty, 
b.  The duration of the temporary disability, 
c.  The physician's name, address and signature, 
d.  The date of the physician's statement. 
C.  Contents of Parking Card. Upon compliance with subsection B of this section, the chief of police or his authorized officer shall issue a temporary handicapped parking card on an eight inch by two and three quarter inch paper, stating: 
1.  The name and address of applicant; 
2.  Card number; 
3.  The date of issue and the date of expiration; 
4.  An indication that the card is an original; 
5.  The words "Physically Disabled Parking Privileges" at the top of the card. 
D.  Display and Effect. The card shall be prominently displayed on the left sun visor, left dashboard or the left front windshield of the vehicle. The effect of the card shall allow the temporarily handicapped person to park in all designated handicapped parking stalls in the city during its period of validity. 
E.  Fee. There shall be no fee. 
(Prior code § 12.18) 
Chapter 10.24 - SNOWMOBILES 
Sections: 

10.24.010 - State snowmobile laws adopted. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided in this title, the statutory provisions describing and defining regulations with respect to snowmobiles in the following enumerated sections of the Wisconsin Statutes are hereby adopted by reference and made part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. Acts required to be performed or prohibited by such statutes are required or prohibited by this chapter. 
350.01 Definitions 350.02 Operation of Snowmobiles on or in Vicinity of Highway 350.03 Right-of-Way 350.04 Snowmobile Races, Derbies and Routes 350.045 Public Utility Exemption 350.047 Local Ordinance to be Filed 350.05 Operation by Youthful Operators Restricted 350.055 Safety Certification Program Established 350.06 Firearms and Bows 350.07 Driving Animals 350.08 Owner Permitting Operation 350.09 Head Lamps, Tail Lamps and Brakes 350.10 Miscellaneous Provisions for Snowmobile Operation 350.12 Registration of Snowmobiles 350.13 Uniform Trail Signs and Standards 350.15 Accidents and Accident Reports 350.17 Enforcement 350.18 Local Ordinances 350.19 Liability of Land Owners  
  
(Prior code § 7.10(1)) 
10.24.020 - Applicability of rules of the road to snowmobiles. 
    The operator of a snowmobile upon a roadway shall, in addition to the provisions of Ch. 350, be subject to Sections 346.04, 346.06, 346.11, 346.14(1), 346.18, 346.19, 346.20, 346.21, 346.26, 346.27, 346.33, 346.35, 346.37, 346.39, 346.40, 346.44, 346.46, 346.47, 346.48, 346.50(l)(b), 346.51, 346.52, 346.53, 346.54, 346.55, 346.87, 346.88, 346.89, 346.90, 346.91, 346.92(1) and 346.94(1), (6), (6m) and (9), Wis. Stats. 
(Prior code § 7.10(2)) 
10.24.030 - Permitting operation by improper persons prohibited. 
    No owner or person having charge or control of a snowmobile shall authorize or permit any person to operate such snowmobile who is not permitted under state law to operate such snowmobile or who is under the influence of an intoxicant or a dangerous or narcotic drug. 
(Prior code § 7.10(3)) 
10.24.040 - Operation while under influence prohibited. 
    Section 350.101, Wis. Stats., shall apply to the operation of a snowmobile anywhere within the city. 
(Prior code § 7.10(4)) 
10.24.050 - Written consent of owner required. 
    The consent required under Sections 350.10(1)(f), (1)(k),(1)(L) and (1)(m), Wis. Stats., shall be written consent dated and limited to the year in which the consent is given. If the property is owned or leased by more than one person, the consent of each shall be obtained. 
(Ord. 2001-11 § 19: prior code § 7.10(5)) 
10.24.060 - Snowmobile routes and trails designated. 
    Except as provided in Sections 350.02 and 350.045, Wis. Stats., or for snowmobile events authorized in accordance with Section 350.04, Wis. Stats., no person shall operate a snowmobile upon any public right-of-way or on any other public property in the city, except upon designated snowmobile routes and trails. 
A.  Routes. Every snowmobiler authorized by state law to cross streets or highways may use only those streets in the city which are designated snowmobile routes and are signed with the appropriate snowmobile route signs. The city hereby designates official snowmobile routes as follows: 
Street Name From To St. Croix Street Summit Street CTH MM St. Croix Street West Pomeroy Street West Quarry Road West Summit Street St. Croix Street North Main Street Summit Street North Main Street Troy Street Troy Street Summit Street Benson Street Benson Street Troy Street Quarry Road Quarry Road Corporate Limits North Main Street West Quarry Road North Main Street St. Croix Street CTH MM Corporate Limits St. Croix Street Winter Street Locust Street CTH MM Roosevelt Street Clark Street Winter Street Johnson Street Main Street Orange Street Orange Street Johnson Street Kennedy Street Kennedy Street Orange Street Sixth Street South  
B.  Speed. No person shall operate a snowmobile upon any public highway, official snowmobile trail or other property permitting snowmobiling within the city at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 1997-1, § 1; Prior code § 7.10(6)) 
(Ord. 2009-14, § 1, 11-10-09) 
10.24.070 - Additional regulations. 
A.  Unattended Snowmobiles. No person shall allow his or her snowmobile to remain unattended on any public highway or public property while the motor is running or the starting key is in the ignition. 
B.  Operation on Sidewalks and Paved Trails. No person shall operate a snowmobile on any sidewalk, paved trail, pedestrian way, or upon the area outside of the curb lines of a street within the city unless for the purpose of crossing to obtain immediate access to an authorized area of operation. 
C.  Operation on Icebound Waters. No person shall operate or ride upon a snowmobile on Lake George, Lake Louise or the Kinnickinnic River within the city at any time or place. 
D.  Operation Near Hospitals. No person shall operate a snowmobile within three hundred (300) feet of hospitals and nursing homes. 
E.  Operation in Park or Other City Property. No person shall operate a snowmobile within any park or other land owned by the City of River Falls. 
(Prior code § 7.10(7)) 
(Ord. 2009-14, § 2, 11-10-09) 
10.24.080 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-10 , § 1, adopted August 28, 2018, repealed § 10.24.080, which pertained to snowmobile renters licensed and derived from prior code § 7.10(8). 
Chapter 10.26 - NEIGHBORHOOD ELECTRIC VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.26.005 - Definitions. 
    "Neighborhood electric vehicle (NEV)" means a self-propelled electric motor vehicle meeting the definition of Section 340.01(36r), Wis. Stats., which is registered and licensed by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. A slow-moving vehicle sign is not required. 
(Ord. 2008-23 § 1 (part): Ord. 2008-11 § 1 (part)) 
10.26.010 - Use of NEV. 
    A person may operate an NEV on any roadway within the municipal boundaries of the city of River Falls that has a speed limit of thirty-five (35) miles per hour or less, subject to the following restrictions: 
A.  The person operating the NEV must hold a valid Wisconsin operator's license or a valid operator's license from another state. 
B.  The person operating the NEV must obey all state and local traffic regulations not inconsistent with this chapter. 
C.  Operation of NEVs shall be prohibited on or across the following streets: 
1.  South Main Street (STH 29/35), south of East Johnson Street, except that crossings shall be permitted at Cemetery Road; 
2.  North Main Street, north of Paulson Road. 
D.  The city shall create and the city clerk shall at all times maintain a map highlighting those roadways within the city limits on which NEV use is permitted. 
(Ord. 2008-23 § 1 (part): Ord. 2008-11 § 1 (part)) 
10.26.020 - Enforcement. 
    Use of an NEV within the city limits, which is contrary to or not in compliance with this chapter, shall be subject to the assessment of a forfeiture for each violation, plus court costs as outlined in the approved municipal court bond schedule. In addition, the operation of an NEV within the city limits, in a manner contrary to city ordinance or state law regulating the use of streets or highways by motor vehicles, shall be subject to such sanctions as are provided thereunder. 
(Ord. 2008-23 § 1 (part): Ord. 2008-11 § 1 (part)) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS, OTHER PUBLIC PLACES AND PROPERTY USE IMPACTS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Standards and specifications. 
A.  Establishment. The city engineer may from time to time establish standards and specifications for work to be done on or over the public right-of-way. The grades of all streets, alleys and sidewalks shall be established and described by the city engineer and recorded in his or her office. The council may grant variances from the standard by a majority vote of the whole council, subject to concurrence by the city engineer that the variance would not negatively affect the public welfare or the safeguarding of life, health, or property and does not run contrary to any code or specification published by the state of Wisconsin. 
B.  Required. No street, alley or sidewalk shall be worked until the grade thereof is established. 
C.  Altering Prohibited. No person shall alter the grade of any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground on any part thereof, unless authorized or instructed to do so by the city engineer. 
(Ord. 2000-3: Ord. 1997-16: prior code § 8.01) 
12.04.020 - Safety standards for sidewalk openings. 
A.  All service openings in sidewalks when not in use by the person for whose benefit the same have been installed or maintained shall be protected by a cover so as to allow pedestrian traffic to safely walk on and over it. Such protective cover shall be level with the sidewalk, of nonslippery smooth surface and shall be so fastened as not to expose the opening without an intentional effort being made to do so. 
B.  The service openings in sidewalks, when exposed, shall have protective devices designed and adequate to prevent pedestrian traffic from falling into or tripping over such openings. Such protective devices shall not interfere with normal pedestrian traffic along such sidewalk except across such opening and shall be so designed as to be clearly visible and to restrict, but not be a hazard, to pedestrian traffic over or across such openings. 
C.  The owner and occupant of the premises designed to be served by such sidewalk openings shall be jointly responsible for complying with the provisions of subsections A and B of this section. 
D.  No person shall serve any premises through such sidewalk openings unless the provisions of subsection B of this section are complied with at the time of such service. 
(Prior code § 8.03) 
12.04.030 - Snow and ice removal. 
A.  Sidewalks to be Kept Clear. The owner or occupant of any lot or parcel shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of cessation of each continuous period of snowfall, remove all snow and ice which may have fallen or accumulated upon the sidewalk in front of such lot or parcel, provided when ice or packed snow has so formed that it cannot be removed, the owner or occupant shall keep the same sprinkled with a nonskid material which will prevent the sidewalk from being dangerous to pedestrians. This requirement shall also apply to the main sidewalk as it extends from a corner lot to the curbline of an intersecting street. 
B.  Deposits of Snow Restricted. Excepting the clearing of snow from sidewalks or entries located upon a public right-of-way, no person shall cause snow to be deposited on boulevards, sidewalks, streets or avenues or any other city owned property without permission therefore from the city. Payment of a fee sufficient to reimburse the city for the cost of removing any snow so deposited without permission may be required. 
C.  Depositing of Snow on Private Property. All snow from private property (driveways or parking lots) shall be either deposited on the originating owner's property or hauled away by the owner on their agent. Property owners shall not place their snow on other property without permission from the owner of the other property. 
D.  Abatement. 
1.  If the provisions of this chapter are not complied with, the city or designee shall serve written notice once per calendar year upon the owner, lessee or occupant, or any person having care or control of any such lot or land to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
2.  If the person upon whom the notice is served fails, neglects or refuses to shovel within twenty-four (24) hours of date of such notice, or if no person can be found in the city who either is or claims to be the owner of such lot or land or who represents or claims to represent such owner, the city shall cause such snow to be removed. 
3.  The cost of such removal, and other costs associated with it, at the discretion of the city, shall be billed to the property owner and payable to the city within thirty (30) days. Costs shall be invoiced per the city's current fee schedule. 
4.  Failure to pay the city for the services billed will result in the costs being assessed against the property as a special charge per Section 13.32.010. 
(Prior code § 8.04) 
(Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 3-9-2010; Ord. No. 2018-08 , §§ 1, 2, 6-26-2018) 
12.04.040 - Official map. 
A.  Intent. It is the intent of the common council to establish an official map for the purpose of conserving and promoting the public health, safety, convenience, economy, orderliness and general welfare of the community; to further the orderly layout in the use of land; to stabilize the location of real property boundary lines, to insure proper legal description and proper monumenting of land; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, parks, playgrounds and stormwater drainage; and to facilitate the further subdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. 
B.  Authority. The ordinance codified in this chapter is enacted under the authority granted by Section 62.23(6), Wis. Stats. 
C.  Definitions. The following definitions shall control the interpretation and application of this section. 
1.  "Boundaries" means the corporate limits of the city. 
2.  "City" means the city of River Falls. 
3.  "Parkway" means and includes any right-of-way for vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or both, with full or partial control of access and usually located within a park or a ribbon of park-like development. Such parkway may include land area which is required for stormwater drainage purposes where the drainage improvement is to include park-like treatment and where pedestrian vehicular travel may be permitted. 
4.  "Subdivision plat" means and includes certified survey maps. 
5.  "Waterway" means and includes rivers, streams, creeks, ditches, drainage channels, watercourses, lakes, bays, ponds, impoundment reservoirs, retention and detention basins, marshes and other surface water areas regardless of whether the areas are natural or artificial. 
D.  Jurisdiction-Effect. 
1.  The official map is hereby established for the city together with those parts of the Towns of Clifton, Kinnickinnic, River Falls and Troy as are described and referenced on the official map. In accord with Section 62.23(6)(e), Wis. Stats., the street, highway, waterway and parkway system may be shown on the official map as extending beyond the boundaries of the city to a distance not greater than that which is within the approval jurisdiction of the city for subdivision plats in accord with Section 236.10(1)(b)2., Wis. Stats. All notations, references and other information shown on the official map shall be as much a part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein. 
2.  The official map shall show the location and width of streets, highways, waterways, parkways, parks and playgrounds which have been laid out, adopted and established by law, as well as the location of, width and exterior lines of planned new streets, highways, waterways, parkways, parks and playgrounds. 
3.  The official map shall be deemed to be conclusive with respect to the location and width of streets and highways, waterways and parkways and the location and extent of parks and playgrounds shown on the map. 
E.  Extraterritorial Areas. As set forth in Section 62.23(6)(d), Wis. Stats., the street, highway, waterway, and parkway systems shown on the official map may be shown as extending beyond the boundaries of the city into its extraterritorial subdivision approval jurisdiction. 
F.  Amendments. 
1.  The common council may amend the official map of the city from time to time so as to establish the exterior lines of the planned new streets, highways, waterways, and parkways, parks or playgrounds; or to widen, narrow, extend or close existing streets, highways, waterways and parkways, parks or playgrounds. When adopted, amendments become a part of the official map and are conclusive with respect to location and width of the streets, highways, waterways and parkways and the location and extent of parks, and playgrounds shown thereon. 
2.  The common council shall refer any proposed amendment to the official map to the plan commission for review and report thereon prior to adoption. The plan commission shall report its recommendation to the common council within sixty (60) days. In the event the plan commission does not make its report within sixty (60) days of such reference, it forfeits the right to further suspend action. 
3.  A public hearing before the common council of parties in interest and citizens shall be required before any amendments to the official map as defined in Section 62.23(6), Wis. Stats., are effective. Notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing shall be given by publication as a Class 2 Notice under Ch. 985 Wis. Stats., in the official city newspaper. 
4.  The locating, widening or closing of or the approval of the locating, widening or closing of streets, highways, waterways and parkways, parks or playgrounds by the city under provisions of law other than this section shall be deemed to amend the official map and are subject to Section 62.23(6), Wis. Stats., except that changes or additions made by a subdivision plat, approved by the city under Chapter 236 do not require the public hearing specified in Section 62.23(6)(c) if the changes or additions do not affect any land outside the plat area. 
G.  Building Permits. 
1.  No permit may be issued for any building within the limits of any street, highway, waterway or parkway shown or laid out on the map except as provided in this section. 
2.  Any person desiring to construct a building within the limits of a street, highway, waterway or parkway shown on the official map within the city may apply to the planning department for a building permit. Any person desiring to construct a building within the limits of a street, highway or parkway extending beyond the city boundaries may also apply to the planning department of the city for a building permit. Unless an application is made and the building permit granted or not denied within thirty (30) days, the person is not entitled to compensation for damage to the building in the course of such construction. 
3.  The applicant for such a permit shall submit with his application, an accurate plat plan certified by a qualified surveyor showing the location of the proposed building with reference to any street, highway, waterway, parkway or park or playground shown on the official map. 
4.  No permit for the erection of any building may be issued unless the street, highway or parkway giving access to such proposed building has been duly placed on the official map. For purposes of this section a street, highway or parkway shall be considered duly placed on the official map at the time that the governing body accepts such street, highway or parkway. 
H.  Municipal Improvements. No public sewer or other municipal street, utility, or improvement shall be constructed in any street, highway or parkway until such street, highway or parkway is duly placed on the official street-highway map. For purposes of this section, a street, highway or parkway shall be considered duly placed on the official map at the time that the governing body accepts such street, highway or parkway. 
I.  Appeals. 
1.  The zoning board of appeals of the city may review any administrative decision of the planning department denying a permit for the erection of a building under this chapter and may grant, conditionally grant or refuse a permit by the vote of a majority of its members in the manner provided for under Section 62.23(6)(d) through (g), Wis. Stats. 
2.  In taking action authorized in this subsection, the board of appeals shall follow the procedure set forth in Section 62.23(6)(f), Wis. Stats. 
J.  Certified Copy of Map. 
1.  A certified copy of the official map shall be kept in the office of the city engineer and shall be available for inspection by any interested person during regular office hours. It shall bear on its face a certification that it is a true copy of the official map described in the ordinance and shall show the date of adoption of the ordinance codified in this chapter and shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk. Thereafter every amendment of the official map shall be indicated on the aforesaid certified copy of the official map and a certificate placed thereon or attached thereto bearing the number or date of adoption of the amendment. The certificate shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk. For purposes of this section, plats, and certified survey maps do not require certification when being placed on the official map. 
2.  A certified copy of the official map and amendments thereto affecting the towns of Troy, Kinnickinnic, River Falls, and Clifton shall be sent to the town clerks of the appropriate towns and the St. Croix and Pierce County zoning administrators. 
K.  Filing with Register of Deeds. Upon adoption of the official map, the city clerk shall immediately file with the St. Croix County and Pierce County Register of Deeds a certificate showing that the city has established such official map. 
L.  Effect of Placement Upon the Official Map. The placing of any street, highway, waterway/parkway, park or playground line or lines upon the official map does not constitute the opening or establishment of any street, waterway/parkway, park or playground of the taking or acceptance of any land for these purposes. 
M.  Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the planning department to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
N.  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not more then two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), and cost of prosecution for each violation. 
O.  Severability. If any section or part of this chapter is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this chapter shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. 2007-01 § 1; Ord. 2006-34 § 1) 
Chapter 12.06 - RESIDENTIAL PARKING PERMIT SYSTEM 

12.06.010 - Purpose. 
    It is declared necessary, in the interest of the residents of the city, to establish a residential parking permit system in accord with Section 349.13(1g), Wis. Stats., whereunder motor vehicles bearing a valid residential parking permit may be parked on city streets in excess of the time limits on specifically designated streets within a specified zone or zones. The reason in support of this chapter is that there exists in the city at this time an excess of commuter parking on city streets, which limits or prevents residents of neighborhoods from parking their own motor vehicles on the streets adjoining their places of residence. It is the intent of this chapter to provide greater opportunity to those residents to avail themselves of the ability to park their motor vehicles on city streets while regulating the length of time, generally, during which commuters may park their motor vehicles on the same streets. It is further intended that this chapter shall assist in reducing automobile commuting and alleviate traffic congestion, illegal parking and related health and safety hazards in the zones established pursuant hereto. It is also the position of the city that the acquisition of a permit under this chapter confers no rights upon the holder. It is merely a privilege which is subject to revocation at the pleasure of the city. 
(Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall control the interpretation and application of this chapter: 
    "Block" means both sides of a street between two intersecting streets. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms, which are arranged, designed or used as a living quarter for one family only. Individual bathrooms and complete kitchen facilities are always associated with a dwelling unit. 
    "Lodging house" means a residential building containing lodging rooms which accommodate five or more persons who are not members of the family of the owner or keeper of the house who are provided with lodging or board and lodging in exchange for compensation. 
    "Motor vehicle" means a vehicle, which is self-propelled, including but not limited to automobiles, trucks and motorcycles and which are registered for and eligible to travel on the streets and highways of the State of Wisconsin. 
    "Parking manager" means the city employee or officer designated by the common council to administer the residential parking permit system. 
    "Residence" means a dwelling place, house, apartment, room or other place of accommodation, which constitutes the true, fixed, permanent place of abode or home, to which a resident intends to return whenever absent. 
    "Resident" means a person whose place of residence is so located in the city as to render him or her eligible for procurement of a residential parking permit under this chapter. 
    "Residential street" means a street eligible for designation under Section 12.06.030 of this chapter for use of residential parking permits. 
    "Street" means a route of public travel, opened and maintained by the city and located within the city limits. 
    "Temporary resident" means a person who lives in River Falls for the academic year at the University of Wisconsin-River Falls or for some other purpose for a duration shorter than that of one year in length. 
(Ord. 2003-24 § 1 (part); Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.030 - Zone designations-Application to residential streets and withdrawal of residential streets from application. 
A.  The designated zones in which residential parking permits may be obtained by residents shall include the following: 
1.  Zone A. Zone A shall consist of the following blocks or described partial blocks of these named streets: 
a.  Fifth Street: between Spring Street and Elm Street, 
b.  Sixth Street: between Spring Street and Maple Street, 
c.  Locust Street: between Second Street and Third Street, 
d.  Walnut Street and Elm Street: between Second Street and Sixth Street, 
e.  Third Street and Fourth Street: between Spring Street and Maple Street; 
2.  Zone AA. Zone AA shall consist of the following blocks or described partial blocks of these named streets: 
a.  Valley View Dr. 
b.  South Fork Dr. 
c.  Broadway St. from Valley View Dr. to South Fork Dr. 
3.  Zone B. Zone B shall consist of the following blocks or described partial blocks of these named streets: 
a.  State Street: Between Cascade Avenue and Vine Street, 
b.  Vine Street: From Main Street West to its end, 
c.  Maple Street and Pine Street: Between Second Street and Eighth Street, 
d.  Third Street, Fourth Street and Seventh Street: Between Maple Street and Cedar Street, 
e.  Eighth Street: Between Spring Street and Cedar Street, 
f.  Hazel Street and Lake Street: Between Sixth Street and Eighth Street, 
g.  Spring Street: Between Sixth Street and Crescent Street, 
h.  Hillcrest Street and Pierce Street: Between Spring Street and Oak Knoll, 
i.  Crescent Street: Between Spring Street and Cascade Avenue, 
j.  Birch Street: Between Cascade Avenue and Morgan Road, 
k.  Birch Crest Lane: Between Cascade Avenue and Birch Street, 
l.  Birchcrest Drive: From Cascade Avenue North to its end; 
4.  Zone BB. Zone BB shall consist of the following blocks or described partial blocks of these named streets: 
a.  Oak Knoll Avenue: Between Cascade Avenue and Crescent Street 
5.  Zone C. Zone C shall consist of the following blocks or described partial blocks of these named streets: 
a.  Spring Street: Between westerly most Fifth Street and Sixth Street, 
b.  Fifth Street: Between Cascade Avenue and Spring Street, 
c.  Sixth Street: Between Cascade Avenue and Spring Street. 
B.  Within Zones A, AA and C, residents of the designated streets shall be deemed to be eligible for the issuance of residential parking permits as follows: upon application under this chapter, no more than two permits shall be issued for each single-family residence. For each multifamily residence or lodging house, one permit per tenant to a maximum number as allowed by the zoning code. 
C.  Petition for Designation of Zone for Residential Parking Permit Purposes. For the inclusion of one or more of the streets designated as being in Zones B and BB, the street must abut a street with similar parking restrictions or be adjacent to the University of Wisconsin-River Falls campus, and greater than fifty (50) percent of the property owners of a given block shall petition the common council. All properties abutting a given block shall be considered. In the event such a petition is filed with the city, the common council shall hold a public hearing, to be preceded by a public notice published in the city's official newspaper which shall identify the residential streets proposed for consideration of inclusion under the residential parking permit system based upon the criteria stated above, as well as setting forth the reasons for such consideration. Only after the holding of such a public hearing may the city officially declare by resolution one or more of the residential streets within Zones B and BB to be subject to this chapter. 
D.  Withdrawal of Residential Streets from Application of this Chapter. Once the decision has been made by the common council to designate the residential streets in one or more of the defined zones as being subject to this chapter, none of the streets may be withdrawn from application of this chapter for a period of at least twelve (12) months next following the date of common council action activating this chapter in a given zone. Thereafter, a change may be made upon the petition of greater than fifty (50) percent of the property owners of a given block, such petitions to contain the same information as is required of original petitions under subsection C of this section. In such event, withdrawals of streets may be accomplished on less than a zone-by-zone basis but shall not apply to anything less than a particular street in a particular block. Prior to ordering the withdrawal of a particular street in a particular block from operation of this chapter, the common council shall hold a public hearing in accord with subsection C of this section and the city police chief or his or her designee shall provide the city with a recommendation as to the petition for withdrawal. After the public hearing has been held, the common council may, in its discretion, continue operation of this chapter as to a given street and block or it may rescind the same by resolution. In the event that it rescinds operation of this chapter as to a given street and block, permits shall no longer validate residential parking. 
(Ord. 2006-16 § 1 (part): Ord. 2003-28 § 1 (part); Ord. 2003-24 § 1 (part); Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-14 , § 2, 9-13-2016; Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.040 - Implementation of system. 
    For each street in Zone A and those in Zones AA B and BB which are included upon petition under the operation of this chapter, this chapter shall be in effect from September 1st each year to May 31st of the following year during the hours of seven a.m. to four p.m. excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. For each street in Zone C, this chapter shall be in effect at all times during the hours of seven a.m. to seven p.m. excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. 
    In Zones A, B, and C; parking on the even side of each affected street shall be limited to those vehicles displaying valid residential parking permits during the stated hours each day and any vehicle, whether displaying a valid residential parking permit or not, may be parked on the odd side of each affected street unless otherwise restricted. 
    In Zones BB; parking on the odd side of each affected street shall be limited to those vehicles displaying valid residential parking permits during the stated hours each day and any vehicle, whether displaying a valid residential parking permit or not, may be parked on the even side of each affected street unless otherwise restricted. 
    In Zone AA; parking on both sides of each affected street shall be limited to those vehicles displaying valid residential parking permits during the stated hours each day. 
    For purposes of this chapter, the "even" and "odd" sides of each street shall be determined by the address numbering system. 
(Ord. 2006-16 § 1 (part): Ord. 2003-24 § 1 (part); Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.050 - Issuance of permits. 
    A residential parking permit shall be issued, upon application, to the owner or operator of a motor vehicle who resides within one of the zones designated under Section 12.06.030(A), which shall allow the owner or operator to park on any street designated for residential parking in the zone, as long as the permit is valid, subject to other designated restrictions, if any. Such a permit shall not be issued to any owner or operator who has outstanding citations for parking or moving violations in the city. The cost of such permit, including guest permits, shall be approved by the city council and established in the city fee schedule. 
(Ord. 2006-16 § 1 (part): Ord. 2005-15 § 1 (part): Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.060 - Application. 
    Each application shall be made on a form prepared by the city and shall include the following information: (1) The name of the owner or operator of the motor vehicle, his or her residential address, the make, model and registration number of the motor vehicle; and (2) The owner's driver's license. The city parking manager may request further information from the applicant to verify his or her eligibility for issuance of a permit, including but not limited to the following: if the applicant's driver's license or motor vehicle registration reflects a place of residence other than within the zone in question or one which is not situated on one of the designated residential streets, the applicant shall be required to attest to the fact that the motor vehicle in question is kept only at the address listed on the application, located on an affected residential street. If a tenant at the listed residence, the applicant may be required to present a copy of an executed lease or proof satisfactory to the city that he or she actually resides at the place of residence listed. Each application shall be attested to, meaning that the applicant shall swear or affirm as to the correctness of the information supplied therein. 
(Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.070 - Term and form of permit. 
    Each permit for Zones A, AA, B and BB shall be valid from September 1st to May 31st of the new following year. Permits issued for Zone C shall be valid from September 1st to August 31st of the new following year. Permits shall automatically be voided prior to the expiration date of such a term should the owner or operator of the motor vehicle in question remove his or her place of residence to a street which is not designated as residential, to an area of the city which is not contained within the designated zone for which it was issued or outside of the city. Each permit shall display the motor vehicle's license number and permit expiration date and shall be displayed by hanging upon the rear view mirror so as to be clearly visible through the windshield of the motor vehicle to which it applies. In the case of a motorcycle, permit shall be displayed as directed by the parking manager. 
(Ord. 2006-16 § 1 (part): Ord. 2003-24 § 1 (part); Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.080 - Temporary residents. 
    Temporary residents of one of the designated zones in the city may apply for temporary residential parking permits upon compliance with all of the provisions of this section: Such applicant shall attest under oath on the application that he or she: (1) maintains his or her permanent residence in another jurisdiction and shall provide the address thereof; (2) owns or operates a motor vehicle registered in the jurisdiction of his or her permanent residence, whether or not that is the State of Wisconsin, for which vehicle the permit is being sought; (3) is living in one of the zones subject to this chapter, under a valid lease, at a particular place of residence, specifying the address therefore, as well as the name, address and telephone number of the landlord or his or her agent; (4) that it is understood by the applicant that any change in circumstances materially affecting continuing eligibility for the permit or any false information or representation made in the process of applying for and receiving a permit shall be cause for immediate revocation of such a permit. Furthermore, each applicant for a temporary permit shall be required to provide a copy of his or her lease at the time of making such application. Temporary permits issued under this section shall be valid only for the remaining term of the lease in question or one year, whichever is shorter. 
(Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.090 - Guests or invitees of residents. 
    For use by guests of invitees of residents of streets subject to this chapter, two guest permits shall be provided to the owner of each property containing one or more dwelling units in the same manner and subject to the same restrictions as are resident permits. Guest permits are only valid for the city block in which they were issued. 
(Ord. 2005-15 § 1 (part): Ord. 2003-18 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 11-22-2016) 
12.06.100 - Parking permits. 
A.  A residential parking permit is valid only when it is displayed pursuant to Section 12.06.070 on a motor vehicle parked along one of the residential streets subject to this chapter. Use of the parking permit shall be restricted to streets designated for residential parking permits within each specified zone. A residential parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve to the holder a parking space, whether on a given residential street or on any residential street within the zone in question. 
B.  A residential parking permit shall not authorize the holder to cause to stand or park a motor vehicle at such places where parking is prohibited or during such times as when the stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles is set aside for specified types of vehicles, nor exempt the holder from observance of any traffic regulation other than the specified hourly parking limit.
