Code by the city's office of the building inspector for any construction, repair, enlargement, improvement or alteration of any building, or structure within the city. It does not include the "Fast Start" permit or preliminary permit issued at the time of excavation or installation of footings for any such building or structure. 
(b)  "Capital costs" means the capital costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, including the cost of land, and including legal, engineering, planning and design costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities, except that not more than ten (10) percent of capital costs may consist of legal, engineering, planning and design costs which relate directly to the public improvement for which the impact fees were imposed exceed ten (10) percent of capital costs. "Capital costs" does not include other noncapital costs to construct, expand or improve public facilities or the costs of equipment to construct, expand or improve public facilities. 
(c)  "Developer" means a person that constructs or creates a land development. 
(d)  "Development" means the construction or modification of improvements to real property that requires issuance of a building permit to create additional residential dwelling units within the city. For purposes of this chapter, development does not include new, expanded or improved nonresidential uses within the city. 
(e)  "Impact fee" means a fee to be collected per Section 14.16.050 of this chapter for the construction or modification of improvements to real property that creates additional residential dwelling units. Non-residential buildings are excluded from library impact fees. 
(f)  "Multifamily" means any residential dwelling greater than a duplex or twin home. 
(g)  "Public facilities" for purposes of this chapter, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0617, means facilities for library services. 
(h)  "Residential equivalent unit (REU)" means a unit of measure for impact fees equivalent to one single-family residential dwelling unit. 
(i)  "Service area" means a geographic area delineated by the city council within which the city provides or will provide facilities. 
(j)  "City" means the city of River Falls. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2014-09, § 5, 10-14-2014 ) 
14.16.030 - Impact fee revenue administration. 
(a)  An impact fee shall be imposed on developers to pay for capital costs of public facilities that are necessary to accommodate land development. 
(b)  Revenues from impact fees shall be placed in one or more segregated, interest bearing accounts and shall be accounted for separately from other city funds. Impact fee revenues and interest earned thereon may be expended only for capital costs, including interest expense, for which the impact fees were imposed. 
(c)  Impact fee revenues imposed and collected but not used within a reasonable period of time after collection to pay the capital costs for which they were imposed shall be refunded on a prorated proportional basis, as defined by Section 66.0617(9), Wis. Stats., to the current record owner or owners of the property with respect to which the impact fees were imposed. Under this chapter the reasonable and appropriate time period for expenditure of impact fee revenues shall be within ten (10) years after collection of the impact fee, subject to the adoption by the common council of a resolution extending said expenditure period for three years in accord with Section 66.0617(9)(b), Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-2, § 1, 1-26-10) 
14.16.040 - Use of impact fees. 
    Funds collected from impact fees shall be used solely for the purpose of paying the proportionate costs of providing public facilities that may become necessary due to development. These costs may include the costs of debt service on bonds or similar debt instruments when the debt has been incurred for the purpose of proceeding with designated public facilities projects prior to the collection of all anticipated impact fees for that project, to reimburse the city for advances of other funds or reserves, and such other purposes consistent with Wis. Stats. Section 66.06 17, which are recorded and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
14.16.050 - Payment of impact fees. 
    All required impact fees, unless expressly exempted in a section of this chapter, shall be paid one hundred (100) percent at the time of building permit issuance. Rates that are in effect at the time of building permit issuance shall be applied. Impact fee payments shall be the responsibility of the owner of record at the time of building permit issuance. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-2, § 2, 1-26-10) 
14.16.060 - Appeals. 
    The payment of an impact fee imposed under this section as a condition of a building permit may be contested as to the amount, collection or use of the impact fee to the city council, provided that the applicant files a written notice of appeal with the city clerk's office within fifteen (15) days of the approval by the building inspector of an application for a building permit upon which the impact fee is imposed. Such notice of appeal shall be entitled "Notice of Appeal of Impact Fee" and shall state the applicant's name, address, telephone number, address (if available) and legal description of the land development upon which the impact fee is imposed, and a statement of the nature of and reasons for the appeal. The city clerk shall schedule the appeal for consideration by the city council at a regular meeting as soon as reasonably practicable under the circumstances and shall notify the applicant of the time, date and place of such meeting in writing by regular mail, deposited in the mail no later than at least three (3) days before the date of such meeting. Upon review of such appeal, the city council may adjust the amount, collection or use of the impact fee upon just and reasonable cause shown. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
14.16.070 - Refunds of fees paid. 
    Any funds not expended within the reasonable period of time after collection as defined by Section 66.0617(9), Wis. Stats., to pay the capital costs for which they were imposed shall be returned to such current landowner with interest at a rate of two percent per annum. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-2, § 3, 1-26-10) 
14.16.080 - Impact fees. 
(a)  The basis for the imposition of library impact fees is the Impact Fee Needs Assessment Report and its attachments prepared by Short, Elliott and Hendrickson, Inc. (SEH) in June 2003, which are on file in the office of the city clerk of the city of River Falls. 
(b)  The library impact fee will be adopted by resolution. 
(c)  The common council shall adopt by resolution and may, from time to time, amend a schedule of fees to implement this chapter, a copy of which shall be maintained at all times for public inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-2, § 4, 1-26-10 
14.16.090 - Exemptions. 
    The following situations shall be exempted from payment of the impact fees: 
(a)  The replacement of a building or structure with a new building or structure of the same size and use where no additional residential units are added and no additional non-residential square footage is added. 
(b)  Demolition of residential units or non-residential building square footage without replacement does not prompt a refund of previously paid impact fees. 
(c)  Upon city council approval, an exemption from or a reduction in the amount of library impact fees on land development that provides city, state or federal approved low cost housing programs may be made. As set forth in Section 66.0617(7), Wis. Stats., no amount of an impact fee for which an exemption or reduction is provided under this subsection may be shifted to any other development in the land development in which the low-cost housing is located or to any other land development in the city. Any claim for exemption must be made no later than the time of application for a building permit. 
(d)  Upon city council approval, an exemption from or a reduction in the amount of library impact fees on development located within a tax incremental district may be made. As set forth in Section 66.0617(7), Wis. Stats., no amount of an impact fee for which an exemption or reduction is provided under this subsection may be shifted to any other development in the land development in which a tax incremental district is located or to any other land development in the city. Any claim for exemption must be made no later than the time of application for a building permit. 
(e)  Non-residential development. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
14.16.100 - Review. 
    The council may review the impact fees contained herein every two (2) years. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
14.16.110 - Other means of financing library improvements. 
    Pursuant to Section 66.0617(2)(6), Wis. Stats. the imposition of library impact fees under this section does not prohibit or limit the city's authority to finance library facilities by other means as authorized by law, including but not limited to, the use of fees which are not impact fees as the term is used in § 66.0617, Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. 2003-22 § 1 (part)) 
Title 15 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
Chapters: 
Chapter 15.04 - BUILDING CODE 
Sections: 

15.04.010 - Code enforcement officer. 
A.  How Appointed. The code enforcement officer shall be appointed in accordance with the adopted personnel policy. "Code enforcement officer" shall be a title given any individual who is certified by the State of Wisconsin for inspection of UDC-Construction, UDC-HVAC, UDC-Electrical, UDC-Plumbing and Commercial Buildings, signifying sole responsibility for enforcing this chapter, per Chapters SPS 320 to 325, of the Wis. Adm. Code. He or she shall also enforce other building and housing related ordinances as adopted by the city council. 
B.  Code enforcement officers shall be under the supervision of the city administrator or his designee. 
C.  Powers and Duties. The code enforcement officer shall have the power and duty to enforce the provisions of this chapter and all other ordinances and all laws and orders of the state which relate to building construction, plumbing, HVAC, electrical installations, moving regulations regarding buildings, and shall assist with site and zoning enforcement, and erosion control, except as specifically provided by other ordinances. For these purposes, the code enforcement officer shall have the authority to enter buildings and premises in the city at reasonable times. 
D.  Maintenance. All public and private buildings and structures, new and existing, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition. The code enforcement officer may cause any building or structure to be inspected in order to assure compliance with this section. 
E.  Cooperation of Other City Officials and Officers. The code enforcement officer may request and shall receive the assistance and cooperation of other officers of the city in the discharge of his or her duties. 
F.  Liability. The code enforcement officer, when acting in good faith and without malice in the performance of his or her duties, shall not be held personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act or by reason of any act or omission in the discharge of his or her duties. Suits brought against the code enforcement officer shall be defended by legal counsel provided by the city until final termination of such proceedings. 
    By enforcing the building codes, the city shall not be held liable for damages to persons or property or assume any responsibility as a result of the inspections authorized by this chapter or any certificates of completion/occupancy issued under this chapter. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.020 - Designation of unfit buildings and dwellings and procedures for condemnation. 
A.  Whenever the code enforcement officer or health officer finds any building or dwelling or part thereof, to be in his or her judgment so old, dilapidated, decayed, out of repair, vermin infested, lacking in illumination and ventilation, decaying, unsafe, unsanitary, or otherwise unfit for human habitation, occupancy or use, he or she shall condemn the property, and after notification of his supervisor, shall placard it as such. The code enforcement officer or health officer shall not be prohibited from taking independent action when, in his or her judgment, an immediate threat to life or safety exists. 
1.  Any building or dwelling placarded as unfit for human habitation or use shall be vacated within thirty (30) days or less, as determined by the code enforcement officer or health officer. 
2.  No person shall deface or remove the placard from any building or dwelling which has been condemned, except as provided in subdivision 3 of this subsection. 
3.  No building or dwelling which has been condemned and placarded as unfit for human habitation shall again be used for human habitation until written approval is secured from, and such placard is removed by, the code enforcement officer or health officer. The code enforcement officer or health officer shall remove such placard when he or she determines that the condition(s) upon which the condemnation was predicated are eliminated. 
B.  The owner shall be notified, in writing, of the placarding, the conditions which warranted such action, and the options, noted herein, for correcting the violation(s). 
1.  If a building or dwelling, or part thereof, can be made habitable by repairs, the owner may, with approval from the code enforcement officer or the health officer, make it safe and sanitary. 
2.  If the building or dwellings is ordered to be razed, such order and proceedings shall be as provided in Wisconsin Statutes. 
C.  Any person affected by any notice or order relating to the condemning and placarding of a building or dwelling may request, and shall be granted, a hearing on the matter as provided in Chapter 1.12 of this code. 
D.  Nothing herein shall be construed as conflicting in any way with appropriate codes of the state and wherever such conflict exists, the more restrictive code shall apply. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.030 - Building permits, fees and inspections. 
A.  Permits Required. 
1.  No building or any part thereof shall be erected or ground broken for the same within the city, except as herein provided, until a permit therefor has first been obtained by the owner or his or her authorized agent from the code enforcement officer. 
2.  Additions, Alterations, and Repairs. Additions, alterations, or repairs to any building within the city shall require a building permit and be made to comply with current codes as determined by the code enforcement officer who shall consider issues of life safety, structural or occupancy overload and other hazards. 
B.  Exempt Work. A building permit is not required for the following work: 
1.  One-story detached accessory structures not on a permanent foundation and under one hundred fifty (150) square feet in projected roof area; All accessory structures shall be anchored and shall maintain all setback requirements per Title 17 of this municipal code; 
2.  Fences less than or equal to six feet in height (see Title 17 of this municipal code for the requirements of fences greater than six feet in height); 
3.  Landscape retaining walls which do not affect the structural integrity of a structure; 
4.  Platforms, patios and walks set on, or within eight inches of finished grade; 
5.  Decorating work, such as painting, papering or carpeting; 
6.  Minor repairs and alterations which do not change occupancy, area, structural strength, fire protection, ingress and egress, natural light, and ventilation; 
7.  Replacement of roof covering; 
8.  Replacement or repair of bathroom fixtures and faucets; 
9.  Replacement of electrical outlets and light fixtures; 
10.  Replacement of siding; 
11.  Replacement of doors and windows; 
12.  Replacement of water heaters; 
13.  Replacement of furnaces, boilers or air conditioners; 
14.  Replacement of driveways and parking lots; 
15.  Installation of by-pass water meters and backflow preventers. 
C.  Application. Application for a building permit shall be made in writing upon a form furnished by the city and shall state the following: 
1.  The name and address of the property owner; 
2.  The legal description of the land upon which the building is located or the street address assigned by engineering; 
3.  The name and address of the designer, general contractor, subcontractors and such other information as the code enforcement officer may require. 
D.  Plans. For all construction pertaining to one-and two-family dwellings, two complete sets of plans and specifications, including a site plan showing the location of the proposed building with respect to adjoining streets, alleys, lot lines and other buildings located on the property, shall be submitted with an application for a building permit, one set of plans to be returned after approval as herein provided and the other set to remain on file with the code enforcement officer. 
1.  For buildings required to comply with the state commercial codes, a single set of original plans, bearing a stamp of approval from the state department of commerce and the signature of the engineer or architect, shall be submitted as a condition of the building permit. 
2.  The site plan shall show positive drainage away from all buildings. The site plan shall also indicate the elevation of all property line(s), the elevations of the driveway and adjacent street, and the elevation of the garage floor or parking lot. 
    The new garage floor must be elevated above or below the front property line such that the slope of the driveway is between two (2) and fifteen (15) percent. The elevation of the front property line shall meet the existing or proposed sidewalk elevations as established by the city engineer's office. 
E.  Waiver of Plans. If the code enforcement officer finds that the character of the work is sufficiently described in the application, he or she may waive the filing of plans for alterations or repairs if he or she determines that the work is such that compliance can be gained without the submission of detailed plans. 
F.  Approval of Plans. If the code enforcement officer determines that the proposed building will comply with all ordinances of the city and all applicable laws and orders of the state, he or she shall officially approve and stamp one set of the plans and return it to the owner and shall issue a building permit therefor which shall be kept and displayed at the site of the proposed building. 
    After approval, the plans and specifications shall not be altered in any respect which involves the safety of the building or occupants, except with written consent of the code enforcement officer. If adequate plans are presented for part of the building only, the code enforcement officer may issue a permit for that portion of the building only before receiving plans and specifications for the entire building. 
G.  Retention of Plans. 
1.  The applicant shall keep a set of plans approved by the code enforcement officer available at the construction site at all times while work is in progress for use by the contractors and the code enforcement officer. 
2.  The issuance of approved plans shall not lessen the responsibility of the owner or contractor to build to the provisions of this chapter. The code enforcement officer shall require any violations or errors in such plans or work resulting from same to be corrected. 
H.  Responsibility for Posting Permit Card. Any homeowner, contractor or subcontractor working on a job shall insure that a building permit card is posted at the site before starting any work. 
I.  Relationship to Housing Code. Any person constructing a building within the city intended for occupancy by third persons which would require any permit or license under Chapter 15.16 of this municipal code shall be advised that the specifications and design standards contained in Chapter 15.16 including, but not limited to, all room sizes and egress requirements shall be adhered to if the owner or applicant intends to later obtain any necessary licenses or permits to rent or lease such building. 
J.  Fees. Fees shall be approved by the common council and on file with the city clerk. 
1.  Schedule. A building permit fee schedule shall be kept on file at the community development department. Payment of fees shall be prerequisite to issuance of a building permit. 
2.  New Construction, Alterations, Additions and Repairs. The fees for all new construction, alterations, additions, and repairs required under this chapter shall be in accordance with the current fee schedule. 
3.  Plan Check Fee. When a plan is required to be reviewed for financing or other purposes, but no permit is requested, a plan check fee according to the current fee schedule shall be paid to the city. If a permit is requested within six (6) months of the review, the fee shall be applied toward permit fees. 
4.  Signs. Fees for sign permits shall be calculated in accordance with Title 17 of this municipal code. 
5.  Voluntary Inspection. The fee for conducting a voluntary inspection of an existing structure, upon the request of an owner or lawful occupant, shall be charged according to the current fee schedule. 
K.  Inspection of Work. 
1.  All inspections required to enforce this chapter shall be performed by the code enforcement officer. He or she shall notify the permit holder and/or owner of any noted violations. These include erosion, footings, foundation, rough-in inspections for general construction (framing), electrical, plumbing, HVAC, drain tiles, insulation, and final/occupancy inspection. 
2.  The building permit holder or an authorized representative shall, in writing, or orally, request inspections of the city which are noted herein. The code enforcement officer shall perform the requested inspection(s) within two business days after notification, except the final inspection for purposes of occupancy. (See also subsection M of this section.) 
3.  All inspections shall be performed prior to concealment of each phase of construction. 
    Exception. Construction may proceed if the inspection has not taken place within two business days of notification, except if otherwise agreed between the applicant and the code enforcement officer. 
L.  Inspection Record. The building permit card shall be conveniently located on the construction site, as required under this chapter, to allow the, code enforcement officer to record inspections. Its location shall be such that any person seeing the work in progress can also reasonably determine that a proper permit is issued. Work shall not proceed beyond the indicated stage on the permit card without the approval of the code enforcement officer. 
M.  Final Inspection (Certificate of Occupancy/ Completion). Upon completing the final inspection, the code enforcement officer shall sign and date the occupancy category on the building permit card. The signed building permit card shall then serve as the certificate of occupancy/completion. 
1.  New Residential Construction. No occupancy shall be allowed prior to the completion of the final inspection. 
2.  Additions and Alterations. No occupancy and/or use of the area affected by the building permit shall be allowed prior to the completion of the final inspection. 
N.  Voluntary Inspection. The code enforcement officer, at the request of an owner or a lawful occupant, may enter and inspect a building, subject to the provisions of chapters 15.04 through 15.16, to ascertain compliance with those codes. 
1.  This inspection shall be specific to the code items in question by the owner and shall not serve as a general point of sale inspection or as verification or confirmation of the disclosure statement which is required of the seller pursuant to Ch. 709, Wis. Stats. 
2.  If any violations are noted during the voluntary inspection which are directly related to the specific areas in question, the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, shall be required to obtain all required permits and to correct the violations. 
3.  Per Section 15.04.180 of this chapter, the property owner shall disclose all orders to correct outstanding violations of this chapter and Chapters 15.08 through 15.16 of this municipal code. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, §§ 1-4, 6-22-2010) 
15.04.040 - Demolition permits. 
A.  Deposits. A refundable deposit, as determined by the community development department, utilities and engineering, may be required prior to the issuance of a demolition (razing) permit to insure proper abandonment of water and sewer facilities, electrical service, the restoration of the building site, and any repairs to the street, sidewalks, or curb and gutter caused by the demolition. Utility department staff shall inspect and sign off on the disconnecting or temporary abandonment of electrical service and water and sewer lines. The municipal utility shall specify the manner in which the disconnection or abandonment shall be conducted. 
B.  Time Limits. Water and sewer lines shall be properly abandoned within ten (10) days of the permit issuance. All work and restoration of the site, including city property, shall be completed within sixty (60) days. Failure of the applicant to complete the required work shall constitute forfeiture, to the city, of costs incurred by the city to complete the required work. If the costs incurred by the city exceed the deposit amount, the owner and/or applicant shall be responsible for the additional expenses. 
C.  Fee. The fee for a demolition (razing) permit shall be in accordance with the current building permit fee schedule and shall be in addition to the deposit required in subsection A of this section. 
D.  Site Cleanup. As part of the demolition project, all building components and materials associated with the building including, but not limited to, foundation, footings, gas or oil storage tanks, and abandoned appliances, shall be removed from the site in an approved manner. 
E.  Inspection. An inspection must be completed by the code enforcement officer or the appropriate inspection agency prior to the back-filling of open excavations. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.050 - Electrical permits and inspections. 
    All electrical work, including the placing of wires and other equipment, shall conform to Chapter SPS 316, Wis. Adm. Code and Chapter 15.12 of this municipal code. No electric wiring or other equipment shall be installed or altered without first securing a permit as provided in Chapter 15.12 of this municipal code. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.060 - Plumbing permits and inspections. 
    All plumbing shall be done in compliance with Chapter 15.08 of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.070 - Issuance of permits. 
A.  Payment of Fees. All fees shall be paid, upon application, to the city, and shall be nonrefundable. The building permit shall be issued by the code enforcement officer after review and approval of the application and any required documentation. 
B.  Permit Lapses. A permit issued under this chapter shall lapse and be void, unless operations under the permit are commenced within six months from the date of issuance. Additionally, a building permit issued pursuant to 15.04.030 of this chapter shall be valid for a period of two years, within such time the construction shall be completed and a certificate of compliance issued, subject to a reasonable extension thereof as provided in Chapter 15.20 of this municipal code. 
C.  Exception. A permit issued for moving a building shall be good for a period of six months from the date of issuance. 
D.  Revocation. If the code enforcement officer finds at any time that the provisions of this chapter are not being complied with and that the holder of the permit refuses to conform after a written warning or instruction has been issued, the code enforcement officer shall revoke the building, HVAC, electrical, or plumbing permit by written notices posted at the site of the work. When any permit is revoked, no further work shall be done until the permit is reissued, except such work as the code enforcement officer may order as a condition to the reissuance of the permit or as he or she may require for the preservation of human life and safety. 
E.  Reporting of Violations. All officers of the city shall report at once to the code enforcement officer any building, HVAC, electrical or plumbing work which is being carried on without a permit as required by this municipal code. 
F.  Records. The code enforcement officer shall keep a record of all permits, fees and inspections under this chapter and shall make an annual report thereon to the city council. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.080 - Moving permit. 
A.  Required. No building shall be moved from outside of the city limits onto a lot, piece or parcel of land within the city limits, nor shall any building be moved from a lot, piece, or parcel of land within the city limits without the person desiring to move such building having first obtained a moving permit from the code enforcement officer. 
B.  Exempt. A structure that is loaded to meet D.O.T. requirements and will not cause local road damage may be moved without a moving permit. If a structure is of sufficient size to cause a traffic problem, a permit will be required. 
C.  Review and Approval of Application. The code enforcement officer will review the application and all required documentation submitted by the owner or mover. The documentation shall include, but not be limited to, approvals from the following agencies; River Falls municipal utilities, the Department of Transportation, zoning, engineering, police, natural and propane gas companies, cable companies, phone companies, and tree services. Upon receipt of such approvals and the appropriate fees and/or deposits, the code enforcement officer may issue the permit. 
D.  Application. The application forms for a moving permit shall be provided by the code enforcement officer. 
E.  Conditions on Alterations. 
1.  Where the applicant proposes to move and alter a building, in addition to obtaining the required building permits, the community development department shall designate a time within which the alterations must be completed. Failure to complete alterations in such designated time shall constitute a violation of this chapter and each day in which such alterations remain uncompleted shall be a separate violation. 
2.  The foundation for a moved building and reconnected heating, plumbing and electric systems shall be made to comply to current building codes as determined by the code enforcement officer. At the applicant's option, a voluntary inspection (pre-inspection) will be conducted and a list of potential repairs noted. 
F.  Mover's Responsibility. Applicants shall be responsible for all expenses associated with moving a building including, but not limited to, public safety, utility relocation, street repair and any damages to public property and shall, as part of the application process, hold and save the city harmless for all damages or injuries that may result from moving a building. In addition, the applicant shall, prior to receiving a permit, deposit with the city the sum of five hundred dollars ($500) or such greater amount as may be determined by the community development department and utilities, sufficient to cover the costs of any utility or other work necessary to permit moving the building. Posting a deposit does not relieve the applicant of any liability for costs and damages exceeding the amount of the deposit. 
    Upon the completion of the move, the city and utility shall determine any damages caused by the move. The owner/applicant shall be responsible for all costs incurred by the city and utility, including the repair caused to the street and any public or private property, along with any other costs associated with the move. Should the applicant fail to reimburse the city for such expenses and settle damage claims, the city and utility shall apply the deposit and release the balance to the applicant. 
G.  Fee. The permit fee for moving a structure shall be in accordance with the current fee schedule. 
H.  Display and Term of Permit. A moving permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be prominently displayed at all times on the building to be moved, or to be moved and altered, until all conditions established by the city have been complied with. Such permit shall be good for a period of six months from the date of issuance. 
I.  Appeal. Any person aggrieved by the granting or denial of a moving permit by the code enforcement officer may appeal to the board of appeals. The board of appeals, in the absence of proof to the contrary adduced in such hearing, shall deem the refusal to grant such moving permit to be based on the inability of the building to meet the findings required by subsection E of this section for approval by the code enforcement officer. 
J.  Violation. Each day that a building, which has been moved in violation of this chapter, remains on any site other than its original site, shall constitute a separate violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.090 - Construction of buildings. 
A.  State Codes Adopted. 
1.  One- and Two-Family. The Wisconsin Uniform Dwelling Code, Chapters SPS 320 to 325, Wis. Adm. Code, and all amendments thereto, is made by reference a part of this chapter with respect to those classes of buildings to which the Uniform Dwelling Code specifically applies. A copy of such Uniform Dwelling Code is available at the public library. 
    Dwellings constructed prior to the Wisconsin Uniform Dwelling Code (June 1, 1980), Additions, and the portion of existing dwellings which are being altered, shall be made to comply with the current UDC requirements as per Section 15.04.030(A)(2). 
2.  Commercial Buildings. Chapters SPS 361 to 365, Wis. Adm. Code, and all amendments and references thereto and contained therein are made by reference a part of this chapter. 
B.  Twin Home Construction. 
1.  Setback/Fire Walls. Each single-family dwelling unit, constructed as part of a twin home for the purpose of separate ownership of each dwelling unit, shall be provided with a one-hour rated fire wall at the common property line. The fire wall shall extend from the lowest point of the foundation to the underside of the roof sheathing and to the outermost projection of the eaves. 
2.  Sharing of Foundation Wall. Each single-family dwelling unit may share a single foundation wall, composed of cement or masonry, at the common property line. 
C.  Terms. The building terms used in this chapter shall have the meaning given them in the code that applies to the structure or work in question. Where a conflict is present, the most restrictive definition shall prevail. 
D.  Workmanship. Workmanship in the fabrication, preparation and installation of materials shall conform to generally accepted good practice. 
E.  Applications. Buildings not covered under applicable state codes shall be constructed or altered in such a manner as to bring them as close as practical into compliance with the current codes and in such a manner as to not increase a fire or life safety problem. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.100 - Yard and setbacks. 
    Yard and setbacks shall be as set forth in Title 17 of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.110 - Fire district. 
    The fire district shall be as set forth in Chapter 8.20 of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.120 - Regulations within fire district. 
    Chapter 8.20 of this municipal code shall govern the erection, enlargement or placing of any building within the fire district. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.130 - Razing old and/or damaged buildings in fire district. 
    Any existing frame building within the fire limits which may hereafter be damaged by fire or which has deteriorated to an amount less than one-half of its fair market value, exclusive of the foundation, shall not be repaired or rebuilt, but shall, under the provisions of § 101.14(1)(c), Wis. Stats. be ordered removed by the code enforcement officer. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.140 - Installation of liquefied petroleum gas systems. 
    Chapter SPS 340, Wis. Adm. Code, is made by reference a part of this chapter with respect to the installation of liquefied petroleum gas systems in the city and shall be enforced by the fire department and/or a state inspector. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.150 - Existing supplemental heating units. 
    Supplemental heating units, chimneys and fireplaces judged by the code enforcement officer to be in violation of safe operating standards shall be tagged by the code enforcement officer as "faulty." The owner of faulty installations and the occupants of the dwelling unit shall be notified immediately upon inspection and advised of corrective action needed. Failure to take corrective action on faulty installations within the time frame ordered by the code enforcement officer shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.160 - Smoke detectors. 
A.  Any building occupied for sleeping purposes shall have smoke detectors installed and maintained in accordance with the laws of this state. Reference § SPS 321.09, Ch. SPS 328 and § SPS 351.245, Wis. Admin. Code. 
B.  No unauthorized person shall tamper with, alter or remove any detector, fire extinguisher, fire apparatus or alarm from any building or unit required by this section or required by the laws of this state, except for necessary testing or maintenance. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.170 - Building numbering required. 
    All buildings in the city shall be numbered in accordance with the following: 
A.  Numbers shall be easily seen from the street the building is addressed. Numbers shall be block style and a minimum of three inches in height, unless otherwise specified. The use of words to write out the required street number is not permitted. The color of the numbers shall distinctly contrast the color of the covering they are placed on. 
B.  Multiple dwellings shall be identified with numbers which are a minimum of five inches in height and individual apartment identification shall be minimum of three inches in height. 
C.  When practical, the required numbers shall be placed as close to the main entry door as possible, but not be placed on garage doors or in similar locations on the building that may become covered. 
D.  Buildings exempt from this requirement include secondary buildings if there is a properly numbered building on the same lot. 
E.  In the event of conflict, the code enforcement officer shall determine compliance. 
F.  All new structures shall meet the minimum requirements of this section prior to occupancy being granted. 
    Retroactive. All existing structures shall meet the minimum requirements of this section. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.180 - Disclosure. 
    Pursuant to Ch. 709, Wis. Stats., the property owner shall disclose all orders to repair, alter, or correct outstanding violations of this chapter and Chapters 15.08 through 15.16 of this municipal code. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or any order, rule or regulation made hereunder shall be subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. Each day an owner and/or contractor willfully violates a provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.200 - Disclaimer. 
    This chapter shall not be construed as lessening the responsibility or liability of any person who engages in any activity falling within the provisions of this chapter for damages to persons or property. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.210 - Appeals. 
    Any person, officer, department, board or bureau aggrieved by any decision of the administrative officers of the city under this chapter may obtain review of such determination under Chapter 1.12 of this municipal code. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.04.220 - Building contractor requirements-State certification or proof of insurance/bonding. 
A.  All building contractors required to be certified by the State of Wisconsin, per Chapter SPS 305, Wis. Adm. Code, must provide the city with proof of such certification prior to commencement of any building project within the city. 
B.  With the exception of an owner of a dwelling who resides or will reside in a single-family dwelling, all other building contractors unable to satisfy the requirements of subsection A of this section, including contractors for commercial projects which fall under Chapters SPS 361 to 365, Wis. Adm. Code., must provide the city with a completed building permit application and proof of general liability insurance (minimum of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00)) or surety bond (minimum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00)) prior to the commencement of any project within the city. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.04.230 - HVAC contractors-State certification required. 
    All HVAC contractors must be registered with the State of Wisconsin per Chapter SPS 305, Wis. Adm. code and provide the city with proof of such certification. 
    With the exception of an owner who currently resides in a single-family dwelling, all LIVAC work, including the installation and/or replacement of equipment and related duct work, shall be performed by a certified HVAC contractor. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
Chapter 15.08 - PLUMBING CODE 
Sections: 

15.08.010 - State regulations adopted. 
A.  Adopted by Reference. 
1.  Chapter 145, Wis. Stats., and the State Plumbing Code, SPS 381 to 387, Wis. Adm. Code, are adopted and by reference made a part of this chapter with the same force and effect as though set out in full. Failure to comply with any of the provisions of such regulations shall constitute a violation of this chapter, punishable as provided herein. 
2.  The city further emphasizes that backflow prevention pressure reducing values or similar state approved devices may be required by the city per the following reasons: 
a.  To prevent contamination of public water distribution systems; 
b.  To assure that adequate pressures are maintained in private water systems. 
B.  To Be on File. A copy of the State Plumbing Code shall be on file in the office of the building inspector. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 15.01) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.08.020 - Plumbing defined. 
    In this chapter, "plumbing" means and includes: 
A.  All piping, fixtures, appliances, equipment, devices and appurtenances in connection with the water supply, water distribution and drainage systems, including hot water storage tanks, water softeners and water heaters connected with such water and drainage systems and the installation thereof; 
B.  The construction, connection or installation of any drain or waste piping system from the outside or proposed outside foundation walls of any building to the mains or other sewerage system terminal within bounds of or beneath an area subject to easement for highway purposes, including private domestic sewage treatment and disposal systems, and the alteration of any such systems, drains or waste piping; 
C.  The water service piping from the outside or proposed outside foundation walls of any building to the main or other water utility service terminal within bounds of or beneath an area subject to easement for highway purposes and its connections; 
D.  The water pressure systems other than municipal systems as provided in Ch. 145, Wis. Stats.; 
E.  A plumbing and drainage system so designed and vent piping so installed as to keep the air within the system in free circulation and movement; to prevent with a margin of safety unequal air pressures of such force as might blow, siphon or affect trap seals or retard the discharge from plumbing fixtures or permit sewer air to escape into the building; to prohibit cross connection, contamination or pollution of the potable water supply and distribution systems; and to provide an adequate supply of water to properly serve, cleanse and operate all fixtures, equipment, appurtenances and appliances served by the plumbing system. 
(Ord. 2001-11 § 22; prior code § 15.02) 
15.08.030 - Enforcement. 
A.  General. The building inspector shall enforce all provisions of this chapter and all other state and city provisions relating to the construction, installation, alteration and repair of all plumbing within the city and shall make such inspections, perform such tests and issue such orders as may be necessary for such enforcement. 
B.  Authority to Enter Premises. 
1.  In the discharge of his or her duties, the building inspector or his or her authorized agent may enter any building, upon presentation of the proper credentials, during reasonable hours for the purpose of inspection and may require the production of any permit or license required hereunder. No person shall interfere with the supervisor or his or her authorized agent while in the performance of his or her duties; and any person so interfering shall be in violation of this chapter and subject to a penalty as provided by Chapter 1.20. 
2.  If consent to entry to personal or real properties which are not public buildings, or to portions of public buildings which are not open to the public, for inspection purposes has been denied, the Building Inspector shall obtain a special inspection warrant under Sections 66.0119(1), (2) and (3), Wis. Stats. 
C.  Permits. The building inspector or his or her authorized agent shall prepare suitable forms for permit applications and permits, shall take applications and issue to qualified applicants permits as required for all work contemplated by this chapter and shall maintain suitable records of the permits issued. He or she shall weekly submit permit fees collected by his or her office to the city treasurer. 
D.  Records and Reports. 
1.  To the City Council. The building inspector shall keep in his or her office a daily record of all the transactions of his or her office, including permits issued and fees received, and shall make such reports thereon to the city council as it may require. 
2.  To the Department of Health and Social Services. The building inspector shall make such reports to the Department of Health and Social Services as are required under Section 145.04(3), Wis. Stats. 
3.  Record of Special Locations. The building inspector shall insure that proper records are kept of all sewer and water connections and maps showing the locations of the same. 
E.  Stop Work Orders. The building inspector may order work stopped on the construction, installation, alteration or repair of plumbing when such work is being done in violation of this chapter. Work so stopped shall not be resumed except with written permission of the building inspector, provided if the stop work order is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written order within a reasonable period of time. 
F.  Inspections. It shall be the responsibility of the plumber in charge to notify the building inspector when work is ready for inspection as required in the State Plumbing Code. Failure to notify the building inspector shall be considered a violation of this chapter. (Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 15.03) 
15.08.040 - Plumbing permits. 
A.  Required. No work contemplated by this chapter shall be started until a permit therefor has been obtained from the building inspector or his or her authorized agent, provided no permit shall be required for minor repairs to faucets or the removal of stoppages in soil and waste pipes. 
B.  Application. The application shall be in writing upon forms which the plumbing supervisor shall provide and shall include the name of the owner and the description of the property on which the work is to be done, along with such pertinent information as the building inspector may require and shall state that the property owner and the applicant shall be bound by and subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
C.  Issuance, Term, Suspension and Revocation. When the building inspector is satisfied that the work proposed by the applicant can be done in conformity with the provisions of this chapter and after the appropriate fees have been paid to him or her, he or she shall issue the permit. Such permit shall be good for the continuous performance of the work named thereon. A permit shall automatically expire when work ceases for a period of sixty (60) days without good and reasonable cause for same and shall automatically expire on completion of the work for which it was issued; provided the building inspector may, upon notice, suspend or revoke such permit for violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
D.  Restrictions on Issuance. 
1.  No plumbing permit shall be issued to any person who is in violation of this chapter until such violation has been corrected. 
2.  No plumbing permit shall be issued to any person against whom an order issued by the building inspector is pending, provided this restriction may be waived by the building inspector. 
E.  Appeals For Failure to Issue-Suspension and Revocation. Any person directly interested who is aggrieved by the decision of the building inspector to refuse to issue a permit or to suspend or revoke such permit or to order work stopped under Section 15.08.030 may obtain review of such determination under Chapter 1.12 of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 15.04) 
15.08.050 - Plumbers to be licensed. 
    All plumbing work shall be done only by a plumber licensed by the state for such work, provided a property owner may make repairs or installations in a single-family building owned and occupied by him or her as his or her home if a permit therefor is issued and the work is done in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 15.05) 
15.08.060 - Registration of plumbers. 
A.  All plumbers must be licensed by the State of Wisconsin, per Ch. SPS 305, Wis. Adm. Code, and provide the city with proof of such state license and proof of general liability insurance (minimum of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00)) or surety bond (minimum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00)) prior to the commencement of any plumbing work within the city. 
B.  Registration Requirements Limited. The purpose of this section is solely to provide for the administration of state licensing requirements and this chapter. No fee shall be charged by the city for the plumber's registration nor is any further information than that in subsection A of this section required. 
(Ord. 1998-4 (part); prior code § 15.06) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
Chapter 15.12 - ELECTRICAL CODE 
Sections: 

15.12.010 - Purpose. 
    The object and purpose of this chapter is to safeguard persons and property from hazards arising from the use of electrical energy by establishing minimum standards for the installation and maintenance of electrical equipment. 
(Prior code § 16.01) 
15.12.020 - State code and regulations adopted. 
    All electrical work, including installations and alterations, shall conform to Ch. SPS 316, Wis. Adm. Code, and appropriate rules and regulations of the public service commission, which are by reference made a part of this chapter. A copy of the electrical code shall be kept on file in the office of the building inspector. Wisconsin Public Service Commission rules and regulations shall be on file in the municipal utilities office. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 16.02) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.12.030 - Permit. 
    No electrical wiring or other equipment shall be installed or altered without first securing a permit therefor from the building inspector, except that repairs or replacements of broken or defective sockets, switches or base receptacles may be made without a permit. The application for such permit shall be on a form furnished by the building inspector and shall state clearly the work planned, alterations to be made and equipment and materials to be used and all later deviations from such plans shall be submitted to and approved by the building inspector. 
(Prior code § 16.03) 
15.12.040 - Fees. 
    Fees for electric permits shall be as computed for permits in Section 15.04.030 of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 16.04) 
15.12.050 - Inspection of work. 
    After roughing in the wiring of any building and before any such work is covered up or upon completion of any outside wiring construction work, the person doing such work shall notify the building inspector who shall at once inspect the same. Upon completion of such wiring, the inspector shall be notified and shall inspect the finished work. Failure to notify the building inspector shall constitute a violation. No electrical equipment shall be used, except for temporary emergency use, until approved by the building inspector. If no inspection is made within forty-eight (48)hours, exclusive of holidays, Saturdays and Sundays, after notification, construction may be completed and the wiring covered up. 
(Prior code § 16.05) 
15.12.060 - Licenses. 
    All electrical contractors must be licensed by the State of Wisconsin, per Ch. SPS 305, Wis. Adm. Code, and must provide the city with proof of such state license prior to the commencement of any electrical work within the city. 
(Prior code § 16.06 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2018-07 , § 1, 6-26-2018) 
15.12.070 - Electrical contractors-State certification required. 
    All electricians engaged in the business of installing, altering or repairing any electrical wiring, fixtures or apparatus in the city must hold a license or certification as a licensed electrical contractor by the State of Wisconsin, per Ch. SPS 305.41, Wis. Adm. Code, and provide the city with proof of such state certification prior to the commencement of any electrical work within the city. 
(Ord. 1998-4 (part): prior code § 16.06(1)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016; Ord. No. 2018-07 , § 2, 6-26-2018) 
15.12.080 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-07 , § 3, adopted June 26, 2018, repealed § 15.12.080, which pertained to public liability insurance and derived from prior code § 16.08. 
15.12.090 - Affidavit requirement. 
    All qualified electricians or electrical firms performing any installation or alteration of electrical systems served by the city municipal electric utility shall upon completion of the work file an affidavit certifying that the work was performed by a qualified, licensed electrician and that the work completed conforms to Wisconsin State Electric Code, the Wisconsin Public Service Commission Utility Service Rules and to the municipal code. 
(Prior code § 16.09) 
15.12.100 - Inspections. 
A.  Dangerous Wires or Equipment. Whenever the building inspector finds wires or equipment in a dangerous condition or so placed as to interfere with the work of the fire department, he or she may order the persons using or operating the same to place them in a safe and non-interfering condition within forty-eight (48) hours and on failure to comply with such order or direction, the inspector shall order such wires disconnected. Failure to comply with such orders shall constitute a violation of this chapter. Any person who resists or obstructs any lawful exercise of authority by the inspector shall be subject to the penalty provided in this chapter. 
B.  Right of Entry. The building inspector shall have the authority to enter any building or premises at any reasonable hour in the discharge of his or her duties. He or she shall also have the authority to enter any building used in whole or in part for the purpose of public assemblage when occupied by the public or at any time in order to examine electrical equipment in such building. 
(Prior code § 16.10) 
15.12.110 - Interpretation. 
    This chapter shall not be construed to relieve or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person supplying electricity to or selling, renting, leasing, owning, using, operating, controlling, installing, altering, repairing, removing, replacing, disturbing, connecting, disconnecting or maintaining any electrical equipment for damage to persons or property caused by any defect therein or therefrom; nor by reason of the issuance of or revocation of any permit or the inspection or reinspection authorized by this chapter or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any electrical equipment, sales, rentals, drawings, plans, specifications, materials, samples, test reports, literature, information or schedules authorized in this chapter. Nor shall the city be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of this chapter. Any act done by any person appointed to carry out the duties or obligations under this chapter or their representatives shall be given the same rights, immunities and privileges as the city. 
(Prior code § 16.11) 
Chapter 15.16 - HOUSING CODE 
Sections: 

15.16.010 - Purpose. 
    Since there are or may be in the future dwelling structures which are so dilapidated, unsafe, dangerous, unhygienic, or unsanitary as to constitute a menace to the health and safety of the people of this city, this chapter is enacted for the following purposes: 
A.  To establish minimum standards governing supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to make rental dwellings safe, sanitary and fit for human habitation. These minimum standards shall also include all standards covered by Chapters 15.04 through 15.12; 
B.  To fix certain responsibilities of owners and occupants of dwellings and the condemnation of dwellings unfit for human habitation; 
C.  To coordinate the activities and functions of the code enforcement officer and health officer of the city; 
D.  To fix penalties for violations and a time when the same shall take effect. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter, except that whenever the words "dwelling," "dwelling unit," "rooming house," "rooming unit" or "premises" are used in this chapter, they shall be construed as though they were followed by the words "or a part thereof." 
    "Basement" means that portion of a dwelling below the first floor or ground floor with its entire floor below grade. 
    "Code enforcement officer" means the authorized representative of the city, certified by the state of Wisconsin, or his or her authorized representative. 
    "Dwelling" means a building or portion thereof, including a trailer or mobilehome, designed or used exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family and multiple-family dwelling units, but not including motels, hotels or temporary housing. 
    "Dwelling unit" means a structure, or that part of a structure, which is used or intended to be used as a home, residence, or sleeping place. 
    "Efficiency apartment" means a dwelling unit with minimal kitchen and bath facilities and whose habitable areas are not separated by walls. The tenant occupancy limit for an efficiency unit is determined per the requirements of Section 15.16.080(A). 
    "Extermination" means the control and elimination of insects, rodents or other pests by eliminating their harborage places by removing or making inaccessible materials which may serve as their food by poisoning, spraying, fumigating, trapping or by other recognized and legal pest elimination methods. 
    "Family" means two or more persons related by blood or marriage. 
    "Fraternity," for the purposes of the housing code, is considered to be under the requirements of a rooming house, as approved by the State Commercial Code. 
    "Garbage" means solid animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the domestic and commercial handling, preparation, cooking, and dispensing or consumption of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    "Grandfathered," for the purposes of this code section, means any dwelling used for rental purposes prior to October 12, 1972, the effective date of the city municipal housing code. 
    "Guest" means a temporary invitee residing in a dwelling unit for a period up to, but not exceeding, fourteen (14) days within any three month period. The tenant(s) shall be liable for any property damage, waste, or neglect caused by the negligence or improper use of the premises. 
    "Habitable room" means any room used for sleeping, living, or dining purposes, excluding such enclosed spaces as kitchens, closets, pantries, bath or toilet rooms, hallways, laundries, storage spaces, utility rooms, and similar spaces. 
    "Health officer" means the health officer of the city or his or her authorized representative. 
    "Infestation" means the presence within or around a dwelling of any insects or rodents. 
    "License" means a written formal permit which gives authorization to the holder thereof. 
    "Manufactured dwelling" means any structure or component thereof which is intended for use as a dwelling and is of closed construction and is fabricated or assembled on site or off site in manufacturing facilities for installation, connection, or assembly and installation at a building site or is a building of open construction which is fabricated or assembled in manufacturing facilities away from the building site for installation, connection, or assembly and installation on the building site and for which certification is sought by the manufacturer. 
    "Mobilehome" means a prefabricated unit with walls of rigid construction that is designed to be towed as a single unit or in sections upon a highway by a motor vehicle and that is used or intended to be used for human habitation. 
    "Multiple dwelling" means a dwelling designed and approved for and containing three or more dwelling units. 
    "Occupant" means any person living in or having actual possession of a dwelling unit or rooming unit. 
    "Owner" means any individual, firm, association, co-partnership, corporation, trust, or any other legal entity who alone, jointly, or severally with others, holds sufficient proprietary interest. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, trust, partnership, public or private, association or corporation, company, organization, municipality, joint stock company, society, group, joint venture, unincorporated association, county or state agency within Wisconsin, the federal government or any combination thereof. 
    "Plumbing" means piping, fixtures, appliances, appurtenances, devices and systems as defined in State Statutes. 
    Refuse. (See "Garbage.") 
    "Rental income" means payment or other considerations, including but not limited to, house-sitting, baby-sitting, elderly care, housework, lawn care, and general maintenance. Exceptions must be reviewed and approved by the city attorney and the code enforcement officer. 
    "Rooming unit" means a single room, rented as sleeping and living quarters, without cooking facilities or eating purposes, and with, or without, an individual bathroom. In a suite of rooms without cooking facilities, each room which provides sleeping accommodations shall be counted as one rooming unit. 
    "Rooming house" means a dwelling approved under Ch. COMM 57, Wis. Adm. Code or any grandfathered dwelling containing six or more rooming units which are let for pay or other considerations. It is intended that fraternities, cooperatives, communes, or other unchartered groups of people be included under this definition. For the purposes of this code, any grandfathered dwelling with five or less roomers will be categorized as a single-family dwelling unit. 
    "Rubbish" means combustible or noncombustible waste materials, except garbage, and shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke and other combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood excelsior, rubber, leather, tree branches, yard trimmings, leaves, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass, crockery or dust. 
    "Supplies" means paid for, furnished or provided by or under the control of the owner or manager. 
    "Temporary housing" means any tent, trailer or other structure used for human shelter which is designed to be transportable and which is not attached to the ground, to another structure or to any utilities system on the same premises for more than thirty (30) consecutive days. 
    Trash. (See "Rubbish.") 
    "Voluntary inspection" means an inspection, completed by a code enforcement officer, upon the request of a potential owner of a property which is not currently licensed by the city for rental purposes, for adherence to the current municipal housing code. Upon taking ownership, all noted corrections must be completed within thirty (30) days, or a time period determined by the code enforcement officer, as part of the requirements for obtaining a housing license. 
(Ord. 2008-20 §§ 1, 2; amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.030 - Inspection of dwellings, dwelling units, rooming units and premises. 
    The code enforcement officer shall determine the condition of dwellings, dwelling units and premises located within the city in order that he or she may perform his or her duty of safeguarding the health and safety of the occupants of dwellings and the general public. For the purpose of making such inspections, the code enforcement officer may enter, examine and survey at proper times, upon receipt of verbal authorization to or after twelve (12) hours notice to the owner and/or occupant, all dwelling units, rooming units and premises. The owner and/or occupant of every dwelling unit and rooming unit or the person in charge shall give the code enforcement officer access to such dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit and its premises at reasonable times after due notice for the purpose of each inspection, examination and survey. Every occupant of a dwelling unit or dwelling shall give the owner thereof or his or her agent or employee access to any part of such dwelling or dwelling unit or its premises at all reasonable times for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.040 - Enforcement. 
A.  Notice of Violation. Whenever the code enforcement officer or health officer determines that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter, he or she shall give notice of such violation to the person or persons responsible therefor and to any known agent of such person as therein after provided. Such notice shall: 
1.  Note, in writing, the violation(s) that exist; 
2.  Allow a reasonable time, up to thirty (30) days, as determined by the code enforcement officer, for the performance of any act it requires. 
    An extension may be granted at the discretion of the code enforcement officer if substantial progress towards compliance has been documented; 
3.  Be served upon the owner or his or her agent, or the occupant, as the case may require; provided that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served if a copy thereof is served upon any of the above personally or if a copy is sent by registered mail to his or her last known address or if a copy is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by the notice or if he or she is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required under the laws of this state. 
4.  Such notice shall contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, shall affect compliance with the provision of this chapter. 
B.  Hearing. Any person affected by any such notice issued by the code enforcement officer or health officer may request, and shall be granted, a hearing in the matter as provided in Chapter 1.12 of this code. 
C.  Emergency Orders. Whenever the code enforcement officer or health officer finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health or safety, he or she may without notice or hearing, issue an order reciting the existence of such an emergency and require that such action be taken as he or she deems necessary to meet the emergency. Notwithstanding the other provisions of this chapter, such order shall be effective immediately. 
D.  All HVAC work and construction projects requiring a building permit must be completed by certified contractors per Section 15.04.230. 
E.  All plumbing work shall be performed by a licensed plumber per Section 15.08.050. 
    Exception. The repair or replacement of faucets and fixtures may be completed by the owner or occupant. 
F.  All electrical work shall be performed by a licensed electrician per Section 15.12.070. 
    Exception. The replacement of electrical outlets and light fixtures may be completed by the owner or occupant. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.050 - Minimum standards for basic equipment and facilities. 
    No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking or eating therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
A.  Every dwelling unit shall contain a kitchen sink in good working condition and properly connected to a water and sanitary sewer system approved by the State Plumbing Inspector and/or code enforcement officer. 
B.  Every dwelling unit shall contain a room with its walls, separate from the habitable room or rooms, which affords privacy and security to a person within and which is equipped with a flush water closet, a lavatory basin and a bathtub or shower and the necessary fixtures and accessories therefor in good working condition and properly connected to hot and cold water lines and sanitary sewer system approved by the code enforcement officer. 
C.  Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with adequate rubbish and garbage storage facilities that are structurally sound and have tight fitting covers. Number and size shall be as follows: 
1.  One and two-family residences shall have containers, as specified by Chapter 8.26 of this municipal code, in sufficient number to adequately store the rubbish and garbage generated without spillage. 
2.  Multiple-family residences shall have container space available equal to or greater than 0.4 cubic yards (eighty (80) gallons) per dwelling unit. 
3.  Other uses shall be supplied with rubbish and garbage storage facilities of adequate size and number such that the rubbish and garbage generated can be stored with covers closed and without spillage. 
4.  The code enforcement officer or health officer may require greater storage requirements than those stated herein if, in his or her judgment, the minimum requirements as stated prove to be inadequate in specific instances. 
D.  Every dwelling unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level as defined by the Wis. Adm. Code. 
E.  All bedrooms or rooming units shall have at least one operable door or window or which opens to the outdoors. The window shall allow a clear opening of twenty (20) inches by twenty-four (24) inches for egress or rescue. The window sill shall be within forty-six (46) inches of the floor and the window sash and storm/screen shall be openable from the inside without the use of tools, the removal of the sash, or special knowledge. 
1.  If an existing window is used to meet the egress requirement, and the sill does not meet the maximum allowable height above the floor of forty-six (46) inches, an approved permanent step(s) must be provided below the window. 
2.  If the door or window is located below grade, an approved areaway shall be installed. 
3.  Coverings that prevent rain and snow from entering the areaway are allowable as long as egress or rescue can be achieved without the use of separate tools or special knowledge. 
F.  Hot Water Requirements. Every dwelling unit shall be supplied with water heating facilities which are installed in an approved manner, properly maintained and capable of heating water to such a temperature as to permit an adequate amount of water to be drawn at every required kitchen sink, lavatory basin, bathtub, shower and laundry facility or other similar units at a temperature of not less than one hundred ten (110) degrees and no greater than one hundred twenty-five (125) degrees per the Ch. SPS 382, Wis. Adm. Code and Ch. 704, Wis. Stats. 
G.  Minimum Number of Electrical Outlets and/or Fixtures per Room. 
1.  Every habitable room of a dwelling unit shall contain at least three separate and remote outlets. A wall switched light fixture may be counted as one of the three required outlets. 
2.  Every public hall, bathroom, laundry room or furnace room shall contain at least one electric outlet in addition to a light fixture. 
3.  Every furnace/mechanical room shall be provided with a light fixture. 
H.  Screen Requirements. From May 1st to October 1st every door opening directly from a dwelling unit to outdoor space, shall have supplied and installed screens and a self-closing device and every window or other device with openings to outdoor space, used or intended to be used for ventilation shall likewise be supplied with screens installed. 
I.  Smoke Detectors. Any building occupied for sleeping purposes shall have smoke detectors installed and maintained in accordance with Section 15.04.160. 
    No unauthorized person shall tamper with, alter, or remove any detector, fire extinguisher, fire apparatus, or alarm from any building or unit required by Section 15.04.160, except for necessary testing or maintenance. 
J.  Building Numbering Required. All buildings in the city shall be numbered in accordance with Section 15.04.170. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
15.16.060 - Minimum standards for light, ventilation and heating. 
    No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein, which does not comply with the following requirements: 
A.  Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight facing directly to the outdoors. The minimum total window area, measured between stops, for every habitable room shall be eight percent of the floor area of such room. 
B.  Every habitable room shall have at least one window or skylight which can be easily opened. The total clear opening window area in every habitable room shall be equal to not less than three and a half percent of the floor area. 
    Habitable rooms, other than bedrooms, without openable windows, may be provided with a balanced mechanical ventilation system producing one air change per hour of fresh outside air while the room is occupied. 
C.  Every bathroom and water closet compartment shall have five percent clear opening window or skylight area except that no window or skylight shall be required in bathrooms and water closet compartments equipped with a mechanical ventilation system as defined in the Wis. Adm. Code. 
D.  Every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are properly installed and maintained, and are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms, bathrooms and water closet compartments in every dwelling unit located therein to a temperature of at least seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit at a distance of thirty (30) inches above floor level under ordinary minimum winter conditions. 
E.  Every public hall and stairway in every rental unit shall be lighted in conformity with the National Electrical Code. 
F.  Every basement bedroom shall receive natural light and shall be ventilated according to Wis. Adm. Code standards. Every basement or cellar window used or intended to be used for ventilation and every other opening to a basement which might provide an entry for rodents or insects shall be supplied with a screen or such other device as will effectively prevent their entrance. 
G.  All HVAC work, including the installation of new or replacement heating or cooling equipment, associated electrical or plumbing work, and the installation of new or replacement duct-work shall be performed by an HVAC contractor credentialed by the state of Wisconsin. 
    Changing of filters or grilles may be performed by the owner or occupants. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.070 - General requirements relating to the safe and sanitary maintenance of parts of dwellings and dwelling units. 
    No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the following: 
A.  Every foundation, floor, wall, ceiling and roof shall be reasonably weather tight, watertight and rodent proof, shall be capable of affording privacy and security and shall be kept in good repair. 
B.  Every window, skylight, exterior door and basement hatchway shall be reasonably weather tight, watertight, secure, and rodent proof and shall be kept in sound working condition and good repair. 
C.  Every inside and outside stair, every porch, corridor and every appurtenance thereto shall be so constructed as to support eighty (80) pounds per square feet in commercial applications and forty (40) pounds per square feet in one-and-two family applications. 
D.  Every plumbing fixture and waste water pipe shall be properly installed and maintained in good sanitary working condition, free from defects, leaks and obstructions. 
E.  Every water closet compartment floor surface and bathroom floor surface shall be constructed and maintained to be impervious to water and to permit such floor to be easily kept in clean and sanitary condition. 
F.  Every appliance, or facility, piece of equipment, or utility which is required under this chapter, or supplied by the landlords, shall be so constructed or installed as to function safely and effectively and shall be maintained in satisfactory working condition. 
G.  No owner, manager, or occupant shall cause any service facility, equipment or utility which is required under this chapter to be removed from or shut off from or discontinued for any occupied dwelling let or occupied by him or her except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repair or alterations are in progress or during temporary emergencies or when discontinuance of service is approved by the code enforcement officer or health officer. 
H.  No owner shall let to any other occupant any vacant dwelling unit unless it is clean, sanitary, and fit for human occupancy.
