(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.080 - Minimum space and occupancy requirements. 
    No person shall let to another for occupancy any dwelling or dwelling unit, for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the following requirements: 
A.  Every dwelling unit shall contain a minimum gross floor area of not less than one hundred fifty (150) square feet for the first occupant, one hundred (100) square feet for the second occupant, and seventy-five (75) square feet for each additional occupant. The floor area shall be calculated on the basis of the total area of all habitable rooms. 
B.  In every dwelling unit of two or more habitable rooms, every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain at least eighty (80) square feet of floor space. Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one occupant shall contain at least forty (40) square feet of additional floor space for each occupant over twelve (12) years and at least an additional thirty (30) square feet of additional floor space for each occupant under twelve (12) years. 
1.  Exception. The occupancy for efficiency apartments shall be determined per the requirements of subsection A of this section. 
C.  At least one-half of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of a least seven feet and the floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area in computing the total floor area of the room for the purpose of determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof. 
D.  No "dwelling unit," as defined in Section 15.16.020, shall be occupied by more than one of the following: 
1.  One "family" as defined in Section 15.16.020, provided that the family does not exceed the maximum allowable occupants as determined under and subject to subsections A and B, above. 
2.  In an R-1 zoning district, up to four unrelated persons as determined under and subject to subsections A and B, above. 
3.  In all other zoning districts, up to five unrelated persons as determined under and subject to subsections A and B, above. 
(Ord. 2008-20 §§ 3, 4; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.090 - Responsibilities of owners and occupants. 
A.  Every owner of a dwelling unit shall be responsible for maintaining, in a clean and sanitary condition, the shared or public area of the dwelling and premises thereof. 
B.  Every owner of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall be responsible for hanging all screens whenever the same are required under provisions of this chapter or of any rule or regulation adopted pursuant thereto, except where the occupant has agreed to supply such service. 
C.  Every owner of a dwelling containing a single dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents or other pests therein or on the premises and every occupant of a dwelling unit in a dwelling containing more than one dwelling unit shall be responsible for such extermination whenever his or her dwelling unit is the only one infested. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this subsection, whenever infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a rodent proof or reasonable insect proof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner. 
D.  Every owner shall be responsible for providing furnace filters. The owner shall also be responsible for the periodic changing of the filters, except where the tenant has agreed to supply such service. 
E.  Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall keep in a clean and sanitary condition that part of the dwelling, dwelling unit and premises thereof which he occupies and controls. 
F.  Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the rubbish container required by Section 15.16.050. 
G.  Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall dispose of all his garbage and any other organic waste which might provide food for rodents in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in the garbage disposal facilities or garbage storage containers required by Section 15.16.050. 
1.  The owner shall supply such facilities or containers for all rooming units located on the premises. 
2.  In all other cases the occupant shall furnish such facilities or containers. 
H.  Every occupant of a dwelling unit shall keep all plumbing fixtures therein in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be responsible for the exercise of reasonable care in the proper use and operation thereof. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.100 - Rooming houses. 
    No person shall operate a rooming house or shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any rooming unit in any rooming house, except in compliance with the provisions of every section of this chapter. 
A.  At least one flush water closet, lavatory basin and bathtub or shower properly connected to a water and sanitary sewer system approved by the State Plumbing Inspector or the code enforcement officer, shall be supplied for each six persons or fraction thereof residing within a rooming house established prior to October 12, 1972, including members of the operator's family wherever they share the use of such facilities. 
1.  In a rooming house where rooms are let only to males, tank system urinals of the floor resting type fixtures may be substituted for not more than one-half of the required number of water closets. 
2.  All such facilities shall be so located within the dwelling to be accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities. 
B.  When bed linen is furnished, the manager of every rooming house shall furnish clean bed linen and towels at least once a week and prior to the letting of any room to any occupant. The manager shall be responsible for the maintenance of supplied bedding in a clean and sanitary manner. 
C.  The occupant capacity for each individual sleeping area within a rooming house shall be determined per the requirements of Section 15.16.080(B)(2). 
    In a rooming house established prior to October 12, 1972, the occupant capacity for every room occupied for sleeping purposes shall be determined per the requirements of Section 15.16.080(B). 
D.  Every rooming unit shall have safe, unobstructed means of egress leading to safe and open space at ground level as required per Section 15.16.050. 
E.  The owner of every rooming house shall be responsible for the sanitary maintenance of all walls, floors and ceilings and for maintenance of a sanitary condition in every other part of the rooming house and the entire premises. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.110 - Rental dwelling unit permit application and fee schedule. 
A.  No owner shall operate a dwelling unit producing rental income unless he or she holds a valid permit, issued by the city, in his or her name and for the specific dwelling unit. The owner or his or her authorized agent shall apply to the office of the community development department for a permit. 
B.  The application shall contain the following information: 
1.  Name of the property owner; 
2.  Address of the rental property; 
3.  Address of the owner if different from the property; 
4.  Name of the manager/caretaker if applicable; 
5.  The work and home phone number of the owner and of the manager/caretaker if applicable; 
6.  Number of units within the building; 
7.  Provide an address where all correspondence to the permit may be forwarded. The rental property address, unless written notice is otherwise given to the city, shall be considered the address of the permit and all mail forwarded to the permit at such address shall be conclusive as to its receipt by the permit. 
C.  After an application has been filled out and the fee is paid the city shall then issue a permit. The permit year shall commence on January 1, and shall end on the following January 31, and shall be renewed annually. 
D.  The permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within the dwelling at all times. 
E.  The city shall be promptly notified of any changes in the names, addresses, and other information concerning the persons listed in the last housing permit application. The owner of any dwelling which is required to be permitted by this chapter shall, prior to the time of sale of the dwelling, notify the buyer in writing of all unabated orders and outstanding violations which have been noticed by the city, as well as the ordinance requirement that the dwelling, upon acquisition by a new owner, must be permitted by the city. A copy of the notification shall be mailed to the city within five days of furnishing the notification to the buyer. If a corporation owns the dwelling, an officer of the corporation shall carry out the notification required by this section. If more than one person owns the property, a notification by one of the owners shall satisfy this section. For the purposes of this section, "time of sale" shall be construed to mean when a written purchase agreement is executed by the buyer or, in the absence of a purchase agreement, upon the execution of any document providing for the conveyance of a dwelling requiring to be permitted. 
F.  Fee Schedule. The fee schedule for new and renewal permits shall be approved by the common council and shall be on file with the city clerk. The permit fee shall be prerequisite to issuance of each permit. 
G.  Rental housing types are as follows: 
1.  Single-family; 
2.  Manufactured home/mobile home; 
3.  Duplex; 
4.  Townhome; 
5.  Twinhome; 
6.  Condominium; 
7.  Rooming house; 
8.  Fraternities; 
9.  Multifamily apartments; 
10.  Home with apartments (existing nonconformance). This describes grandfathered dwellings with two or more apartments. 
H.  Transfer Fee. This fee shall be in accordance with the current rental permit fee schedule on file in the community development department. 
I.  Inspection Fee. The fee for conducting an inspection on a property, for the purpose of determining compliance with the housing code, shall be charged according to the current fee schedule. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, § 1, 7-13-2010) 
15.16.120 - Designation of unfit dwellings and legal procedure for condemnation. 
    The designation of dwellings or dwelling units as unfit for human habitation and the procedure for the condemnation and placarding of such shall be carried out in compliance with the following requirements: 
A.  Any dwelling or dwelling unit which is found to have any of the following defects, but not limited to, shall be condemned as unfit for human habitation and shall be so designated and placarded by the code enforcement officer or the health officer: 
1.  One which is so damaged, decayed, dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe or vermin infested that it creates a serious hazard to the health or safety of the occupants or of the public; 
2.  One which lacks illumination, ventilation or sanitary facilities adequate to protect the health or safety of the occupants or of the public; 
3.  One which because of its general condition or location is unsanitary or otherwise dangerous to the health or safety of occupants or of the public. 
B.  Any dwelling or dwelling unit condemned as unfit for human habitation and so designated and placarded by the code enforcement officer or health officer shall be vacated within thirty (30) day or less, as determined by the code enforcement officer or health officer. 
    No person shall deface or remove the placard from any dwelling or dwelling unit which has been condemned as unfit for human habitation and placarded as such, except as provided in subsection C of this section. 
C.  No dwelling or dwelling unit which has been condemned and placarded as unfit for human habitation shall again be used for human habitation until written approval is secured from, and such placard is removed by, the code enforcement officer or health officer. The code enforcement officer or health officer shall remove such placard whenever the defect or defects upon which the condemnation and placarding action were based have been eliminated. 
D.  Any person affected by any notice or order relating to the condemning and placarding of a dwelling or dwelling unit as unfit for human habitation may request and shall receive a hearing before the board of appeals under the procedure set forth in Section 15.16.040 of this chapter. 
E.  Nothing herein shall be construed as conflicting in any way with appropriate codes of the state and wherever such conflict exists, the more restrictive code shall apply. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.130 - Equal rights of all persons to fair and open housing. 
A.  The city council adopts Section 106.50, Wisconsin Statutes, as amended, and all subsequent amendments thereto. 
B.  The officials and employees of the city shall assist in the orderly prevention and removal of all discrimination in housing within the city by implementing the authority and enforcement procedures set forth in Section 106.50, Wisconsin Statutes, as amended. 
C.  The city clerk shall maintain forms for complaints to be filed under Section 106.50, Wisconsin Statutes, as amended, and shall assist any person alleging a violation thereof in the city to file a complaint thereunder with the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development, Equal Rights Division for enforcement of Section 106.50, Wisconsin Statutes, as amended. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1999-12: Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.140 - Disclosure. 
    Pursuant to Ch. 709, Wis. Stats., the owner of a rental property shall disclose all orders to repair, alter, or correct outstanding violations of this chapter and Chapters 15.04 through 15.12 of this municipal code. (Amended during Supplement #1; Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
15.16.150 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Except as otherwise provided, any person violating any of the terms of this chapter shall forfeit not less than one hundred dollars ($100) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200), together with the costs of prosecution; provided that for any violation(s) of any condition in this chapter which can be corrected by modification or repair, failure to correct or rectify such defect within a reasonable time, as determined by the code enforcement officer or health officer, shall constitute a separate violation for each day in which the violations exists, and be subject to penalties herein provided. If any licensee continues to operate rental property after suspension or revocation of the license, each day of operation during that period shall be considered a separate violation of this chapter. 
    The code enforcement officer may revoke, suspend, terminate, or discontinue any housing license, or may refuse to issue, reissue, or renew any housing license which has been or may be issued under this chapter if the owner of the concerned premises has any taxes, assessments, forfeitures, or any other claims of the city that are delinquent or unpaid as determined by the city clerk. 
(Ord. 1998-20 (part)) 
Chapter 15.20 - CERTIFICATES OF COMPLIANCE 
Sections: 

15.20.010 - Purpose. 
    The city council deems it to be in the public interest and in keeping with the health, safety and welfare of the citizens and inhabitants of the city to require the issuance of a certificate of compliance certifying that the holder of a building permit, or the subdivider of any lands within the corporate jurisdiction of the city, has complied with all applicable local code provisions and has completed all improvements required by the local code. 
(Prior code § 12.17(1)) 
15.20.020 - Certificate required. 
    The holder of any building permit issued in accordance with Chapter 15.04 of this municipal code, or the subdivider of any land within the corporate jurisdiction of the city who has been granted the necessary approvals for the development of the subdivision, shall obtain, at the completion of the project, a certificate of compliance from the building inspector of the city which shall certify that the constructed improvements comply and are in conformity with all applicable provisions of this municipal code. At the request of the holder of the building permit, or at the request of the subdivider, the building inspector, accompanied by support staff as he or she may deem necessary to make a determination, shall inspect the premises for the purpose of determining total compliance with the applicable provisions of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 12.17(2)) 
15.20.030 - Effect of certificate. 
    The issuance of the certificate of compliance shall be prima facie evidence of compliance with all applicable provisions of this municipal code, and shall entitle the holder of the certificate to immediate occupancy of the premises and the conduct of business thereon. Failure to obtain a certificate of compliance shall prohibit the subdivider or owner of the premises from conducting business operations on the premises, leasing or occupying the premises and, in the case of subdividers, shall prohibit the construction of any structures within the subdivision; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prohibit an owner from carrying on regularly conducted business or occupancy of the premises that was being conducted or occupied prior to the issuance of the building permit, during the period of construction. 
(Prior code § 12.17(3)) 
15.20.040 - Extensions. 
    If the holder of the building permit of a previously conducted business or previously occupied premises fails to secure a certificate of compliance within the time limitations of the building permit because of inadequate code compliance, the building inspector shall notify such owner or occupant in writing of the deficiencies, and grant a reasonable time to rectify the deficiencies, not to exceed one year, such that a certificate may be issued. Failure to so comply will allow the city to avail itself of the remedies contained in Section 15.20.030. 
(Prior code § 12.17(4)) 
15.20.050 - Penalties not exclusive. 
    The penalties contained in this chapter shall be in addition to any other penalties contained in this municipal code that apply to specific violations. 
(Prior code § 12.17(5)) 
15.20.060 - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision of the administrative officers of the city under this chapter, or who fails to secure a certificate of compliance within any extension period granted under Section 15.20.040, may obtain review of such determination under Chapter 1.12 of this municipal code. 
(Prior code § 12.17(6)) 
Title 16 - SUBDIVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 16.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS, ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

16.04.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this title is to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the community, to lessen congestion in the streets and highways; to further the orderly layout and use of land; to secure safety from fire and other dangers; to provide adequate light and air; to avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate provision for transportation, water, sewerage, schools, parks, playgrounds and other public requirements; and to facilitate the further resubdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. These regulations are made with reasonable consideration, among other things, of the character of the city with the view of conserving the value of the buildings placed upon land, providing the best possible environment for human habitation and for encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the city. 
(Prior code § 18.01) 
16.04.020 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in this title: 
    "Act of division" means the division of a lot or parcel of land into two or more parcels. 
    "Alley" means a public right-of-way shown on a plat which serves only a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Bikeway" means a general term describing any of the following defined types of facilities used for bikes: 
1.  "Bike path" means a paved area completely separated from the roadway designed for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
2.  "Bike lane" means a striped portion of the roadway reserved for bicycles which separates motorists from bicyclists. 
    "Certified survey map" means a map or plan which has been prepared by a registered land surveyor in accord with all of the requirements of Section 236.34, Wis. Stats., and this title. 
    "City council" means the city council of River Falls. 
    "Comprehensive plan" means the comprehensive plan adopted by the city of River Falls in accord with Section 66.1001, Wis. Stats., together with any and all amendments thereto as adopted from time to time by the common council. 
    "Dead-end" street or streets begin at the point where a public street or public streets can be accessed by travel on only a singular segment of public street. Any intersection shall be considered a singular segment of public street. 

Figure 16.04a: Dead Ends 
1.  "Permanent dead end" means that the current official map for the city does not include a public street planned for future construction that, if built, would result in changing the street's designation as a dead end. 
2.  "Temporary dead end" means that the current official map for the city includes a public street planned for future construction that, if built, would result in changing the street's designation as a dead end. 

Figure 16.04b: Permanent and Temporary Dead End 
    "Division of land" means the process of creating two or more lots, or parcels of land from one or more preexisting lot, parcel or tract of land. 
    "Driveway" means a vehicle access from private property to a public street. 
    "Extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction" means the unincorporated area within one and a half miles of the incorporated city limits of the city. 
    "Extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction" means the unincorporated area within three miles of the incorporated city limits of the city. 
    "Master plan" means the comprehensive plan for guiding and shaping the growth and development of the city's community area, including all of the component parts, as prepared by the plan commission and certified to the city council. 
    "Minor subdivision" means a division of land which creates no more than four lots or parcels of land. 
    "Official map" means the map indicating the location, width and extent of existing and proposed streets, highways, parkways, parks and playgrounds as adopted by the city council. 
    "Outlot" means a parcel of land other than a buildable lot or block, so designated on the subdivision plat or certified survey map, which is used to convey or reserve parcels of land. Outlots may be created to restrict a lot which is unbuildable due to high groundwater, steep slope equal to or greater than twenty (20) percent, or other physical constraints or to create common open space. Outlots may also be parcels of land intended to be converted to lots, redivided into lots or combined with lots or outlots in adjacent land divisions in the future for the purpose of creating buildable lots. An outlot shall not be used as a buildable lot unless it meets the design standards of the subdivision ordinance and has been converted to a lot through the subdivision process. 
    "Plan commission" means the city plan commission. 
    "Plat" means a map of a subdivision but does not include a subdivision by means of a certified survey map. 
    "Preliminary plat" means a map showing the necessary features of a proposed subdivision submitted to the plan commission and other approving agencies for preliminary consideration. 
    "Replat and resubdivision" means the process of changing or the map which changes the boundaries of a recorded plat or a part thereof. 
    "Resubdivision" means any further subdivision of land which occurs after an initial division or a redivision of land previously divided which, in accord with Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., and this title is subject to approval as a subdivision of land. 
    "Street" means a public way for vehicular traffic whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, thruway, road, avenue, boulevard, lane, place or however otherwise designated. 
    Street, Public. "Public streets" shall meet one of the following requirements: 
1.  Streets within right-of-way that have previously been platted as public right-of-way; 
2.  Streets within right-of-way that will be platted as public right-of-way in the plat under consideration; or 
3.  Proposed streets that have been adopted as part of the official map. 
    Streets, Arterial. "Arterial streets" means those streets which provide for rapid movement of concentrated volumes of traffic over relatively long distances, including, but not limited to: 
1.  "Freeways and expressways" means streets or highways which provide the major interstate and interregional traffic corridors and provide the highest mobility level and a high degree of access control. 
2.  "Principal arterials" means a road intended to move through traffic to and from major traffic generators such as central business districts, colleges or universities, major industrial areas or as a route for traffic between communities, and which accommodates a high degree of mobility with a high degree of access control. 
3.  "Minor arterials" means a road intended to collect and distribute traffic in a manner that is designed to serve minor traffic generating areas such as neighborhood commercial areas, educational facilities, hospitals, major recreational facilities, churches or designed to carry traffic from collector streets to principal arterials. 
    Streets, Collector. "Collector streets" means streets intended to move traffic from local streets to arterial streets. These streets provide moderate speed movement and serve a direct route between activity centers. 
    Streets, Local. "Local streets" means streets designed for low speeds and low volumes which provide access from low traffic generating areas to collectors and arterial systems. Local streets generally provide direct access to private property. 
1.  "Cul-de-sac" means a street closed at one end with a turn-around. A street shall be considered closed at one end if the public street does not continue on for through traffic. A cul-de-sac shall be that portion of a street from the closed end to the nearest intersection with a public street that provides two or more alternative directions of travel. 

Figure 16.04c: Cul-de-Sacs 
2.  "Frontage roads" means roads or streets parallel and adjacent to arterial streets which provide access to abutting properties and separation from through traffic. 
    "Subdivision" for the purpose of these regulations, means the division of land within the city limits into such number of lots or parcels as are controlled by this chapter and Chapter 16.08, below. Within the extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction it shall be the division of land into such number of lots or parcels and of such minimum sizes as are expressed in Chapter 16.10, below. 
    Subdivision, Minor. "Minor subdivision" means a subdivision which may create not more than four parcels of building sites, each of which is five acres or smaller in size or the division of a block or outlot within a recorded subdivision plat into not more than four parcels or building sites that does not change the original exterior boundaries of such block or outlot. 
    Survey, Plat of. "Plat of survey" means the division of a lot or property which does not create a new building site and which is intended to transfer or convey a portion of a lot to an adjoining lot or property. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 1; Ord. 1999-6; prior code § 18.02) 
(Ord. 2009-9, § 1, 8-25-09) 
16.04.030 - Exemptions. 
    No plat or certified survey map shall be required in any of the following instances: 
A.  The conveyance of parcels of land or interests therein for use as right-of-way for railroads or other public utility facilities which does not include the creation of any new streets or easements of access; 
B.  The conveyance of land owned by a railroad or other public utility which does not involve the creation of new streets or easements of access, limited, however, to circumstances in which such a conveyance is not intended for the creation of a new lot or parcel for building or development purposes. With respect to such a conveyance, the city may require that there be appended to its legal description a covenant in favor of the public prohibiting its use for building or development purposes; 
C.  The conveyance of land for highway or other public purposes, grants or conveyances relating to the dedication of land for public use or instruments relating to the vacation of land impressed with a public use; 
D.  Conveyances made to correct descriptions in prior conveyances; 
E.  The sale or exchange of parcels or tracts of land existing on September 12, 1977, and not involving the creation of any new streets or easements of access; 
F.  The transfer or conveyances of any portion of any lot to an adjoining lot such that no new building sites are created; 
G.  Minor subdivisions as defined in Section 16.04.020. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 2) 
16.04.037 - Engineering standards for utility construction. 
    The construction of such water and sanitary sewer facilities as are required under this title in each subdivision of land shall comply with the engineering standards incorporated by reference under Section 13.04.080 of the city code. 
(Ord. 2007-13 § 2) 
16.04.040 - Minor subdivisions-Use of certified survey map divisions. 
    Minor subdivisions may be created, subject to the following requirements: 
A.  Each proposal for a minor subdivision utilizing a certified survey map pursuant to Section 236.34, Wis. Stats., and this title shall be submitted to the city plan director for approval or rejection. The city plan director is expressly delegated the power to approve or reject certified survey maps in accord with Section 236.34(1)(f), Wis. Stats. 
B.  Each certified survey map shall be prepared by a land surveyor registered in Wisconsin. 
C.  Compliance with all of the requirements imposed under Section 16.08.030(B) shall be indicated on the certified survey map. To the extent applicable, compliance with all other provisions of this title shall be indicated, as well. 
D.  Compliance with all of the requirements imposed under Section 236.34, Wis. Stats., shall be indicated on the certified survey map. 
E.  Twelve (12) copies of the certified survey map shall be submitted to the city plan director, who shall approve or reject the same within ninety (90) days of submittal unless the time is mutually agreed to be extended. For purposes of calculating this time period, the date of submission shall be deemed to be the later of the date when the application for approval is submitted or when the required fee is paid to the city. The failure of the city plan director to approve or reject a certified survey map within the designated period of time shall not, however, cause it to be deemed to have been approved. 
F.  In the event that a certified survey map is rejected, the city plan director shall set forth the reasons for the rejection and provide a written copy of the same to the proposed subdivider. 
G.  No lot to be created pursuant to a certified survey map shall be offered for sale until after the certified survey map has been recorded. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 3 (part)) 
16.04.050 - All other subdivisions to comply with Chapter 16.08. 
    Each subdivision which does not qualify for consideration as a minor subdivision and review and approval in accord with Section 16.04.040 shall be required to be created by a plat in accord with Chapter 16.08. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 3 (part)) 
16.04.060 - Variances. 
A.  The city council and plan commission may grant variances from the provisions of this title, but only after determining that: 
1.  Because of the unique conditions of the subdivision involved, literal application of the title would impose a hardship; 
2.  The variance shall not violate the purpose of this title or the provisions of Ch. 236, Wis. Stats. 
B.  The requirement of filing and recording a plat for subdivision shall not be waived. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 3 (part); prior code § 18.10) 
16.04.070 - Enforcement, penalties and remedies. 
A.  The plan commission shall have primary responsibility for enforcing this title. No land use permit shall be issued for construction on any lot until the final plat for the subdivision has been duly recorded or a certified survey map has been recorded. In addition, no building permit shall be issued for any lot in any area or subdivision, or part thereof, unless and until the improvements required by this title have been completed for the lot for which application for a building permit is made. 
B.  Any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a penalty as provided in Chapter 1.20 of this municipal code. In addition, the remedies provided by Sections 236.30 and 236.31, Wis. Stats., shall be available to the city. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 3 (part); prior code § 18.15) 
16.04.080 - Application of title. 
A.  This title shall not only apply to subdivisions and additions herein approved and accepted by the council, but shall also apply, insofar as the improvement of the undeveloped area and payment for the costs thereof are concerned, to those subdivisions and additions, or parts thereof, already platted and approved which are undeveloped wholly or partially as of September 15, 1977. 
B.  Nothing in this title shall be construed as creating an assumption for or by the city of any liability for any injuries, loss or damage caused by compliance or failure to comply by any subdivider or developer in maintaining all improvements in a safe condition. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 3 (part); prior code § 18.16) 
Chapter 16.08 - PLATTING PROCEDURE 
Sections: 

16.08.010 - Procedures for plats of survey. 
A.  Plats shall be submitted to the city plan director. Plats shall be submitted in accordance with Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., compliance with all requirements of which shall be indicated on the face of the plat. 
B.  Plats of survey shall be prepared by a Wisconsin registered land surveyor. 
C.  Plats of survey shall clearly indicate existing and proposed property lines, buildings, drives, streets and alleys, on-site sewage disposal systems, utility lines, easements and any other information found necessary by the city. 
D.  All requirements of the Ch. A-E 7, Wis. Adm. Code, Minimum Standards for Property Surveys, shall be indicated on the plat of survey. 
E.  Nineteen (19) copies of each plat shall be submitted to the city plan director, who shall approve or reject the same within ninety (90) days of submittal unless the time is mutually agreed to be extended. For purposes of calculating this time period, the date of submission shall be deemed to be the later of the date when the application for approval is submitted or when the required fee is paid to the city. 
F.  The city council shall consider the recommendation of the city plan director and approve or deny the plat within sixty (60) days of its submission unless the time is mutually extended. For purposes of calculating this time period, it shall commence on the date of the first meeting at which the plat is considered for approval by the city council. 
G.  In the event that a plat is rejected, the city plan director shall set forth the reasons for the rejection and provide a written copy of the same to the proposed subdivider. 
H.  No lot to be created pursuant to a plat shall be offered for sale until after the plat has been recorded. 
(Ord. 2007-06 §§ 4-7; prior code § 18.035) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
16.08.020 - Division of land. 
A.  No division of land shall be permitted if it results in a subdivision, unless a plat or a certified survey map is submitted and approved in accordance with this title and Ch. 236, Wis. Stats. 
B.  In addition to the provision of this title and Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., all subdivisions shall conform to the zoning ordinance, the official map and the comprehensive plan for the city and its extraterritorial planning area. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 8) 
16.08.030 - Procedure for submitting subdivisions. 
A.  Preliminary Meeting. Before filing a preliminary plat, the subdivider shall consult with the plan commission or its staff for advice regarding general requirements affecting the proposed development. A sketch of the proposed subdivision drawn on a topographic survey map shall be submitted. The subdivider shall also submit a location map showing the relationship of the proposed subdivision to traffic arteries and existing community facilities. Nothing in this section shall be construed as an assumption of liability by the plan commission or its staff as to the legality or form requirements of the proposed preliminary plat, nor be construed as preventing the plan commission from rejecting a preliminary plat merely because the plan commission or its staff made suggestions or gave advice with reference to it. 
B.  Preliminary Plat. 
1.  The subdivider shall submit to the plan commission and to those agencies having the authority to object to plats under the provisions of Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., a preliminary plat (six copies) based upon an accurate exterior boundary survey by a registered land surveyor which shows clearly the proposed subdivision at a scale of not more than one inch per one hundred (100) feet having two feet contour intervals. A sketch or preliminary layout shall be included for all land contiguous of the same owner so the plat may be reviewed as a portion of a total development. A plat shall be considered submitted when it is considered by the plan commission at the first meeting at which the plat is a scheduled agenda item. 
2.  A preliminary plat shall not be acceptable for review purposes unless all of the following information is clearly indicated: 
a.  Description. 
i.  Name of the proposed subdivision; 
ii.  Name, address of the owner, subdivider, engineer, land surveyor or land planner; 
iii.  Date, graphic scale and north point; 
iv.  Location of the proposed subdivision by quarter section, township, range and county and a location map showing the relationship between the plan and its surrounding area. 
b.  Existing Conditions. 
i.  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet; 
ii.  A scaled drawing of the exterior boundaries of the proposed subdivision referenced to a corner established by the U. S. Public Land Survey and the total acreage encompassed thereby; 
iii.  Location of existing property lines, buildings, drives, streams, water courses, dry runs, lakes, marches, rock outcrops, wooded areas and other significant features within the parcel being subdivided; 
iv.  Location, right-of-way width and names of any adjacent existing streets, alleys or other public ways, easements and railroad and utility rights-of-way within or adjacent to the proposed subdivision; 
v.  Water elevations of adjoining lakes or streams at the date of survey, regional flood elevation data and where determined, high and low water elevations; 
vi.  Location and size of any existing sanitary and storm sewers, culverts or drain pipes and the location and size of any existing water, electric and gas service on or adjacent to the proposed subdivision; 
vii.  Location and names of adjacent subdivisions, parks and cemeteries; 
viii.  Existing land use and zoning included within or adjacent to the proposed subdivision. 
b.  Proposed Conditions. 
i.  Location, width and name of all proposed streets and walkways; 
ii.  Layout and scale dimensions of all lots and proposed lot and block numbers; 
iii.  Draft of proposed protective covenants, if any, to be imposed; 
iv.  Location and approximate dimensions of any sites to be reserved or dedicated for parks, playgrounds, greenways or other public uses; 
v.  Location and size of proposed utilities, including sanitary and storm sewer, water, electric and gas service, plus other required utilities and appropriate easements with widths indicated. 
3.  After review of the preliminary plat and negotiations with the subdivider on changes recommended and the kind and extent of public improvements which will be required, the plan commission shall approve, approve conditionally or reject in writing the preliminary plat within ninety (90) days (effective 11-1-80) after it has been submitted as defined above, unless the time is mutually extended. 
4.  Approval of the preliminary plat shall entitle the subdivider to final approval of the layout as it pertains to lots, streets and other dedicated, lands shown by such plat, provided that the final plat conforms substantially to such layout and all conditions of approval have been met. 
C.  Final Plat. 
1.  Final plats shall be submitted to the plan commission within twenty-four (24) months of preliminary plat acceptance. The final plat shall conform to the preliminary plat as approved and to the requirements of all applicable ordinances and state laws and shall be submitted for certification of those agencies having the authority to object to the plat as provided by Section 236.12, Wis. Stats. The final plat shall be accompanied by detailed construction plans of all improvements. The final plat shall be submitted to the plan commission at a regular meeting and shall be accepted or rejected by the plan commission and the city council within sixty (60) days of its submission unless the time is extended by an agreement with the subdivider. Reasons for rejection shall be stated in the minutes of the council meeting and a copy thereof or written statement of such reasons shall be given to the subdivider. Approved final plats shall be recorded in accordance with the statutory requirements prior to the time that lots are offered for sale, reference is made to the map for sale purposes or use is made of lot and block numbers shown on the plat. A reproducible mylar shall be submitted to the city after all approvals and filings have been completed. 
2.  If the original of the final plat has been filed with another approving authority, the subdivider may file a true copy of such plat in lieu of the original. However, before approval of the plan commission and the city council shall be inscribed on the original of the final plat, the surveyor and subdivider shall certify the respects in which the original of the final plat differs from the true copy and all modifications shall first be approved. 
D.  Approval. All approvals shall be in writing and a copy attached to the final plat. 
E.  Fees. The subdivider shall pay the city at the times specified in this section all fees as herein required to defray any administrative expenses. 
1.  Preliminary Plat. At the time of the filing of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall pay to the city clerk a fee plus a per lot fee for each lot in the proposed subdivision. A reapplication fee shall be paid to the clerk at the time of filing of a preliminary plat which has previously been reviewed. The fees will be set from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
2.  Final Plat. At the time of the filing of the final plat, the subdivider shall pay to the clerk a fee plus a per lot fee for each lot in the proposed subdivision. A reapplication fee shall be paid to the clerk at the time of filing of a final plat which has previously been reviewed. The fees will be set from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
3.  Certified Survey Map. At the time of the filing of the certified survey map, the subdivider shall pay to the clerk a fee. The fee will be set from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 2001-11 § 26; prior code § 18.05) 
Chapter 16.10 - EXTRATERRITORIAL SUBDIVISIONS 
Sections: 

16.10.001 - Statement of purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter shall be to govern the subdivision of lands lying within the extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction of the city in adjoining towns as determined pursuant to Sections 236.02(5) and 236.10(1)(b)2., Wis. Stats. Underlying the regulations is the need of the city to deal with the effects of growth upon the city and its potential need to provide for or to extend its provision of services and infrastructure to anticipated subdivisions and land developments. Also underlying the regulations is the city's need to finance the installation, construction, and operational costs of services and infrastructure related to development thereof upon the planning for and efficient delivery of public improvements in the city and, as annexations occur, in areas now adjoining the city. A further basis for this chapter is the need to deal with the rapid growth in impervious surfaces resulting from development, the environmental impacts of development adjacent to the Kinnickinnic River and upon the bluffs surrounding the city and the corresponding problems of dealing with presently uncontrolled residential, commercial, and industrial development of lands in adjoining towns which, in the future, may require the extension of city services or may result in requests for annexation to the city, resulting in haphazard or unplanned or under planned streets, sewage disposal and water system extensions and other infrastructure related problems. In addition, unplanned or uncontrolled subdivision of lands and their development outside of the city limits may in the future restrict planned growth of the city, impacting upon the need for and location of parks, schools and other governmental structures and services. This chapter and its regulation of extraterritorial land subdivisions is further designed to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to that end shall be used as a means of lessening congestion in the streets and highways; to further the orderly layout and use of land; to insure the use of proper legal descriptions and monumenting of land subdivisions; to secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; to provide adequate light and air; to promote development of land which is harmonious to the use of adjoining land; to prevent the overcrowding of land and avoid undue concentration of population; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, water, sewage, storm water drainage, schools, parks and parkways, playgrounds and other public requirements; and to facilitate the resubdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.010 - Authority. 
    This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority granted to the city under Sections 62.11(5), 236.02(5), 236.10(1)(b)2 and 236.45, Wis. Stats. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.050 - Goals of this chapter. 
    The city of River Falls subscribes to the policy that the development of land, both in and adjoining the city, should be located in a compact manner so as to facilitate the efficient and cost effective provision of municipal services and facilities. With this intent in mind, proposed subdivisions shall be reviewed in accord with and shall conform to the following goals: 
A.  Preservation and enhancement of the business, industrial, residential and institutional climate of the city of River Falls and encouragement of compact, balanced growth, both within and adjoining its city limits. 
B.  Encouragement of an appropriate array of and configuration of commercial, industrial, residential and institutional land uses, together with promotion of employment opportunities and preservation of open space, land uses, including but not limited to those associated with the Kinnickinnic River, a regional natural resource, so as to meet both the needs of present as well as future residents of the area. 
C.  Direction of new growth to those areas capable of providing adequate public services and facilities. 
D.  Prevention of scattered, noncontiguous development without discouraging new, desirable development. 
E.  Ensuring that new development will not be detrimental to the physical, social and economic well being of the residents of the city or adjoining areas of Pierce and St. Croix Counties. 
F.  Ensuring that new development will be organized and timed so as to permit urban services and facilities to be provided as economically and efficiently as possible. 
G.  Discouragement of new developments in those areas which are premature in terms of planning and timing for the provision of adequate public services and facilities. 
H.  Preservation of high quality agricultural lands for that purpose when located in areas designated for agricultural land uses. 
I.  Prohibition of development in areas or forms where substantial problems will result from excessive automobile traffic volume. 
J.  Favoring of land use intensities and patterns which are supportive of alternative modes of transportation. 
K.  Fostering the preservation of significant historical properties and sites. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.075 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall control the interpretation and application of this chapter: 
    "Accessory structure" means a subordinate structure that is customarily incidental to and located on the same lot as a principal structure. 
    "Adjacent" means immediately adjoining or neighboring, as in the case of properties that have common borders or boundaries. 
    "Agricultural lands" means land which is at the time of application for approval of a proposed subdivision actively being used for agricultural purposes, including commercial bee keeping, dairying, floriculture, forestry, general farming, horticulture, nurseries, orchards, paddocks, pasturage, stabling, truck farming and viticulture or which land is vacant but in accord with soil maps and agricultural zoning regulations has been determined to be prime agricultural land. 
    "Approval authority" means, in the case of a certified survey map, the city plan director, and in the case of a plat, the plan commission. 
    "City limits" means the corporate limits of the city of River Falls. 
    "City plan director" means the city plan director and his or her designees. 
    "Extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction" has the same meaning as is set forth at Section 16.04.020. 
    "Farm" means a parcel of real estate, together with all structures associated with the same, used for an agricultural purpose, as described with reference to the definition of "agricultural lands," above. 
    "Gross area" means the physical area of a lot not including any portion thereof subject to an easement or dedication for street or other public travel purposes. 
    "Lot" means a legally identifiable and recordable parcel of land created in the process of and as a direct result of the subdividing of a larger tract of land. 
    "Principal structure" means the main structure on a lot and is anything that is constructed or erected the use of which requires a permanent location on the ground or attachment to something having a permanent location on the ground. 
    "Public improvement" means the same term as is used in Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., further defined as a type of permanent addition to or betterment of real property which improves the value or utility of the subdivision and is made available for use by the public. 
    "Public sewerage system" means a municipally owned and operated sewage disposal system, but shall not include any Wis. Adm. Code Ch. SPS 383 systems. 
    "Subdivision area" shall consist of that portion of the extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction lying between the city limits and the subdivision boundary, as established pursuant to Section 16.10.100, below. 
    "Vacant land" means land that at the time that its subdivision is proposed has not been improved, nor is it then being used for any purpose permitted or conditionally permitted under applicable zoning regulations. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
16.10.100 - Subdivision area established. 
A.  For purposes of this chapter, and consistent with Sections 236.02(5) and 236.10(5), Wis. Stats., the subdivision area, shall consist of all territory lying between the city limits and a line established by the common council and set forth on the city official map, denominated thereupon as the subdivision boundary. 
B.  Determination of Boundaries. Whenever uncertainty exists as to the boundary as shown on the city official map, the following rules apply: 
1.  Where boundary lines are indicated as quarter section line or quarter-quarter section line, such line shall be construed to be such boundary. 
2.  Where boundary lines are indicated as approximately following lot lines, such lines shall be construed to be such boundaries. 
C.  In order to facilitate the administration of this chapter, the following requirements shall be imposed: 
1.  The city clerk shall file a certified copy of this chapter with the clerk of each town. 
2.  The city clerk shall file a certified copy of the official city map with the clerk of each town. 
3.  The city clerk shall file certified copies of all amendments or other modifications to this chapter, the comprehensive plan and the official city map with the clerk of each town. 
4.  The city clerk shall file certified copies of legislation approving the subdivision of land in accord with this chapter with the clerk of the town in which the subdivided real estate is situated. 
D.  A copy of each application for a building or sanitary permit for real estate situated within the boundaries of the subdivision area shall, prior to its issuance, be filed by the town officer or employee designated to approve of the same with the city plan director who shall promptly review the same for compliance with the official city map and setback requirements imposed under this chapter. It shall be the duty of the city plan director to file an objection with the designated town officer or employee within a reasonable period of time after receipt of a copy of the application for a permit, in lieu of which it shall be presumed that the application is in compliance with city regulations. 
E.  To the extent that this chapter limits the subdivision area to land lying within the subdivision boundary, established with reference to the attached map, it constitutes a waiver on the part of the city to approve of land subdivisions lying outside of that border and extending to the three mile limit for its extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction as established pursuant to Sections 236.02(5) and 236.10, Wis. Stats. The city reserves the right, in accord with Section 236.10(5), Wis. Stats., to rescind this modification of its extraterritorial subdivision jurisdiction at any time upon adoption of an ordinance modifying the provisions of subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.110 - Official city map to apply. 
    No permit shall be issued to construct or enlarge any building within the limits of any street or highway, waterway, public transit facility or parkway, shown or laid out on the official city map at any location in the subdivision area except in full accord with this chapter. No subdivision of land that is inconsistent with the city map shall be approved unless conditions are imposed thereupon to prevent any development which is inconsistent therewith. Any person seeking to do so shall apply to the city plan director for a permit, and no such permit may be issued except in full accord with this chapter, Section 12.04.040 and the official city map. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.115 - Shoreland zoning ordinances and maps applicable. 
    No permission may be granted for the subdivision of land that violates the city floodplain protection and shoreland and wetland zoning regulations, as set forth in Chapter 15.24 of the city code. Nor may any subdivision violate the provisions of any town or county floodplain, shoreland, or wetland zoning regulations. To the extent that subdivisions are approved subject to compliance therewith, conditions shall be established so as to ensure that use of the land so subdivided meets with all of the provisions of Chapter 15.24 and applicable town and county floodplain, shoreland, and wetland ordinances. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.120 - General requirements. 
    No person shall divide any land located in the subdivision area, resulting in a subdivision as defined in this chapter, without first complying with all of the following to the extent that they are applicable to the subdivision in question: 
A.  The provisions of Ch. 236, Wis. Stats. 
B.  The most restrictive of applicable ordinances, rules and regulations of each approval jurisdiction. 
C.  The city comprehensive plan and official city map. 
D.  All statutes, administrative rules and applicable ordinances pertaining to lot size and soils if the subdivision is not served by a public sewerage system. 
E.  The rules of the State Department of Transportation related to access and preservation of the public interest and investment in streets and highways if the subdivision or any portion thereof abuts on a state trunk highway or street connecting therewith. 
F.  Whenever a tract or parcel proposed to be subdivided contains any part of a street, highway or parkway designated on the official city map, such part of the proposed public way shall be platted and dedicated by the subdivider in the location and at the width indicated in the city map. 
G.  No land shall be subdivided which is held to be unsuitable for use or development by reason of flooding, bad drainage, soil or rock formations which severely limit development potential, tend to create severe erosion potential or for reasons of unfavorable topography or any other feature which is likely to be harmful to the safety or welfare of future residents or landowners in the proposed subdivision or in the community at large. 
H.  Lot sizes shall conform with the most restrictive area and width requirements imposed under state and local regulations prescribed for the territory in which the proposed subdivision is situated. 
I.  To the extent applicable, the city sewer service area criteria. 
J.  Other applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.125 - Setbacks from regulated streams. 
    It is recognized in this chapter that to the extent that streams regulated under Chapter 15.24 of this code flow through the subdivision area, they constitute unique natural features, which require both protection from building encroachments as well as aesthetic protection to maintain their status as unique natural features. To this effect, it is deemed by the city that no principal or accessory structures shall be constructed at any location in relationship to the ordinary high water mark of any such regulated stream which is in conflict with the provisions of Chapter 15.24 of the city code, incorporated herein by reference under Section 16.10.115. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.130 - Subdivisions regulated within subdivision area. 
A.  Minimum Lot Size. No new lot whose gross area is less than thirty-five (35) acres in size may be created by subdivision of existing tracts or parcels of land, except as is set forth in Sections 16.10.135 and 16.10.160 of this chapter. 
B.  Preexisting Lots. Lots which have been legally created and which exist as of the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter and which are less than thirty-five (35) acres in gross size shall be recognized as preexisting, nonconforming lots and may be used in accord with applicable regulations. However, from a subdivision control standpoint, the following regulations concerning such lots shall apply: 
1.  No preexisting nonconforming lot shall be further subdivided. 
2.  Subject to complete compliance with all other provisions of this chapter, preexisting nonconforming lots may be enlarged. However, this allowance shall be subject to the following limitation. In the process of enlarging a preexisting nonconforming lot, land may not be taken from an adjoining lot or parcel as a result of which the adjoining lot or parcel is reduced to less than thirty-five (35) acres in gross area, except in cases involving lot line adjustments which do not create new lots or building sites, or which render either lot or parcel to become more nonconforming than it was prior to the enlargement of the adjoining lot. 
C.  Lands Annexed to City. Land that adjoins the city limits, for which a petition for annexation has been filed and approved by the common council, subject to terms and conditions of an applicable annexation agreement, may be exempted from the lot size restrictions imposed under subsection A of this section, subject to the remaining criteria of this chapter. 
D.  Farm Related Land Subdivision Exemption. The subdivision of a parcel of land from a farm, which is controlled by Section 16.10.160(B), shall be exempt from the minimum lot size requirement of subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 2007-11 § 1; Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.135 - Subdivision of existing substandard parcels permissible subject to conditions. 
A.  A pre-existing parcel of real estate which was not created as a lot in a plat or certified survey map division of land and which was of record prior to the effective date of Chapter 16.10 and which is smaller than thirty-five (35) acres in size or which after division in accord with this section will result in the creation of one lot or parcel which shall be less than thirty-five (35) acres in size may be legally divided, subject to the following limitations: 
1.  The pre-existing parcel must already be occupied by an existing residential dwelling. 
2.  The purpose of the division must be to split off from the remainder of the pre-existing parcel containing the existing residential dwelling. 
3.  Only one division of such a pre-existing parcel shall be allowed, except for other divisions that are in full compliance with Section 16.10.130. 
4.  In accord with subsection (B)(3), below, no building permit or other permission shall be granted to the owner or his or her successor or successors in interest to erect or build a principal structure upon that portion of the pre-existing parcel which does not at the time of such division contain a principal structure. If such a permit is applied for to the town in which the parcel is situated, the city may bring an action in injunctive relief to enforce the covenant required under subsection (B)(3), below. 
B.  Divisions of pre-existing lots or parcels for the purpose of creating a lot containing an existing residential dwelling under this section shall be subject to the following standards. 
1.  The resulting lot or parcel containing the existing house shall be no less than two acres in size, nor more than five acres in size. 
2.  The lot or parcel containing the existing house shall be configured in such a manner as to promote, rather than to hinder, open space use of the remainder of the pre-existing lot or parcel as well as to meet the purpose and intent of this chapter in controlling the subdivision of land. 
3.  The owner of the pre-existing lot or parcel shall record a covenant against the title to that portion of the pre-existing lot or parcel which does not contain the existing residential dwelling, which covenant shall prohibit any further subdivision of that lot or parcel as well as prohibit the erection or building thereupon of any type of principal structure except in full compliance with Section 16.10.130 and other applicable ordinances of the city. The city attorney for purposes of compliance with this section shall approve each such covenant. 
4.  The division of a pre-existing lot or parcel shall conform to all other applicable provisions of this chapter. 
C.  A pre-existing lot which was created by a division of land which was of record prior to the effective date of Chapter 16.10, and with a land use designation of Very Low Infill (VLI) as mapped on the City of River Falls Comprehensive Plan Future Land Use Map may be divided under this chapter to lots whose sizes are authorized in Section 17.108, City of River Falls Municipal Code Extraterritorial Zoning. This type of land division shall be exempt from the requirements under subsection A, above. The utility director and the planning director shall approve of the creation of new lots in accord with a cost of service study and the standards under Section 16.10.200, subject to the appeal of the planning commission and city council. 
D.  Prior to recording a division of a pre-existing lot or parcel in accord with this section, the owner shall meet with the plan director who shall grant permission to the proposed subdivision, subject to the standards under subsection B of this section, if it is in accord with this section. Such authorization may be conditioned upon the owner making changes in his or her proposed division so as to fulfill the objectives of subsection (B)(2) of this section. No division that fails to meet the criteria of this section shall be allowed, in which event the requirements of Section 16.10.130 shall be applied. 
(Ord. 2007-11 § 2) 
(Ord. No. 2008-35, §§ 1-3, 11-25-2008; Ord. No. 2016-08 , § 11, 6-14-2016) 
16.10.140 - Criteria for land divisions. 
    A preliminary plat or certified survey map for the subdivision of land situated in the subdivision area shall not be approved unless it meets with the following criteria: 
A.  The proposed subdivision shall be adequately accessible via streets or highways, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Existing streets shall be found to be adequate to accommodate the traffic that is estimated to be generated by the proposed subdivision in addition to existing traffic. 
2.  Such additional streets or street improvements as are necessary in combination with existing streets to accommodate the additional traffic which will be generated by the proposed subdivision are budgeted for construction in the current adopted budget of the town in which the subdivision is situated or shall be provided for through private means of financing. 
3.  In determination of the adequacy of transportation facilities, the approval authority shall consult with the city engineer and where appropriate with the Department of Transportation. 
B.  The proposed subdivision shall be determined to have adequate stormwater drainage and retention capabilities and where improvements are required in order to conform the same to applicable statutes, rules and regulations, and conditions shall be imposed upon the plat or certified survey map to ensure compliance therewith, including such assurances as may be deemed necessary to allow for the provision of adequate public or private funds to cause the required stormwater drainage and retention facilities to be constructed and maintained. 
C.  The proposed subdivision shall be determined to have adequate private sanitary sewage disposal capability or, if a community disposal system is proposed in accord with Wis. Adm. Code Ch. SPS 383, it is in compliance therewith. 
D.  The proposed subdivision shall have adequate water service. 
E.  The proposed subdivision shall have adequate parks, open space and recreation opportunities available to it and its residents as determined in accord with applicable rules, regulations and standards. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
16.10.150 - Mapping requirements. 
    All subdivisions of land in the subdivision area shall conform with all applicable mapping requirements imposed under Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., and this title. This shall include but not be limited to dimensional criteria, technical mapping requirements and such other and further requirements as are imposed, subject only to the limitations expressed under Section 16.10.210, below. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.160 - Subdivision of agricultural lands. 
A.  Notwithstanding Section 16.10.130, above, approval for the subdivision of agricultural land shall not be granted even for the creation of a thirty-five (35) acre parcel if it is determined in the course of the review process that to authorize such a subdivision will be detrimental to the continued agricultural use of all or any portion of the tract or parcel sought to be subdivided. In making this determination, the city shall take into consideration applicable town or county zoning which has placed the land in question into an exclusive agricultural district as well as the question of whether such a subdivision would violate any transfer of development rights instruments recorded against and pertaining to the same. The latter limitation on subdivision approval shall not apply if the development restrictions imposed against the land in question have been legally released. 
B.  As a complete exception to the limitations imposed under subsection A of this section, the owner of agricultural lands, who also resides upon said land, may seek to legally divide from an agricultural tract of land, a lot not less than two acres in size for the purpose of accommodating the construction and use of a principal structure for residential use by a person who is employed on the farm which is maintained on the remainder of the parcel to be so divided and who earns a substantial part of his or her livelihood from work on the farm. In addition, such a lot may be created for the parents or a child or children of the operator of the farm from which such lot is to be created. For purposes of this subsection, "substantial part of his or her livelihood from work on the farm" shall be defined to mean at least fifty (50) percent of the individual's annual gross income from his or her labor. 
(Ord. 2007-11 § 3; Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.170 - Subdivision of nonagricultural lands. 
    Subject to the minimum lot size requirement, approval of the subdivision of nonagricultural lands shall be made upon the basis that the proposed division complies with the following criteria: 
A.  It is compatible with adjacent land uses and shall maintain the general land use pattern of the area in question. 
B.  It will result in a development pattern that is compatible with surrounding developments and land uses. Measures of compatibility shall include lot sizes, traffic generation, access, noise and visual features. 
C.  The proposed subdivision and resulting development shall not adversely affect the city's ability to provide public services, install public improvements or accomplish future annexations. 
D.  The proposed subdivision complies with one or more of the following: 
1.  It represents infilling of vacant land. Infilling is defined as a subdivision of vacant land which will accommodate the development of vacant land located such that surrounding land uses render the land impractical for anything other than uses similar to those proposed to be made of it after subdivision. 
2.  The proposed subdivision shall provide permanent open space lands for use by the general public in conformity with the comprehensive plan and other city ordinances, if applicable. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.180 - Division of land abutting major streets and highways. 
A.  The city adopts by reference the purposes underlying Wis. Adm. Code Ch. Trans 233 at Section Trans 233.01 as forming the basis upon which it is determined that regulating the development of land adjoining designated major streets and highways is deemed to be a subject of concern for the city, which concern shall be taken into consideration in the process of approving or rejecting proposed subdivisions of tracts of land, as well as the construction thereupon of improvements. 
B.  No person may erect or construct any structure or improvement upon any land which is subdivided under the terms of this chapter which is within one hundred ten (110) feet of the centerline of a street or highway designated in subsection C of this section, or within fifty (50) feet of the right-of-way line thereof, whichever is further from the centerline of the street or highway. If any portion of a service road right-of-way lies within the setback area described above, the setback shall be increased by the lesser of the following: 
1.  The width of the service road right-of-way, if the entire service road right-of-way lies within the setback area. 
2.  The distance by which the service road right-of-way lies within the setback area, if the entire service road right-of-way does not lie within the setback area. 
C.  The streets and highways subject to this section shall be those which are designated on the city map as principal arterials, minor arterials, and collector streets, designated in accord with the definitions of streets set forth at Section 16.04.020. Incorporated in this chapter is a map identifying these streets in the subdivision area. 
D.  The restriction in subsection B of this section, against the erection or construction of structures or improvements in the described setback zone shall not apply to public utility transmission lines, whether above or below the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.190 - Procedure for platting divisions of land. 
A.  All persons desiring to subdivide land in the subdivision area by means of a plat may submit a preliminary map or plan of the proposed division to the city plan director. The city plan director shall within a reasonable time from the date of submission of the same either provide the proposed subdivider with an analysis of the proposed land division or shall call for a conference to be held with the subdivider, the purpose of which shall be to discuss applicable standards and the demonstration on the face of the proposed plat or map of its compliance or noncompliance therewith. This step does not require formal application or the filing of a preliminary plat but is intended to inform the proposed subdivider of the objectives of the city regulations and those set forth in the comprehensive plan and the city map to assist the subdivider in planning the development in question and to informally attempt to arrive at mutual conclusions regarding the general program and objectives of the subdivision and land development in question. 
B.  Submittal of both preliminary plats and final plats shall conform to the requirements of Chapter 16.08, which shall control. The time periods to which approvals, conditional approvals or rejections of preliminary or final plats are subjected shall not commence until the date of the initial meeting of the plan commission at which the preliminary or final plat is on the agenda for consideration by the said commission. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.200 - Certified survey map divisions of land. 
A.  Subject to the limitations on the availability of a certified survey map for use in the division of land as is set forth at Section 236.34(1), Wis. Stats., a certified survey map may be used in lieu of a final plat if it meets with all requirements of Section 236.34, Wis. Stats., this chapter, Section 16.04.040 and all other applicable ordinances. Unless waived by the city plan director, a preliminary map shall be submitted to the city prior to the filing of a proposed certified survey map of a land division and the city plan director shall comply with the recommendations of the city engineer and the River Falls municipal utilities and may require of the proposed subdivider that sketches or other information be submitted for a determination of whether or not the objectives of this chapter can be achieved by means of the proposed certified survey map. 
B.  The subdivider shall file nineteen (19) copies of each proposed certified survey map with the city plan director together with a written application for approval on a form devised for that purpose by the city. The application shall contain the complete legal description of the land in question and shall certify that all of the owners of the property contained within the proposed map join in the submittal. A preliminary review shall be made of the proposed land division for confirmation of ownership, encumbrances, easements, rights-of-way, leases, unpaid real estate taxes and unpaid special assessments. If necessary, the city plan director shall consult with the city attorney. 
C.  The city plan director shall within ninety (90) days of submittal of the said certified survey map either approve of it, conditionally approve of it or reject it. The failure of the city plan director to so act within the designated period of time shall constitute a rejection of the proposed certified survey map, subject to the right of the subdivider to request of the plan commission that it review the non-action of the city plan director and approve of the map. 
D.  In the event that the city plan director determines that a proposed certified survey map or plat does not meet the standards of this chapter for approval, or fails to react to it during the designated time period, the subdivider may refer this denial to the plan commission which shall schedule the matter for review at its next regularly scheduled meeting following the receipt by it of a written request for review. If the plan commission refuses to approve of the certified survey map division, it shall furnish the proposed subdivider with the reasons for its action, in writing. Such decision by the plan commission shall be made within a reasonable period of time after it has been heard by it. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.210 - Conditional approval of subdivisions allowed. 
    The city plan director and the plan commission, in the case of reviews of decisions of the city plan director with respect to certified survey maps and plats, shall have the authority, where necessary, to enforce the requirements of this chapter, to impose conditions upon its approval of maps or plats for recording purposes. Additionally, where deemed an appropriate means of securing compliance with this chapter, the city plan director or plan commission may require the recording of restrictive covenants against the title of the real estate subject to a proposed land division. A further condition of approval shall be the approval of the subdivision in question by all other authorities having the power to approve of or reject the same. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.220 - Design standards. 
    Standards pertaining to the type, method of construction of, materials to be incorporated in or size, length, and dimensions of proposed public improvements to be constructed in proposed subdivision subject to this chapter shall be prescribed by the town in which the land is situated. This limitation does not, however, limit application of the limitations imposed under the official city map, which under Section 62.23(6), Wis. Stats., shall prevail with respect to limitations on construction and enlargement of building impressed with respect to the location and width of streets, highways, historic districts, parkways, parks and playgrounds.
