However, nothing in this chapter prevents the city plan director or plan commission from recommending the installation of public improvements which go beyond the specifications required of the subdivider by the town in which the subdivision is to be located, nor from the city and the subdivider nor from the city, the town and the developer from entering into a developer's agreement specifying the types of public improvements to be installed as well as designating who shall defray the costs associated therewith. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.230 - Waiver of subdivision approval jurisdiction under certain conditions. 
    The authority of the city to approve of subdivisions may be waived by the city as to land situated outside of the city limits if more than one-half of the legal description of a proposed subdivision lies outside of the designated subdivision area. After receiving a report from the plan commission, at its discretion, the common council may waive the rights of the city to review such a subdivision if it finds it to be in the best interests of the city to do so. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.240 - Interrelationship between Chapter 16.10 and Title 16, generally. 
    Should there be any conflict between provisions set forth in this chapter and those found in the remainder of this title, for purposes of the subject matter of this chapter, the specific provisions found herein shall control. In the event that a topic is not covered in this chapter, the provisions of this title shall control. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.250 - Severance clause. 
    Should any paragraph or section of this chapter be held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be unenforceable or unconstitutional, it shall be deemed to be severed from the remainder of this chapter that shall remain in full force and effect as if the offending provision had never been adopted. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.260 - Subdivision boundaries to be governed by modifications to corporate limits of city. 
    In the event that subsequent to the date of adoption of this chapter or any amendment hereto, the city perfects the annexation to itself of additional territory, the city plan director shall place the issue of extension of the boundary of the subdivision area on an agenda of the plan commission for its consideration and recommendation to the common council. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
16.10.270 - Impact of intermunicipal agreements. 
    In the event that in the future, the city and one or more of the four adjoining towns enter into a Section 66.0301 Municipal Cooperation Agreement or a Section 66.0307, Wis. Stats., Cooperative Boundary Agreement, the city agrees that it will duly consider amending this chapter in order to conform it with the terms and conditions set forth in such agreement as pertaining to subdivisions occurring in the town or towns in question. 
(Ord. 2007-06 § 9 (part)) 
Chapter 16.12 - DESIGN STANDARDS 
Sections: 

16.12.010 - Streets and lots. 
A.  The subdivider shall dedicate land for and improve streets as provided herein. Streets shall conform to the official map ordinance of the city. Streets shall be located with due regard for topographical conditions, natural features, existing and proposed streets, utilities and land uses and public convenience and safety. 
B.  All lots shall have frontage on a public street, except as otherwise provided for in this title or in Chapter 15.16. 
C.  Street locations shall be consistent with any street plans officially adopted by the city. Street design shall conform to the following: 
Street Type Right-of-Way Minimum Width Minimum Radius of Curvature Maximum Cul-de-sacs with restricted parking (also loop streets not exceeding 1500' with restricted parking) 50' 100' 10% Local (provides access to individual lots) 60' 100' 10% Collector (collects traffic from minor streets) 66' 180' 9% Minor arterial (carries traffic from collectors to arterials) Note: Individual lot access is discouraged. 80' 230' 8% Principal arterial Note: Individual lot access is denied. 100' 300' 6%  
D.  Streets shall be laid out to provide for possible continuation wherever topographic and other physical conditions permit. 
E.  Minor streets shall be so laid out as to discourage their use by through traffic. 
F.  The number of intersections of minor streets with major streets shall be reduced to the practical minimum consistent with circulation needs and safety requirements. 
G.  Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street (major or minor), the plan commission shall require a frontage road, non-access reservation along the rear of the property contiguous to such arterial street or such other treatment as may be necessary to ensure safe, efficient traffic flow. 
H.  Reserve strips controlling access to streets from an adjacent property owner shall be prohibited except as noted in subsection G of this section. 
I.  A tangent at least one hundred (100) feet long shall be required between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. 
J.  Streets shall afford maximum visibility and safety and shall intersect at right angles where practicable. 
K.  Dedication of half-width streets shall be prohibited. 
L.  Lengths of dead end and cul-de-sac streets shall conform with the following: 
1.  Permanent dead end streets shall not be longer than one thousand (1,000) feet nor provide access to more than thirty (30) residential units, whichever is more restrictive. The length shall be measured along street centerlines, from the center of the turn-around, to the intersection of street centerlines at the nearest non dead end public street. All permanent dead ends streets shall have a turn-around at their end. The turnaround shall have an outside roadway diameter of at least eighty (80) feet and a street property line diameter of one hundred (100) feet. A minimum twenty-five (25) feet radius shall be made at the corners formed by the street and the turnaround right-of-way. 
2.  Permanent cul-de-sac streets shall not be longer than one thousand (1,000) feet nor provide access to more than thirty (30) residential units, whichever is more restrictive. The length shall be measured along street centerlines, from the center of the turn-around, to the intersection of street centerlines at the nearest intersection with a public street. The turn-around shall have an outside roadway diameter of at least eighty (80) feet and a street property line diameter of one hundred (100) feet. A minimum twenty-five (25) foot radius shall be made at the corners formed by the street and the turnaround right-of-way. 
3.  Temporary dead end streets shall not be longer than one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet nor be used for access to more than seventy-five (75) residential units, whichever is more restrictive, and shall have a temporary turn-around with an outside diameter of at least eighty (80) feet constructed to standards approved by the city engineer and planning commission, except as follows. 
a.  Temporary dead end streets shall not be longer than three thousand (3,000) feet nor provide access to more than one hundred fifty (150) residential units, whichever is more restrictive, if all of the following are met: 
i.  A second access for emergency response is provided until such time that the street becomes a non dead end street. The secondary access shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet wide constructed to standards approved by the city engineer and planning commission, be maintainable year-round, and not require a key for access; 
ii.  Location of the temporary access shall be such that no more than seventy-five residential units are provided with only one access for emergency response; and 
iii.  The temporary end of the street has a temporary turn-around constructed to standards approved by the city engineer and planning commission with an outside diameter of at least eighty (80) feet. 
b.  Temporary dead end streets longer than three thousand (3,000) feet or providing access to more than one hundred fifty (150) residential units shall be allowed if all of the following are met: 
i.  The street is part of a route, conforming with the official map, that when complete will cause the street to become a non dead end street; 
ii.  A second access for emergency response is provided until such time that the street becomes a non dead end street. The secondary access shall be a minimum of twelve (12) feet wide constructed to standards approved by the city engineer and planning commission, be maintainable year-round, and not require a key for access; 
iii.  Location of the temporary access shall be such that no more than seventy-five (75) residential units are provided with only one access for emergency response; 
iv.  The temporary end of the street has a temporary turn-around with an outside diameter of at least eighty (80) feet constructed to standards approved by the city engineer and planning commission. 

4.  The planning commission and city council may grant a variance to the requirements herein for the following reasons. 
a.  Topographic conditions exist that do not allow for a subdivision design meeting the requirements above. 
i.  Constraints imposed by limited access roadways may be considered a topographic condition for the purpose of this wording. 
ii.  Constraints imposed by lack of ownership of adjacent developable lands shall not be considered a topographic condition for the purpose of this wording. 
iii.  Constraints imposed by buildings or other development on adjacent lands may be considered a topographic condition for the purpose of this wording. 
M.  Where possible, lot lines shall be perpendicular to the street line and to the tangent at the lot corner on curved streets. 
N.  Lots shall follow, rather than cross, municipal boundary lines whenever practicable. 
O.  No street names shall be used which duplicate or may be confused with the names of existing streets. Street names shall be subject to the approval of the plan commission. 
P.  Notwithstanding the above, if any standard when applied to a particular plat does not meet with good engineering practices as determined by the city engineer, the city council and the plan commission may require such modifications or additions to the plat so as to conform to good engineering practices. 
(Ord. 1999-6 (part); prior code § 18.06(1)) 
16.12.020 - Block design. 
A.  The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be appropriate for the topography and the type of development contemplated. Blocks in residential areas shall not be more than one thousand (1,000) feet long. 
B.  To provide adequate access and circulation to community facilities, a system of pedestrian circulation shall be required. Sidewalks either along streets or through the center of blocks and various kinds of improved trails may be used. In blocks over seven hundred (700) feet long, a pedestrian crosswalk shall be provided at or near the midpoint of the block. The right-of-way for center crosswalks shall not be less than ten (10) feet wide. 
C.  The plan commission shall require that the developer plant (or leave standing in the case of existing) a minimum of one tree for each forty (40) feet of frontage on all streets within the right-of-way, but not so as to interfere with any utilities. Planting shall be a minimum of six feet high and of a species acceptable to the city forester or other agency designated by the city council. 
D.  Subdivision lots in the city shall be in conformance with the area and width requirements of the city zoning ordinance. Area and width requirements of subdivision lots in the extraterritorial planning area shall conform to the extraterritorial zoning ordinance and Ch. SPS 385, Wis. Adm. Code. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 18.06(2)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 2, 5-10-2016) 
16.12.030 - Zoning. 
    Zoning shall be consistent with the district map and extraterritorial zoning ordinance. 
(Prior code § 18.06(3)) 
16.12.040 - Easements. 
A.  The plan commission shall require recorded easements for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary sewers, gas, telephone, water mains or other utility lines in a form approved by the city attorney's office. Easements between lots shall be at least sixteen (16) feet wide, shall be shown on the plat, and shall have the following restriction lettered on the face of the plat: "This utility easement shall have no permanent obstructions (fences, trees, shrubs or other obstacles) that interfere with utility installation and/or maintenance," and the city shall not be held liable for any damages therefrom. This statement shall also be included on the abstract. Easements along dedicated right-of-way shall be of sufficient width for the use intended. 
B.  The plan commission shall require that easements or drainage ways be provided where a subdivision includes a segment or segments of water courses, drainage ways, channels or streams. 
(Prior code § 18.08) 
16.12.050 - Steep slopes (20% or greater). 
A.  Subdivisions shall be designed so that no construction or grading for home sites shall be conducted on steep slopes. 
B.  Steep slopes shall not be considered part of the buildable area of any lot. 
C.  Steep slopes shall be defined as land between the base of the steep slope and the top of the steep slope defined as follows: 
a.  The base of the steep slope shall be that point at which land elevation rises one foot or more over five feet and the rise over the adjacent fifty (50) feet is ten (10) feet or greater. 
b.  The top of the steep slope shall be that point at which the land elevation falls one foot or more over five feet and the fall over the adjacent fifty (50) feet is ten (10) feet or greater. 
c.  The horizontal distance between the base of the steep slope and the top of the steep slope must be fifty (50) feet or greater for land between them to be considered steep slopes. 

D.  Preliminary and final plats shall indicate areas defined as steep slopes based upon a site survey by a registered surveyor or on topographic information plotted from a verified aerial survey. 
E.  Overland stormwater runoff from impervious surfaces that are directed towards steep slopes shall first be directed to an on-site infiltration system. 
a.  On-site infiltration system shall be designed to infiltrate a volume of water equal to one and one-half inches over the entire impervious surface. 
b.  Emergency overflows from the infiltration system shall be designed to be dispersed onto the steep slope in a distributed sheet-flow manner. 
c.  Details for such on-site infiltration system shall be submitted as part of the building permit application. 
F.  These standards shall apply to both division of land within the city as well as the extraterritorial plat jurisdiction area. 
G.  The following are exempt from these provisions: 
a.  Construction of streets and utilities. 
b.  Correction of erosion problems included in an approved stormwater management plan. 
c.  Commercial and industrial lots in existence on December 8, 2009. 
H.  Steep slopes disturbed for any reason shall be restored by planting native vegetation or vegetation as approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-16, § 1, 12-8-09) 
Chapter 16.16 - IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

16.16.010 - General improvements. 
    The following provisions shall apply to the subdivisions platted within the city and shall also apply to subdivisions platted within the extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction of the city. Where extension of utilities and/or annexation is reasonably expected within five years' time as determined by the city council, all improvements shall be required in the extraterritorial area. No improvements are required in the remainder of the extraterritorial area. 
A.  The improvements required under these regulations shall be constructed by the subdivider at his or her expense in accordance with the specifications and under the supervision of the officials having jurisdiction, prior to filing with the plan commission and city council the final plat for final approval; or 
B.  In lieu of construction of the improvements as required in subsection A of this section, the subdivider shall furnish the city clerk with a surety performance bond or other form of surety running to the city sufficient to cover the subdivision cost of such required improvements, as estimated by the city engineers and approved by the city council, thereby to secure the actual construction and installation of such improvements immediately after final approval of the plat or at a time in accordance with the requirements of the council. The bond shall be in such form as approved by the city attorney's office. Prior to either acceptance of the improvement by the city council or release of the subdivider's bond, all improvements shall be inspected by the city engineer and other appropriate city officials and if they are found to be installed according to the plans and specifications and any other requirements herein defined, a written report of such approval by the appropriate city officers shall be given to the city council who may then consider the same in approving the plat or releasing the bond. 
C.  If the procedure under subsection B of this section is followed, the construction of all improvements required by these rules and regulations shall be completed within two years from the date of approval of the final plat by the council unless good cause can be shown for the granting of an extension of time by authority of the council, but the council shall not grant variances to exceed five years from acceptance of the final plat. If no extension is granted, the city, at its option, may cause all uncompleted required work to be constructed and the parties executing the bond shall be firmly bound for payment of all necessary costs thereof. 
D.  The approval of the final plat by the city council shall constitute acceptance of the dedication of any public street, road or highway dedicated in such plat. 
E.  Where unusual or exceptional factors or conditions exist, the city council may modify the provisions of this title. A written statement of the reasons for such modifications shall be attached to all copies of the construction plans. 
F.  If the city council or city engineer make design requirements that are in excess of requirements for the immediate development as determined by the city engineer and approved by the council, the excess cost shall be equally shared by the city and the developer. "Design requirements" shall include size and materials, but not depth or routing. 
G.  The city reserves the right to require independent testing and inspection of any or all improvements installed in a subdivision. This testing and inspection shall be done at the developer's expense and shall be based upon current city construction specifications. 
(Prior code § 18.07(1)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-08 , § 12, 6-14-2016) 
16.16.020 - Improvements. 
    The following improvements shall be required at the expense of the subdivider: 
A.  Streets, Boulevards and Terraces. 
1.  After installation of all utilities the streets shall be brought to finished grade in accordance with the approved plans and specifications subject to the soil conditions peculiar to the subdivision area. After inspection by the city engineer and installation of curb and gutter, the subdivider shall surface the streets with bituminous surfacing or concrete. The subdivider shall be responsible for all subgrade, grade and finishing materials and base. 
2.  Boulevards and terraces shall be top-soiled after the installation of underground utilities to conform to specifications established by the city engineer. 
3.  No street shall be accepted by the city until a written report has been filed by the city engineer stating that all requirements as to fill, grade, compaction and finished surface have been fully complied with. This report shall be made within fourteen (14) days of written request for acceptance of the street. 
4.  The developer shall not be relieved of responsibility for any street construction until one year after the engineer's report has been submitted giving acceptance. 
5.  Curb and gutter shall be installed before any street is surfaced. 
B.  Curb, Gutter and Sidewalks. 
1.  Concrete curb and gutter shall be constructed to conform with specifications established by the city engineer. 
2.  Concrete sidewalks of such width and type of construction as required by Title 12 of this code shall be constructed. 
C.  Bridges and Culverts. Bridges and culverts large enough to take care of all natural flowage of water based upon then current state DNR standards and to take care of traffic for which the street was designed shall be constructed. 
D.  Utilities. Utilities shall be installed at the expense of the subdivider under the supervision of the city engineer and utility department. Prior to any water or sewer mains being installed, the plans must be submitted to the utility department for review, recommendation and approval. When approving any subdivision under this title, the council shall require the developer, in addition to any other requirements imposed by this title, to extend the service provided by all utilities to the end of the boundary lines of the property that is to be platted, such that such utilities form a complete extension to allow the abutting property of the subdivision to connect to the utility extensions. The payment for such extensions shall be done at the sole expense of the subdivider, by assessing a portion of the cost to abutting, benefitting properties, or some combination thereof as may be contained in a developer's agreement, as each individual case warrants. 
1.  Sanitary Sewer. The developer shall install a public sanitary sewer system adequate to provide the subdivision with a complete sanitary sewer system, including lateral connection initially into each lot and connected in a satisfactory manner to the city sanitary sewer system. Sewer mains shall be installed at sufficient depth to ensure use by the area adjacent to the subdivision installing the main. The design and construction of the sanitary sewer main extension shall conform to the design criteria of the River Falls Engineering Guidelines. 
a.  Minimum size of eight-inch sewer is required for new development. 
b.  If a pumping station is required to pump sanitary wastes, the subdivider shall install at no expense to the city a pumping station and force main approved by the city engineer and utility department adequate to service a subdivision and shall deed such pumping station, force main, equipment and site to the city prior to acceptance of the final plat. 
c.  No subdivision shall receive preliminary approval of sewer facilities installations until inspection by the city engineer and utility department. The developer shall not be relieved of responsibility for any sewer installation before one full year from the date of acceptance. 
2.  Water. The developer shall install a complete water distribution system adequate to serve the area being platted, including laterals into each lot. The system fire flow shall be adequate to meet commercial risk services standards. Further, the design and construction of the water main extension shall conform to the design criteria of the River Falls Engineering Guidelines. Calculations shall be based upon the maximum density of the lots in accordance with commercial risk services. 
a.  Water mains shall be looped wherever possible to ensure proper circulation of water throughout the system. No "dead-ends" shall be permitted if an interconnection can be made. 
b.  Gate valves shall be installed wherever the city engineer or utility representative deems them necessary in order that sectionalizing of the water system can be accomplished in the event of repairs or tie-ins. 
c.  Standard minimum size of eight inches is required for new development. Smaller than eight inches may only be used if approved by the city engineer. 
d.  Water mains and services shall be so installed at seven feet of cover depth below final finished grade to insure no freezing shall occur during the coldest weather experienced by this community. 
e.  Before final acceptance of the installed system by the city, sufficient evidence shall be presented to the city that the system has passed the state required bacteriological test, the state requirements for pressure and leakage tests and the city requirements for electrical continuity testing. The developer shall not be relieved of responsibility for any water main or services installation before one full year from the date of acceptance. 
f.  The developer shall furnish and install all necessary fire hydrants according to specifications established by the city engineer and the utility department. 
g.  All fire hydrants shall be installed with respect to final grade. Operation and maintenance specifications shall be adhered to when fire hydrants are installed. Adjustments of hydrants due to final grade shall be the developer's responsibility. 
h.  The plan commission, upon advice from the fire chief, city engineer, or the utility director, may require the developer to install private fire hydrants where deemed necessary. Such private fire hydrants shall be maintained at the developer's or land owner's expense. Further, such private fire hydrants shall be installed in compliance with all appropriate city specifications. 
3.  Storm Water Drainage. 
a.  A storm water sewer or drainage system adequate to serve the area being platted shall be required. When natural flowage of water from adjacent property passes through such development and it is desirable in the opinion of the city engineer and approved by the council to install a larger pipe than necessary for such development, the excess cost shall be determined and assessed under Section 16.16.010. In a developed area (seventy-five (75) percent platted) where a trunk storm sewer is constructed, the cost shall be borne equitably by the entire drainage area as provided by Section 13.12.050 of this code. 
b.  All storm sewers, where required, shall be designed by the rational method, unless otherwise agreed to by the city engineer. 
c.  Inlets shall be provided so that no surface water shall be carried across any intersection. Inlet spacing shall be determined by specifications outlined by the Wisconsin Department of Transportation. 
d.  If a pumping station is required to pump storm water, the subdivider shall install, at no expense to the city, a pumping station and force main as recommended by the city engineer and approved by the city council and adequate to service the subdivision and shall deed such pumping station, force main equipment and site to the city prior to acceptance of the final plat. 
e.  When it is determined that storm water runoff from a subdivision may affect downstream drainage areas, the city engineer shall study the effects of such drainage. No subdivision shall be approved where the city engineer and the plan commission determine that downstream drainage problems may result because of any subdivision. 
4.  Electric. Underground electric utilities shall be required in all new developments, unless determined to be impractical by the utility department. Insofar as possible, lots closest to the sources of power, water and sewer shall be developed first. 
(Prior code § 18.07(2)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-08 , § 13, 6-14-2016) 
16.16.030 - Construction plans and inspection required. 
A.  Approval. Copies of approvals and request for approval shall be in writing and attached to the final plat. 
B.  Construction Plans. Whenever any improvements are required by the city, construction plans for improvements to be installed shall be furnished in accordance with the specifications of the officials having jurisdiction and shall receive approval of these officials before improvements are installed. The following plans may be required: 
1.  The profile of each proposed street with tentative grades indicated. 
2.  The cross section of each proposed street showing the width of pavement, curb and gutter; the location and width of sidewalks and terraces; and the location and size of the utility mains. 
3.  The plans and profiles of proposed sanitary sewers and storm water sewers, with grades and sizes indicated, or method of sewage or storm water disposal in lieu of sewers. 
4.  Any other plans or information, whether enumerated herein or not, may be required by the officials having jurisdiction. 
C.  Inspections. Prior to starting any of the work covered by the plans approved as above, arrangements shall be made to provide for inspection by the city engineer of the work, sufficient in the opinion of the engineer and council, to ensure compliance with the plans and specifications as approved, and written approval obtained from the city engineer and council to start the work. All costs of such inspection by its engineer shall be borne by the city. 
D.  Contractors. The subdivider is to engage his or her own contractors on his or her own responsibility for all required work, subject to approval by the city engineer and other officials having jurisdiction. 
(Prior code § 18.07(3)) 
16.16.040 - Stage development. 
    In all instances where it appears to the satisfaction of the city council that the whole of the plat and its subdivision cannot immediately be fully improved with respect to the installation of all storm and sanitary sewers and related facilities, water mains and related facilities and street improvements by reason of unavoidable delay in the acquisition of land necessary for such improvement or by reason of unavoidable delay in obtaining necessary engineering data and information or for any other good reason or cause, the city council may, in its sole discretion, authorize the subdivider to proceed with the installation of improvements required under this title on a portion or part of the subdivision, and in such event the requirements of this title shall apply to that portion or part thereof authorized for immediate improvement. 
(Prior code § 18.07(4)) 
Chapter 16.20 - DEDICATIONS FOR PARKS AND RECREATIONAL AREAS 
Sections: 

16.20.010 - Recreation, park or open areas. 
A.  Whenever a development is created, or when a parcel of land is developed which involves any division of land by minor subdivision herein referred to as a certified survey map (CSM) or subdivision, e.g., a plat regardless of size, the developer shall be required to dedicate for parks, playgrounds and other open space purposes, a parcel of land equal to ten (10) percent of the gross area of all property proposed for subdivision. Such parcel shall be shown and marked on the plat, "Dedicated for Park or Recreation Purposes." This provision shall also apply to all outlots in existence or annexed to the city as of February 14, 1995. 
B.  The council may require the lands dedicated for park, playgrounds, recreation and open space purposes be of a character, size and location suitable for such use and purpose and may further require it to be relatively level and dry. All such parcels shall be reviewed and recommended by the park and recreation board and the plan commission, prior to council approval. The formula for land dedication shall be as follows: 
Land Dedication Subdivision Type 10% Industrial Commercial and Office 10% (0-3 units per acre) Residential Add 1% for each unit above 3 with a maximum cap of 20%  
C.  Where a proposed park, playground, recreation or open space area is shown on the official map or master plan of the city to be located in whole or in part within the proposed development, the council shall require the dedication of such area within the development. If the official map or master plan provides for an area in excess of the required amount, the council shall, before it takes final action on the plat, consider the official map or master plan and together with the appropriate boards, determine if it should take the necessary steps to acquire, through purchase, all or part of the park, playground, recreation or open space area as shown on the official map or master plan. 
D.  Where, with respect to a particular development, the dedication of a parcel of land for parks, playground, recreation or open space purposes, does not comply with the official map or the master plan; and as determined by the park board, the plan commission and the council and the dedication of such parcel would not be in the public interest, the city shall require a dedication fee, as established in accordance with state statute. 
1.  Dedication fees shall be established through periodic fee needs assessments as implemented from time to time upon resolutions adopted by the common council. 
2.  Planned unit development with mixed land uses shall make cash payments and/or land contributions in accordance with this section based upon the percentage of land devoted to the various uses. 
3.  Should the city determine that it is in the best interest of the city to require a land dedication that is less than that specified in Section 16.20.010(B), the fair market value of that dedication shall be determined at the time the final plat or certified survey is approved in accordance with the following: 
a.  The city and developer may agree to the fair market value; or 
b.  The fair market value may be based on the current appraisal submitted to the city by the subdivider at the subdivider's expense. The appraisal shall be made by appraisers who are approved members of the SERA or MAI, or equivalent real estate appraisal societies. 
c.  If the city disputes such appraisal the city may, at their own expense, obtain an appraisal of the property by a qualified real estate appraiser, said appraisal may be deemed conclusive evidence of fair market value of the land. 
E.  If land dedication is not required, or required in part, the face of the final plat shall include a statement that park dedication fees are due and payable by the owner of each lot at the time of building permit issuance. The statement will also include the percentage of dedication fee due, if less than one hundred (100) percent. 
(Ord. 2007-16 § 1; Ord. 2001-6: Ord. 1999-28: prior code § 18.09) 
(Ord. No. 2011-13, § 1, 12-13-2011) 
Chapter 16.24 - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS FOR LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS 
Sections: 

16.24.010 - Alternate method selected. 
    As provided in Section 66.0701, Wis. Stats., in addition to other methods provided by law, special assessments for any public work and improvement may be levied by alternate methods. The council elects to levy such special assessments as provided in this section. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 18.11(1)) 
16.24.020 - Preliminary resolution. 
    Whenever the city council shall determine that any public work or improvement shall be financed in whole or in part by special assessments levied under this section, it shall adopt a preliminary resolution setting forth the following: 
A.  Its intent to exercise its police powers for the purpose of levying special assessments for the stated municipal purpose; 
B.  The limits of the proposed assessment district; 
C.  The time, either before or after completion of the work or improvement, when the amount of such assessments shall be determined or levied; 
D.  The number of installments in which the special assessments may be paid or that the number of installments will be determined after the public hearing required by Section 16.24.040 and will be included in the final resolution. 
E.  The rate of interest to be charged on the unpaid installments or that the rate of interest will be determined after the public hearing required by Section 16.24.040 and will be included in the final resolution. 
F.  The terms on which any of such assessments may be deferred while no use of the improvement is made in connection with the property or that such terms will be determined after the public hearing required by Section 16.24.040 and will be included in the final resolution. 
G.  The director of public works/city engineer shall prepare a report as required by Section 16.24.030. 
(Prior code § 18.11(2)) 
16.24.030 - Report of director of public works/city engineer. 
    Whenever the city council by preliminary resolution directs the director of public works/city engineer to prepare a report, the director of public works/city engineer shall prepare a report consisting of the following: 
A.  Preliminary or final plans and specifications for the public work; 
B.  An estimate of the entire cost of the proposed work or improvements, except that when the city council determines by preliminary resolution that the hearing on such assessments shall be held subsequent to the completion of the work or improvements, the report shall contain a statement of the final cost of the work, service or improvement in lieu of an estimate of such costs; 
C.  A schedule of the proposed assessments; 
D.  A statement that each property against which the assessments are proposed has been inspected and is benefited, setting forth the basis of such benefit; 
E.  Upon completion of the report, the director of public works/city engineer shall file a copy of the report with the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 18.11(3)) 
16.24.040 - Incorporation of statutory provisions. 
    The provisions of Section 66.0703, Wis. Stats., including those related to notice, hearing and the adoption of a final resolution, shall to the extent not inconsistent with this chapter apply to special assessments levied under this chapter. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 18.11(4)) 
16.24.050 - Lien. 
    Every special assessment levied under this chapter shall be a lien against the property assessment from the date of the final resolution of the city council determining the amount of such levy. 
(Prior code § 18.11(5)) 
16.24.060 - Appeals. 
    The provisions of Sections 66.0703(12) and 66.0701(2), Wis. Stats., relating to appeals, shall apply to any special assessment levied under this chapter. 
(Amended during Supplement #1; prior code § 18.11(6)) 
( Ord. No. 2016-03 , § 1, 5-10-2016) 
16.24.070 - Interest. 
    The interest charged on any assessment levied pursuant to this chapter shall bear a rate of one-half of one percent above the interest rate charged to the city on the bonds, notes or other methods of financing issued to enable the construction and completion of the necessary improvements connected with the project. 
(Prior code § 18.11(7)) 
Title 17 - ZONING 
Chapters: 
Chapter 17.04 - INTRODUCTORY PROVISIONS AND DEFINITIONS 
Sections: 

17.04.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this title is: 
A.  To promote and protect the health, safety and general welfare of the city and its people; 
B.  To promote orderly growth and development in the city; 
C.  To promote compatible uses of land throughout the city; 
D.  To prevent overcrowding of land and unreasonable concentrating of population; 
E.  To prevent deterioration of the environment by regulating uses of land and structures in the city; 
F.  To protect and stabilize property values that could be undermined by the development of incompatible uses on adjacent or nearby property; 
G.  To limit congestion in the public streets and to protect the public health and welfare by regulating off-street vehicular parking and vehicle loading spaces; 
H.  To protect against fire, explosion, noxious fumes, pollution of the environment and other hazards; 
I.  To provide adequate light, air and privacy, and to provide convenient access to property; 
J.  To facilitate efficiency in providing public services and protecting public investments; 
K.  To divide the city into zones or districts by the size, location, construction, reconstruction, alteration and use of land and structures for residential, business and industrial purposes; and 
L.  To define and limit the powers of the administrative officers and bodies provided herein. 
(Prior code § 21.01) 
17.04.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this title: 
    "Accessory building or use" means a subordinate building or use which is located on the same lot on which the main building or use is situated and which is reasonable, necessary and incidental to the conduct of the primary use of such building or main use. 
    "Alley" means a public right-of-way not less than sixteen (16) feet wide, and not more than thirty (30) feet wide, which serves only as a secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    "Apartment" means a room or suite of rooms which is arranged, designed, used or intended to be used as a housekeeping unit for a single family in a multifamily dwelling. 
    Apartment Building. See "Dwelling, Multiple." 
    "Automobile repair" means general repair, engine rebuilding or reconditioning of motor vehicles; collision service such as body, frame or fender straightening and repair which use is distinct from auto wrecking yards. 
    "Automobile service station" means a place where gasoline (stored only in underground tanks) kerosene, motor oil, lubricants or grease for operation of motor vehicles is retailed directly to the public and where minor vehicle repairs and rebuildings are performed. When the dispensing, sale or offering for sale of motor fuel or oil is incidental to the conduct of a public garage, the premises shall be classified as a public garage. 
    "Auto wrecking yard" means any place used for wrecking or storing in the open of two or more motor vehicles not in running condition, or parts thereof; and including any farm vehicles or farm machinery, or parts thereof; stored in the open and not being restored to operating condition; and including the commercial salvaging and scavenging of any other goods, articles and merchandise. 
    "Basement" means a portion of a building located partially or wholly underground. 
    "Billboard" means a structure which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity or entertainment not necessarily conducted or offered upon the premises where the structure is located. 
    "Block" means a tract of land within a platted subdivision bounded by streets or a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, shorelines, waterways or boundary lines or the corporate limits of the city. 
    "Boarding house" means any dwelling other than a hotel, motel or restaurant where meals or lodgings and meals for compensation are provided for five persons or more, pursuant to previous arrangements and not to anyone who may apply. 
    "Buildable area" means the area of a lot remaining after the minimum setback and open space requirements have been complied with. 
    "Building" means any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls, and designed or intended for the shelter, support, enclosure or protection of persons, animals or chattels. 
    "Building or structure height" means the vertical distance measured from the average level of the highest and lowest point of that portion of a lot covered by the building as measured around the entire perimeter of the foundation to the highest point of the cornice of a flat roof or to the midpoint of a pitched roof. 

    "Carport" means a private garage which is open to the weather on at least two sides, intended for sheltering not more than two motor driven vehicles. 
    "Cemetery" means any land, including any mausoleum or columbarium on the land, which is used or intended to be used for the burial of human remains. 
    "Columbarium" means a building, structure, or part of a building or structure that is used or intended to be used for the inurnment of cremated remains. 
    "Columbarium niche" means a space in a columbarium that is used or intended to be used for the inurnment of cremated remains. 
    "Conservation park" means areas developed for compatible uses by the general public and for outdoor education for all citizens with a focus on active land stewardship to maintain and restore native plant communities, native animal communities and cultural/historic resources. A conservation park exhibits one or more of the following attributes in varying degrees: unique plant communities, wildlife populations, geological formations, or historical sites; a critical ecological function, such as protecting surface or ground water quality and supply; relatively undisturbed examples of native biological communities; location and features suitable for outdoor education programs; outstanding aesthetic qualities. 
    "Court" means an open unoccupied space bounded on two or more sides by the exterior walls of a building or buildings on the same lot. 
    "Cremated remains" or, cremains, means the ashes of a cremated human body. 
    "Curb level" means the level of the established curb in front of the building measured at the center of such front. Where a building faces on more than one street, the curb level shall be the average of the levels of the curbs at the center of the front of each street. 
    Day Care, Nursery. "Nursery day care" means a licensed facility where person(s) provide, for compensation or consideration for service, group care for four or more children under seven years of age for less than twenty-four (24) hours a day. 
    "Deck" means an exterior floor system supported on at least two opposing sides by an adjoining structure and/or posts, piers, or other independent supports, with a permeable floor which allows the infiltration of precipitation. 
    "District" means a section or sections of the incorporated area of the city for which the regulations and provisions governing the use of building and land are uniform for each class of use permitted therein. 
    Duplex. See "Dwelling, Two-Family." 
    "Dwelling" means a building or portion thereof, but not including a trailer or mobilehome, designed or used exclusively for residential occupancy, including one-family, two-family and multiple-family dwelling units, but not including hotels, motels, boarding or lodging houses. 
    "Dwelling, Attached. "Attached dwelling" means two or more single-family dwelling units attached and contiguous to each other by sharing a common wall or walls, with each unit having its own utility connections and individual entrances from the outdoors. 
    "Dwelling unit" means one or more rooms in a dwelling or apartment hotel designed for occupancy by one family for living purposes and having its own permanently installed cooking and sanitary facilities. 
    Dwelling, One-Family. "One-family dwelling" means a detached dwelling designed for or occupied exclusively by one family. 
    Dwelling, Two-Family. "Two-family dwelling" means a dwelling designed exclusively for occupancy by two families living independently of each other. 
    Dwelling, Multiple. "Multiple dwelling" means a dwelling designed for and containing three or more dwelling units, the occupants of which live independently of each other. 
    "Family." 
1.  In the (R1) single-family (low density) residence district, "family" means an individual or two or more persons related by blood or marriage, adoption or legal guardianship, or evidence of a stable family relationship or a group of not more than four persons unrelated by blood or marriage, living together for single housekeeping in a dwelling unit. The right to maintain up to and including five unrelated persons in a preexisting rental dwelling unit in a single-family zoning district shall continue until such time as total structural repairs and alterations during its life exceeds fifty (50) percent of the assessed value of the rental dwelling unit or until such time as the dwelling unit is destroyed by fire or casualty or for a period of fifteen (15) years from the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section, whichever shall occur first. This right shall also terminate immediately should the tax parcel be found to have more than five unrelated individuals living within any rental dwelling unit with the knowledge of the landlord or the property manager. 
2.  In the (R2) multiple-family (medium density) residence district and (R3) high density residence district, "family" means an individual or two or more persons related by blood or marriage, or evidence of a stable family relationship, or a group of not more than five persons unrelated by blood or marriage living together for single housekeeping in a dwelling unit. 
    "Farming" means the cultivation and growing of soil crops in the customary manner on open tracts of land; the raising of animals or poultry, except kennels and farms for disposal of garbage or offal; and the incidental retail selling by the producer of farm products raised on the premises. 
    "Farming general" means the growing of crops on existing non-forested tracts of land equal to or greater than thirty-five (35) acres in size but does not include the raising of livestock or the erection of or use of structures for agriculturally related purposes. For purposes of this definition, a tract of land shall constitute a lot or parcel of land on record at the register of deeds office prior to February 13, 2007. The incidental retail sale by the producer of farm products raised on such tract of land shall be allowed. Farming operations in existence at least five years prior to annexation may continue their operation. This includes preservation of the type and size of operation including livestock and crops. 
    "Floor area ratio (F.A.R.)" means the gross floor area of the building or buildings on that zoning lot divided by the area of such zoning lot or in the case of planned unit developments, by the net site area. 
    Floor Area, Gross. "Gross floor area" means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors of the building measured from the exterior faces of the exterior walls. 
    Floor Area, Livable. "Livable floor area" means the same as "floor area, gross" defined above, excluding all areas occupied by garages, porches, attics, stairways and storage, utility and heating rooms. 
    "Fraternity or sorority house" means a building occupied or to be occupied, by an organized group of ten (10) or more students and providing for a succession of memberships therein, where lodging or board or both are provided only for its members and guests of its members. 
    "Frontage" means the property of a lot on the side or sides nearest the street. For the purposes of yard requirements on corner lots and through lots, all sides of a lot adjacent to streets shall be considered frontage and yards shall be provided as indicated under yards in this section. 
    Garage, Private. "Private garage" means an accessory building designed to accommodate storage for vehicles, boats, trailers or recreational vehicles having a load rating of one ton or less used by the occupant of the building to which it is accessory. 
    Garage, Public. "Public garage" means any premises used for the storage or care of motor-driven vehicles or premises where any such vehicles are equipped for operation, are repaired or are kept for remuneration, for hire or for sale. 
    Garage, Truck. "Truck garage" means a building which is used or intended to be used for storage of motor trucks, truck trailers, tractors, semi-trailers and vehicles exceeding one ton in capacity. 
    "Gazebo" means a free standing roofed structure that is open on all sides. 
    Grade, Street. "Street grade" means the elevation of the established street the building measured at the center of such front. Where no street grade has been established, the city engineer shall establish such street grade or its equivalent for the purpose of this title. 
    "Group home" means a facility which provides twenty-four (24) hour service to three or more unrelated adults who reside in a facility where care, treatment or services are offered above the level of room and board, but not including nursing services. 
    "High rise building" means any structure designed for a specific use, the height of which exceeds forty-eight (48) feet. 
    "Home occupation" means an occupation or business activity that results in any commercial activity or enterprise for financial gain, benefit, advantage, livelihood, product or service that is conducted for gainful employment in a dwelling unit by a person residing in that dwelling unit. A home occupation is incidental to the residential use of the dwelling unit. 
    "Hospital" means an institution providing primary health services in medical or surgical care to persons, suffering from illness, disease, injury, deformity, and other abnormal physical or mental conditions, and including, as an integral part of the institution, related facilities such as laboratories, in- and out-patient facilities or training facilities. 
    "Hotel" means a building designed for occupancy as the temporary abiding place of individuals who are lodged with or without meals, in which there are six or more guest rooms or suites. 
    "Industrial park" means a special or exclusive type of planned industrial area designed and equipped to accommodate a community of industries, providing them with necessary facilities and services in surroundings compatible with neighboring uses. 
    "Junk yard" means land or buildings where waste, discarded or salvaged materials are bought, sold, exchanged, stored, cleaned, packed, disassembled or handled including, but not limited to, scrap metal, rags, papers, rubber, glass and lumber products and products from wrecking automobiles or other vehicles. 
    "Kennel" means any lot or premises on which four or more dogs at least four months of age are kept. 
    "Laboratory" means a place devoted to experimental study such as research, testing and analyzing. Manufacturing of a product is not included within this definition. 
    "Loading space" means an off-street space or berth on the same lot with a building or contiguous to a group of buildings for the temporary parking of a vehicle while loading or unloading merchandise or materials and which abuts upon a street, alley or other appropriate means of access. 
    "Lodging house" means a building with not more than five guest rooms where lodging is provided for compensation pursuant to previous arrangements but not open to the public or transients. 
    "Lot" means a parcel of land occupied or suitable for occupancy by one main building or use, with the accessory buildings, having its frontage upon a public street or highway. 
    "Lot area" means the square feet of land area within the lot lines. 
    "Lot coverage" means the area of a zoned lot occupied by the principal building or buildings and accessory buildings. 
    "Lot depth" means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
    "Lot of record" means a lot which is a part of a platted subdivision, the map of which has been recorded in the office of the register of deeds or a lot description by the metes and bounds, the deed to which was recorded in the office of the register of deeds prior to June 20, 1966. 
    "Lot width" means the horizontal distance between the side lot lines measured at right angles to the lot depth at the established front building line. 
    Lot, Corner. "Corner lot" means a lot located at the intersection of two streets or a lot bounded on two sides by a curving street, two chords of which form an angle of one hundred twenty (120) degrees or less measured on the lot side. 
    Lot, Double Frontage. "Double frontage lot" means a lot having frontage on two nonintersecting streets, as distinguished from a corner lot. 
    Lot, Interior. "Interior lot" means a lot other than a corner or reversed corner lot. 
    Lot Line, Front. "Front lot line" means the boundary of a lot abutting a street. On a corner lot, the shortest street lot line shall be the front lot line. 
    Lot Line, Rear. "Rear lot line" means the lot line or lot lines most nearly parallel to and remote from the front lot line. Lot lines other than front or rear lot lines are side lot lines. 
    "Mausoleum" means a building, structure or part of a building or structure that is used or intended to be used for the interment of human remains. 
    "Mausoleum space" means a niche, crypt or specific place in a mausoleum that contains or is intended to contain human remains. 
    Mini-warehouse. See "personal storage facility." 
    "Mobilehome" means a factory building structure more than eight feet in width and more than thirty-six (36) feet in length, equipped with the necessary service connections and electrical systems contained therein and made so as to be readily movable as a unit or units on its or their own running gear and designed to be used as a dwelling unit or units without a permanent foundation. 
    "Mobilehome park" means any plot or tract of ground upon which twenty (20) or more mobilehomes occupied for dwelling purposes are located, provided that such mobilehome is either occupied by the person who owns the mobilehome and the real estate upon which it is located or that the occupant of the mobilehome rents or leases the mobilehome or real estate upon which it is located from the owner thereof. No other land use shall be allowed other than those uses considered as an integral part of the mobilehome park. 
    "Mobilehome sales lot" means a lot, site, field or tract of land on which mobilehomes are displayed for sale. 
    "Motel" means a combination or group of two or more detached, semi-detached or connected dwellings occupying a building site integrally owned as a unit to furnish overnight living accommodations. 
    "Municipal water and sewer systems" means utility systems serving a group of buildings, lots or an area of the city with the design and construction of such utility systems as approved by the city. 
    "Nameplate" means a sign indicating the owner or the practice of a permitted occupation therein. 
    "Nonconforming building" means a building or structure or portion thereof which lawfully existed prior to the establishment of the zoning district in which it is now located which does not conform to the regulations for the zoning district in which it is now located. 
    "Nonconforming use" means an active, actual and continuous use of land, buildings or structure which was lawful prior to the establishment of the zoning district in which located and which does not conform to the use regulations for the zoning district in which located. 
    "Odorous matter" means any matter or material that yields an odor which is offensive in any way. 
    "Open space" means that area completely unobstructed by buildings, structures, roadways, parking facilities or other similar improvements. Open space may include required areas for side yard, front and rear setbacks as determined within the district regulation of this chapter. Open space may also include improvements that are of a recreational nature that are accessible to residents of the property in question. 
    "Open space ratio" means the minimum square footage of open space required for each square foot of floor area per floor. 
    "Parking space" means a land area of not less than one hundred eighty (180) square feet, exclusive of driveways and aisles, of such shape and dimensions and so prepared as to be usable for the parking of a motor vehicle and so located as to be readily accessible to a public street or alley. 
    "Particulate matter" means any dust, smoke or other form of airborne pollution in the form of minute separate particles. 
    "Personal storage facility" (see also "mini-warehouse") means uses oriented to the indoor storage of personal or small business related items entirely within partitioned buildings having an individual access to each partitioned area. Such storage areas may be available on either a condominium or rental basis. 
    "Plot" means a tract other than one unit of a recorded plat or subdivision and occupied and used as a home site and improved by the erection thereon of a dwelling and accessory buildings and having a frontage upon a public street, a thoroughfare or a highway or traveled or used road. 
    "Public open space" means any publicly owned open area including but not limited to parks, playgrounds, school sites, parkways and boulevards. 
    "Public utility" means any person, department or board authorized to furnish, under municipal regulation to the public, electricity, gas, steam, communication services, telegraph service, transportation or water. 
    "Public way" means any sidewalk, bikeway, street, alley, highway or other public thoroughfare. 
    "Religious association" means an association, conference, congregation, convention, committee, or other entity that is organized and operated for a religious purpose and that is exempt from federal income tax under 26 USC 501(c)(3) or (d) and any subunit of such an association, conference, congregation, convention, committee, or entity that is organized and operated for a religious purpose. 
    "Rest home or nursing home" means a home for the care of children or the aged or infirm or a place of rest for those suffering bodily disorders. Such home does not contain equipment for surgical care. 
    "Rooming unit" or "lodging unit" means a room rented as sleeping and living quarters, but without cooking facilities and with or without an individual bathroom. In a suite of rooms without cooking facilities, each room which provides sleeping accommodations shall be counted as one lodging room or rooming unit. 
    "School" means any public or private institution, building or part thereof that is designated, constructed, or used for education or instruction of knowledge and including, as an integral part of the institution, related facilities and properties. 
    "Screen porch" means a structure on or near the exterior of the house that has been covered by window screens to hinder insects, debris and other undesirable objects entering the area inside the screen. 
    "Semi-trailer" means a vehicle of the trailer type so designed and used in conjunction with a truck-tractor so that a considerable part of its own weight or that of its load rests upon and is carried by the truck-tractor semi-trailer combination. 
    "Setback line" means the minimum horizontal distance between the lot line and the line of the building or the allowable building line as defined by the regulations of this chapter. 
    "Sign" means any words, letters, figures, numerals, phrases, sentences, emblems, devices, trade names or trademarks by which anything is made known and which are used to advertise or promote an individual, firm, association, corporation, professional business, commodity or product and which are visible from any public street or highway. 
    Sign, Advertising. "Advertising sign" means a sign which directs attention to a business, commodity, service, activity or entertainment not necessarily conducted, sold or offered upon the premises where such sign is located. 
    Sign, Business. "Business sign" means a sign which directs attention to a business or profession or to a commodity, service or entertainment sold or offered upon the premises where such a sign is located. 
    "Sign display surface" means that portion of a sign on which information or advertisement may be displayed. 
    Sign, Flashing. "Flashing sign" means an illuminated sign on which such illumination is not kept stationary or constant in intensity and color when the sign is in use. 
    Sign, Illuminated. "Illuminated sign" means a sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outlines illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as a part of the sign. 
    Sign, Pylon. "Pylon sign" means a free-standing sign erected upon a single pylon or post which is in excess of ten (10) feet in height. 
    Sign, Rotating. "Rotating sign" means a sign which revolves or rotates on its axis. 
    "Story" means that portion of a building included between the surface of any floor and the surface of the floor next above it; or, if there is no such floor above, the space between such floor and the ceiling next above it. 
    Story, Half. "Half story" means a space under a sloping roof which has the line of intersection of roof decking and wall face not more than three feet above the top floor level and in which space not more than two-thirds of the floor area is finished off for use. A half story containing independent apartment or living quarters shall be counted as a full story. 
    "Street" means a public or private right-of-way which affords a primary means of vehicular access to abutting property, whether designated as a street, avenue, highway, road, boulevard, thoroughfare or however otherwise designated but does not include driveways to buildings. 
    "Structural alterations" means any change in the supporting members of a building such as bearing walls, columns, beams or girders or any substantial changes in the roof or exterior walls. 
    "Structure" means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent location on the ground or attachment to something having a permanent location on the ground. 
    Structure, Attached. "Attached structure" means a structure joined to other structures by part walls or walls. 
    Structure, Detached. "Detached structure" means a structure entirely surrounded by open space, such open space being on the same zoned lot as the structure. 
    Swimming Pool, Private. "Private swimming pool" means any pool, tank, depression or excavation in or above ground or other structure that causes retaining of water of depth greater than twenty-four (24) inches and has a plane surface of water greater than one hundred fifty (150) square feet which is designed or used for swimming or immersion purposes and serves fewer than three individual dwelling units, such as homes or apartments. 
    "Townhouses" means attached dwellings having common side walls with each unit having a separate front and rear entrance from the outdoors. 
    "Trailer" means every vehicle without motive power designed for carrying persons or property and for being drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    "Travel trailer" means a vehicular, portable structure identified from the manufacturer as a travel trailer, built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses and when equipped for the road, having a width not exceeding eight feet and a body length not exceeding thirty-two (32) feet. 
    "Use" means a purpose for which land or premises or a building thereon is designated, arranged or intended or for which it is or may be occupied or maintained. 
    Use, Special. "Special use" means a use which is generally not suitable in a particular zoning district, but which may under some circumstances and with the application or conditions as prescribed in a special use permit be suitable. For the purposes of this title, special uses shall also mean special exceptions as defined in Section 62.23, Wis. Stats. 
    Use, Principal. "Principal use" means the main use of land or buildings as distinguished from a subordinate or accessory use. A principal use may be permitted or conditional. 
    Use, Permitted. "Permitted use" means a use which is lawfully established in a particular zoning district, provided it conforms with all requirements, regulations and standards of such district. 
    "Variance" means a modification of or waiver from the strict interpretation of the provisions of this title as applied to a specific piece of property. 
    "Yard" means an open space on the same zoning lot with a building or structure, which yard is unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward. 
    Yard, Front. "Front yard" means a yard extending across the front lot line between the side yard lines and lying between the front lot line and the nearest part of the main building. On corner lots formed by the intersection of two streets, the front yard is the yard adjacent to the front lot line of least lineal distance. 
    Yard, Rear. "Rear yard" means an open space unoccupied, except for accessory buildings, on the same lot with a building between the nearest of the main building and the rear lot line for the full width of the lot. 
    Yard, Side. "Side yard" means an open, unoccupied space on the same lot with a building between the building and the side line of the lot and extending from the front yard to the rear yard. 
    "Zoning map" means the map or maps incorporated into this title as a part hereof designating the use districts. 
(Ord. 2007-22; Ord. 2007-02; Ord. 2006-23; Ord. 2006-13 (part); Ord. 2005-1 § 1; Ord. 2000-22; prior code § 21.02) 
( Ord. No. 2017-05 , § 1, 3-14-2017; Ord. No. 2017-09 , § 1, 4-11-2017; Ord. No. 2017-10 , § 1, 4-11-2017; Ord. No. 2017-19 , § 1, 11-14-2017) 
17.04.030 - Interpretation. 
A.  The provisions of this title shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the city and shall be construed in favor of the city and shall not be deemed a limitation or repair of any power granted by the Wisconsin Statutes. 
B.  These provisions are not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant or any other private agreement, provided that where these regulations are more restrictive or impose higher standards or requirements than the easement covenant or other private agreement, the requirements of the provisions of this title shall prevail. 
C.  Those uses listed as permitted uses in each zoning district shall be interpreted to be nonexclusive and that similar uses may be permitted upon interpretation by the plan commission. 
(Prior code § 21.03) 
Chapter 17.08 - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 
Sections: 

17.08.010 - Lot and building regulations. 
A.  Lot Area and Population. No lot area shall be so reduced or diminished that the yards or other open spaces shall be smaller than prescribed by this title, nor shall the density of population be increased in any manner except in conformity with the area regulations as hereinafter provided, nor shall the area of any lots be reduced below the minimum requirement herein established. 
B.  Building Access Requirements. 
1.  Access Requirements. No principal building shall be erected or structurally altered unless there is direct access from a public street or highway. No building shall hereafter be erected or altered so as to close the present means of access to an existing principal building unless another access is provided. 
2.  Number of Principal Buildings. There shall be no more than one single-family or duplex structure on any lot of record. There may be more than one multiple dwelling, commercial, industrial or university structure on a lot of record if all parking, open space and other district regulations are complied with for each structure. For the purpose of these regulations, townhouses and condominiums shall be defined as multiple dwelling structures. 
C.  General Provisions. The following general provisions, in addition to the regulations prescribed for each district, shall apply to all districts: 
1.  Yard Size. Yard size measurements shall be taken from the nearest point of the building which shall include any porch, eave, overhang or appurtenance that is attached thereto. 
2.  Rear Yard Depth. In determining the depth of rear yards for any principal building where the rear yard opens into the alley, half the width of the alley, but not exceeding ten (10) feet, may be considered as a portion or the rear yard subject to the following: 
a.  The depth of the rear yard shall not be reduced to less than ten (10) feet by the application of the exception. 
b.  If the door of any building or improvement except a fence opens forward to an alley, it shall not be erected or established closer to the center line of an alley than a distance of fifteen (15) feet and not closer than five feet from the property line. 
3.  Attached Dwellings. Attached dwellings shall be subject to the following provisions: 
a.  Attached dwelling proposals shall be presented to the plan commission as certified surveys or subdivision plats as defined and outlined in Ordinance No. 13.06 and Ch. 236, Wis. Stats., et seq. 
b.  Certified surveys shall be permitted where the division of any lot, parcel or tract of land creates four or less parcels. 
c.  Proposals creating five or more parcels shall require the submittal of a subdivision plat in accordance with applicable regulations and statutes. 
d.  The approval of attached dwelling development or conversion shall be by special use permit and occur only after the plan commission and the city council have accepted or approved any private easements, agreements, covenants or other provisions that may be required. 
e.  Attached dwellings are permitted as a special use in the R1, R2 and R3 districts. This form of construction or conversion shall not create development that exceeds the density standards of a particular zoning district. Through the certified survey or subdivision plan, legal ownership of parcels smaller than those specified in the subdivision code may be allowed, while the special use permit prohibits nonconforming changes to an approved attached dwelling in the future. 
4.  Attached Accessory Buildings. An attached accessory building or structure shall be subject to the setback and yard requirements of and as if it were a part of the principal building or use. 
5.  Unattached Accessory. Unattached accessory buildings in any zone shall be subject to the following conditions: 
a.  No detached accessory building or structure shall occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the area of a required yard. 
b.  No detached accessory building or structure shall exceed the height of the principal building structure. 
c.  Detached accessory buildings shall have the same front yard setback requirements as the principal building or structure and shall not be allowed to encroach upon the front yard or beyond the front building line. 
d.  No detached accessory building shall be closer than five feet from the rear lot line. 
e.  No detached accessory building shall be closer than five feet from the side lot line. 
f.  The minimum distance between the principal building and an unattached accessory building shall be five feet. 
6.  [Decks.] For purposes of this chapter, a deck shall be subject to the following. 
a.  No deck shall occupy more than thirty (30) percent of the area of a required yard. 
b.  A deck shall have the same front yard setback requirements as the principal building and shall not be allowed to encroach upon the front yard setback. 
c.  No deck shall be closer than fifteen (15) feet from the rear lot line. 
d.  No deck shall be closer than five feet from the side lot line. 
e.  No deck shall be closer than fifteen (15) feet from the side lot line on a corner lot. 
f.  No deck shall encroach on a recorded easement. 
    A deck, gazebo or screen porch that is intended to be integrated into the principal structure by a roof extension, walls, or other improvements that partially or fully enclose it, shall be subject to the setback and yard requirements of the principal building. 
(Prior code § 21.04) 
( Ord. No. 2017-19 , § 2, 11-14-2017) 
17.08.020 - Driveway regulations. 
    All private driveways to or from public streets shall be subject to the following restrictions:
